debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I seek leave to amend the motion standing in my name to refer certain matters to a standing committee.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: (a) omit `Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade' and substitute `Finance and Public Administration'.
(b) omit paragraphs (b) and (f)
(c) omit in paragraph (e) the words `and discipline within the Department' and substitute `staff performance and accountability'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. I move:

speech.para: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report:

The management and operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and whether that Department is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests, with particular regard to the following:
(a) management systems and program evaluation procedures;
(b) security procedures and custody of classified material;
(c) overseas conditions of service and their implications for efficiency and effectiveness; and
(d) morale, staff performance and accountability.

talk.start.para: â€”I was wondering why the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has been substituted for the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I consider that the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration might have been the best. Senator Hill has not explained why the substitution has taken place.

â€”by leave-I intervene in the debate simply to say that there was a thought that perhaps the skills of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration are more appropriate to an inquiry which is basically dealing with administrative matters within the Department. It is an arguable point that because it is an inquiry into aspects of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade the skills of those within the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, because of their particular interest in the subject matters of that Department, might be appropriate. On balance, and through discussions, it was thought that it might be more appropriate to keep the concentration on the more technical questions of administration on security aspects that had been demonstrated to fail rather than give the foreign affairs emphasis to it. The explanation really is as simple as that.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”While I fully acknowledge the principle of accountability to parliament for the administration of government departments, and I fully accept that principle, I believe that this particular reference, even in the narrowed down form in which it has now been moved, is both unnecessary and regrettable. I have a healthy sense of realism about the numbers in this place and will not pursue the objections that we have to this to the point of division as a result because it would simply be wasting time.

speech.para: But I do want to say quickly for the record that I think this is misconceived. It is unnecessary because, in the first place, there is ample opportunity available under existing Estimates committee procedures to explore the kinds of issues which are raised in this reference. That is an opportunity which the Committee has never been backward in pursuing at some considerable length in the past. Secondly, it is unnecessary because there is really no prima facie reason to suppose that there is any serious problems with the management of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Part of the atmosphere which underlies this motion was unquestionably that generated by the extraordinary series of allegations about corruption and maladministration in my Department, most of which were made by a single individual, a great many of which were made in a great batch of allegations, some 77 of them in May last year, and all which have now been the subject of detailed investigation and endorsement of that investigation by the Australian National Audit Office.

At most, very minor matters of administrative failure were revealed by those investigations and overwhelmingly the allegations, many of which have been quite extreme and had quite a lot of publicity, have been shown to be utterly without foundation. Similarly, the assumptions that are made in the terms of reference about leaking from the Department, security of information being a major concern, is something that I do not accept on the basis in which it is clearly implied in the text of this motion. The assumption is made that leaks of foreign affairs material which have occurred are all to be attributed to my Department. That is simply not an assumption which is reasonable from everything that all of us know about the way in which this particular place works.

Moreover, such leaks as have occurred have invariably been the subject of prompt investigation by all the appropriate procedures which are available for doing this sort of thing, particularly through the Australian Federal Police. The fact that such investigations have, for the most part, proved fruitless is no demonstration of managerial incapacity or system incapacity or breakdown so far as the Department is concerned.

Equally, so far as the question of departmental morale is concerned and link- age of this with, impliedly, management shortfalls and arguments about overseas terms and conditions, I think again there is no ground that springs out at one, if one has any knowledge of the Department, to suggest that a full-scale inquiry of the kind that here is contemplated is justified. The staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has really demonstrated over and over again a quite extraordinary commitment, particularly in the context of crises of various kinds that erupt from time to time, and in particular I record again the indebtedness we should all feel towards the Department for the role that it played during the Gulf war and the lead-up to it, not only in the policy end of matters back here but also, of course, in the consular administration that was involved, and also the extraordinary courage and dedication to duty that was shown by those who stayed at their posts throughout this particular period.

I think it is also worth saying briefly that, in terms of management generally, we are implementing a comprehensive management improvement program which does seek to improve productivity and morale through improving management and management skills at all levels. We have got in place a massive program of technological change to modernise the workplace. We have got in place a major program of formal educational, new opportunity and multi-skilling, which has opened up many opportunities for staff in the Department to advance themselves within the system, with in fact some 200 people in the Department now under- going tertiary study part time as a means of securing advancement and wider opportunities for themselves.

I could go on in much more detail about various matters that are the subject of this particular motion, but I think I have said enough to demonstrate that, really, if a reference of this kind is going to be made, it ought to be on firmer foundations than appear to be evident in this case. I said that the reference was not only unnecessary but regrettable, and I make that further point again for a couple of reasons. It is regrettable because any inquiry of this kind necessarily involves a major allocation and diversion of resources which simply, in the present environment, my Department can ill afford.

Like every other department in the system, with the budgetary pressures that have been on us for years on end-Senator Reid, as a representative of constituents in this Territory, will be well aware of this-resources are being stretched thinner and thinner. Nerves are getting more and more frayed in more and more departments around the Government because of that fact. People are willing to shoulder the burdens and responsibilities of getting on with the job and the business of government. In my Department, they are willing, as I have said, to shoulder and burden responsibilities of particular demanding situations that occur necessarily from time to time. But it is a matter of regret that they are asked to shoulder and burden additional responsibilities to prepare massive amounts of paperwork and defences of actions that have been taken in the past in order to satisfy exercises of the kind that will be set in train by this particular motion. They are willing obviously to do that in the context of Senate Estimates committee hearings. That is the normal forum and vehicle for this kind of inquiry. They are willing to do it, of course, in the context of Audit Office investigations and inquiries; that is again part of the system. But this kind of ad hoc add-on really is a quite unhelpful further addition to an already desperately overburdened work force that is doing its best to manage in difficult circumstances.

I say finally that it is regrettable because, by giving the opportunity, as this inquiry no doubt will, for the further airing of a whole variety of antagonisms towards the Department that are notori-ously held by at least some people, that will not do much to help the morale of a department which has been subject to quite a battering from assaults of this kind over the course of the last year. If the purported rationale for the motion is, among other things, concern about the morale of the Department, as appears to be the case from the drafting of the revised terms of reference, then I simply say finally that Senator Hill, by this particular bit of grandstanding, which the Australian Democrats have regrettably agreed to join, is not doing much to help just that.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats believe that if an inquiry into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is warranted, and we do accept that there is some evidence to support the Opposition's case, then inquiries into other Commonwealth departments are also just as warranted, and possibly more so. To that end, two of my colleagues moved this morning that the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Employment, Education and Training also be the subject of inquiries into managerial performance.

speech.para: The Department of Transport and Communications, for example, has distinguished itself by repeated failure to implement policy. The regional FM radio plan of 1987 has never been implemented. The Seven Network has been in breach of audience reach restrictions since April 1988 and was in breach of cross-media ownership rules for two years, and there are many other examples. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has been extensively criticised on student financial assistance, and that is just one area of considerable concern.

Nevertheless, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, while it has generally achieved a great deal with too few resources, has undergone significant upheavals and controversies in recent times, including industrial disputes, leaks and complaints about overseas conditions of service, and morale is said to be low, as it is in many departments. Some of these matters have, in our opinion, already been dealt with and, if that is true, then the Department will have an opportunity to demonstrate that publicly. If there are remaining problems, though, then this inquiry may be the catalyst for resolving them.

speech.speaker: Coates Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to speak briefly to this motion. I indicate that, when I have finished my remarks, I will seek leave to continue my remarks later and will then move that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for a later hour today. I am not suggesting that the decision be put off indefinitely; I just want to indicate that there was no consultation whatsoever with me as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration to which it is now proposed that this reference be given.

speech.para: There used to be a courtesy in this place that a check was made with the committee chair and members of the committee as to whether or not the workload of the committee was in such a state that it was appropriate to take such a reference. I believe that such discussion should take place for that question of workload but also for the appropriateness of referring such a matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

As the Democrats have indicated, they not only want to agree to Senator Hill's change of mind about which committee this should go to by sending a reference about the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, but also they want to give us a full-scale inquiry into two other departments, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

In each of these three cases, there is an appropriate committee of the Senate to deal with these matters, if it is decided that a committee should deal with them. We have previously passed a resolution of this Senate allocating departments amongst the eight standing committees. The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has three departments allocated to it-the Department of Finance, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Treasury. There is one department relevant to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training; that is, the department of the same name. There are two departments appropriate to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which would be the appropriate committee for any inquiry into the Department of Transport and Communications.

My point is that if there is to be such an inquiry-and I would support Senator Evans's argument against there being an inquiry at all-it ought to be undertaken by the appropriate committee. That committee ought to be developing relations with the department and the agencies relevant to the portfolio. We should not be loading Finance and Public Administration with an inquiry into potentially every department of the Government.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a tribute to your investigatory powers.

â€”Thank you, Senator: I can do without such tributes! I heard Senator Hill's argument that, because there was a question of management systems, staff performance and accountability among the proposed terms of reference, it was relevant to Finance and Public Administration. Certainly, Finance and Public Administration has taken a Service-wide interest in things such as the Senior Executive Service and one or two other issues, but it is a bit much to add this load onto us. Obviously it will not be just the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: three departments are being talked about. I assume that the Opposition, in exchange for the support of the Democrats on this measure, will support the other two when they come up tomorrow. It may not be too strong to say that it is an insult to the relevant committees to suggest that they are not the appropriate ones to deal with these matters. They are the ones who ought to be developing relations with departments and agencies in their portfolios. It is nonsense to add this inquiry to the committee that I happen to chair.

speech.para: My initial suggestion to defer the matter at least until later in the day was to allow the necessary consultations to take place. Such consultations did not take place, although they should have. There have been too many proposed references to committees lately without any such notification, let alone discussion. This has also happened with the reference of Bills to committees. As I indicated earlier, I think this matter should be dealt with later in the day. Therefore I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-The Australian Democrats have listened to what Senator Coates has said. We are very interested in his argument concerning the two motions, notice of which was given this morning by my colleagues, and assure him that his proposition is under serious consideration.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Student Assistance Amendment Bill is, in itself, not a particularly contentious Bill but one which reminds us of the major flaws that have appeared in the Government's administration of the Austudy scheme and its student support policies. The Bill deals with only some particular aspects of Austudy. It offers no overall review or reform of the scheme. Yet that is what Austudy is crying out for. It is what the Opposition has promised and has called for whenever we have discussed student assistance.

speech.para: The Bill does not address the major problems of Austudy. It does not address the maladministration of it under this Government and it does not address its failure to have clear objectives by which the Government, and indeed the Parliament, can measure the success or otherwise of the scheme. I refer to the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Student Financial Assistance. At page 21 of the report the Committee states:
It is unacceptable however that apart from a few isolated surveys no real attempt has been made by DEET to establish if the program is meeting its stated aims.
That was a conclusion reached by Government and Opposition members alike in the House of Representatives committee. On page 22 we read:

No real assessment of the effectiveness of Austudy or alternative means of student assistance can be determined without proper performance indicators. These do not exist. In the absence of detailed data the Committee has been asked to accept DEET's subjective assessments of the program's effectiveness. It is difficult to accept that the Parliament is required to allocate hundreds of millions of dollars each year-
in fact, over $1 billion this financial year-
to a program for which few objective measures of effectiveness are available.

That is the most recent two-party review of the scheme: it is inadequately administered by the present Government. This Bill does not do anything to redress these inadequacies or to address those matters that were referred to by that parliamentary committee of review. The words that I have quoted are quite an indictment. It is no wonder that the Committee then proceeded to recommend bluntly that `the Government develop clear policy objectives for student financial assistance'. That is what the Opposition has promised since before the last election. That is what is needed and that is not what is involved in the Bill.

I have stated the Opposition's, and indeed this Parliament's, central concern about Austudy. The Government has proceeded to run the scheme in a policy vacuum. It is no wonder that there are so many accounts of inefficient or inadequate administration, a widespread feeling in the student community that Austudy is not being targeted satisfactorily, and grounds for doubt that this substantial slab of taxpayers' money is being spent wisely. This Bill does nothing to assuage our fears and concerns about Austudy.

What this very limited Bill does do however is, on the whole, quite reasonable. It is of small compass. What it sets out to do is reasonable and the Opposition supports the particular small measures of improvement contained in it. I refer to the first. There is a new provision requiring the use of tax file numbers as a condition for receipt of Austudy and Abstudy. I say to honourable senators in the chamber that whenever the use of a tax file number is being extended the Opposition looks at that very carefully.

We have approached this question with due scepticism, concern and caution. Indeed, we will listen to what other senators have to say in this debate about the use of the tax file number. On the basis of our examination, I can say on behalf of the Opposition that, up to this point, we do not object to this extension of the tax file number to Austudy. So we do not oppose this proposal. We will remain alert to any intrusion by government on the privacy of individuals or to any undue bureaucratic extensions of tax into other areas of government administration.

The Bill proposes changes to the late payment of penalties. It also proposes changes to the time within which the Student Assistance Review Tribunal gives reasons for its decisions. The Opposition welcomes these positive changes. The Bill seeks to remove references in the Act to Australian postgraduate awards. This is sensible. It also provides for protection in respect of student Austudy files subpoenaed by courts and tribunals. This change is also supported by the Opposition. We are particularly concerned that details about students be handled with great accountability by education institutions and by the Government.

On a number of occasions over recent years I have alerted the Government to the loopholes in this area and to the discipline of the Department of Employment, Education and Training in particular in terms of the handling of student information. Fortunately, through Estimates committees and in other ways, the Government has responded to Opposition urgings on this matter. I believe that this area is now in a reasonably satisfactory state.

I particularly welcome clause 4 of the Bill, which is the Government's response to an earlier report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That Committee had expressed concern that ministerial determinations under the Act are not subject to parliamentary review. The Bill provides that those determinations will have to be tabled in Parliament and be subject to disallowance by Parliament. I welcome this move by the Government, as I always welcome increases in accountability by the Executive to the legislature. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has again shown the value of its examination of Bills. I commend the Committee.

I want to comment on something which was in the Bill that was dealt with in the other place but which is not in the Bill now. I refer to a reduction in government accountability to Parliament by abolishing the special annual report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act. The Government intended not to give a special report but to include such matters in the annual report. My colleague in the House of Representatives Dr Kemp, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, objected to this. The Government, very wisely, took this matter up right from the start and the status quo will remain. Had the Government not acted in this way, I am very confident that an amendment would have been moved in this chamber.

As I said, the Government had wanted to absorb the special report into the annual report of the Department and the Opposition's resistance to this has been effective. I might say, though, that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, rather grudgingly accepted the amendment that the Opposition moved in the other place. But accept it he did, and we are pleased about that.

The Opposition's approach to Austudy has been made clear on repeated occasions. We have deplored the present inefficiency and ineffectiveness of Austudy. There is no public confidence in Austudy. This scheme, which attracts $1 billion of government spending, is not sufficiently targeted. As I have said, the Government has not even determined what the criteria ought to be to judge the effectiveness of Austudy. The Government is not able to establish any professional accountability. It is not able to say whether targets are being met because there are no targets.

We have been calling for a thorough review of the rules of administration of the scheme to ensure that they are fair to all and that the scheme runs smoothly for all Australians. We do not wish to see anyone deprived of the opportunity to undertake education due to financial pressures. Australia needs a student assistance program that will effectively accomplish this.

The Government has quietly acknowledged the strength of our calls for a review of Austudy and its present weaknesses by arranging for consultants to carry out a review of student assistance. The Government seems to have been trying not to draw much attention to this recent decision to arrange a consultancy. Although tenders were called in April, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services made no public announcement about it until 30 May, just a few days ago. Why such reticence? Even the Minister had to concede in his press release:
. . . there are some issues to do with the targeting of Austudy that need to be looked at a bit more closely.

Well done, Minister! As I say, there has been a guarded, reticent, much after the event acknowledgment by the Minister that the Opposition is right. The Government is saying, `Yes, we too will join in'. It is trying to save the bacon by doing what the Opposition has been advocating for some years. In that recent statement, the Minister also said:
I am not saying that Austudy as it stands is ideal. We need to explore these issues more closely.
The consultants are due to report to the Government by the end of December and we will look forward to that report.

I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to give me an assurance at the end of the debate that that report, which is due at the end of September, be made public, or at least that it be made available to me, to Dr Kemp in the other place and to others with an interest in education and Austudy matters. This is not something that should be kept quiet and treated as a document for the Government's own use. It should not be subject to inaction. If this review is to be of any substance, the report should be made available to those in this Parliament who are interested. It should not be buried in the bureaucracy. The Government should allow it to be exposed to full public and parliamentary debate.

I want to refer to two matters that were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I have already commended the Committee for the report that it made on this Bill. First, an amendment has been proposed to clause 14. The proposed new subsection would enable the Minister, or a prescribed officer, to determine whether to waive the payment of a late payment charge or interest on overpaid amounts. The Committee believes that such decisions appear to be immune from review. The Minister, in his reply to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, said, in effect, that the non-reviewability in that section was a continuation of what was previously in the Act and that he did not desire a change. He did quote from his predecessor's letter to that Committee when the same matter was raised in December 1989. At that time, the Government promised to do a number of things to improve review processes. But we find now, 18 months later, that nothing has eventuated. The present Minister now writes rather plaintively:

I should perhaps add that the Government remains committed to introducing external appeals for the ABSTUDY scheme, although the details are still to be finalised. The Government has not introduced legislation relating to the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme as the Scheme is currently under review. Unfortunately, the Ministerial guidelines have not yet been prepared as my Department's debt processing procedures are still being established . . .
Three delays; three lame excuses. I conclude the quote:
I have directed that guidelines be finalised as a matter of priority.

Where are these things that are a matter of priority? I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to give some indication on those three points. I certainly hope that the Minister will now get a move on and see that these matters are attended to.

A second matter raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is the lack of easy readability of the Act. Yet it is an Act that brings benefits to thousands of Australians. It is one of those areas of legislation that are of very real importance to many individual students and their families and others involved in education. The Committee's report states:

The Committee notes by way of a general comment that the legislation of which this amendment is to form a part is almost impossible to follow. The Student Assistance Act 1973 was re-numbered and re-lettered (with effect from 2 January 1990) as a result of section 17 of the Student Assistance Amendment Act (No. 2) 1989. The Act has not been reprinted to take account of the re-numbering. Since the latest reprint of the Act was published in 1986, in order to find the relevant section referred to by this amending bill, it is necessary to take the 1986 reprint and manually-
with one's own pencil-
re-number it, taking into account the several other amendments that have been enacted to date . . . individuals have a right-
the Scrutiny of Bills Committee contends, I contend, and the Opposition contends-
. . . to understand-
and-

. . . to be able to work out what the law is . . . if the law is hard to understand (as it is here), it does nothing to assist the general public in knowing what the law is. The Committee, therefore, suggests that the reprinting of the Student Assistance Act 1973 be undertaken as a matter of urgency.

That completes the quote from this-again-all-party, Scrutiny of Bills parliamentary Committee. This was an important plea from the Committee and people who are affected by the legislation we pass should be able to make sense of it without undue difficulty. That is why I emphasise this matter.
The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has replied to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, acknowledging the validity of its concern. He said:
I have written to my colleague, the Attorney-General, to ask that a reprint be arranged as soon as possible after the present Bill is finalised.

Again, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary: is there a deadline for this, and is this in train? What assurance, further to the one which I have just quoted-and that is welcome-can be given in this debate? I certainly hope that the Government will act speedily to implement it, but I cannot help wondering whether the assurance would ever have been given if the Minister had not been prodded by the Senate.

Finally, I remind the Senate of a very important part of the Austudy debate: that is, the particular hardship suffered by families caught up in the rural crisis. On 13 May we had four or five hours of debate in this chamber on the particular effect of Austudy on the student members of families caught up with hardships in the rural crisis, particularly as it relates to the assets test-that is, we understand that there is an income test to get Austudy, but that if a family has about $700,000-worth of assets in addition to the family home, they are denied any access to Austudy benefits on the ground that they have a substantial asset. But, as we know, in the rural crisis incomes of many families are zero or negative and yet they may have a primary production asset that is greater than that-nearly three-quarters of a million dollars. The valuations administered with regard to Austudy are out of date and the value of properties has fallen off to below that cutoff point. In the meantime, the students are suffering.

To cut a long story short, I moved a motion on behalf of the Opposition in the Senate-with great commitment, and it was supported by not only Opposition senators but Democrat senators-and it went through on the voices. Even Government senators understood the rural crisis. On that day, 13 May-some six weeks ago-we passed the motion that I moved. It reads:
That the Senate calls on the Government to immediately-
immediately-

introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from Austudy by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

That motion has been on the books, adopted by this chamber, for six weeks. What have we heard from the Government? What immediate action have we seen from the Government? I do not think the Government would want to treat this chamber with contempt. I do not think the Government would want to have a series of tactical, procedural legislative difficulties in this chamber when it has not directly responded to a clear resolution of the Senate.

I refer to the kind of hardship provisions that I had in mind. I refer to my speech of 13 May, reported at page 3208 of Hansard. I shall not quote all of the words that appear there, but, on behalf of the Opposition, I suggested to the Government that administratively there be a change in the approach of the Valuer General to the valuation of rural properties, to make sure that they were up to date and not overvalued with expensive and time-consuming delays by appeal. That is one thing that can be done immediately. Another was to bring in hardship provisions parallel to those that have already been announced by this Government with regard to social security benefits.

I put it to the Government that these measures are to hand. The Opposition and the Democrats are not in the position of having all of the information available to government and have not the legislative or other administrative machinery to define exactly what will meet that general criteria. So there is a general area for the Government to act in. There are specific references that I set out six weeks ago, which appear on page 3208 of the Senate Hansard.

I did not move that motion merely to express an opinion; I moved it as a call to the Government to take action and to do so urgently. The word in the motion-as I emphasised when I read it just now-is `immediately'. So far the Government has made no response to that motion passed by the Senate. I regard that as a disgrace. If it is not remedied in the next couple of days, it will remain an insult and contempt to the Senate.

It is also an insult to the rural community, who are suffering so much. The financial pressures on rural Australia have not eased since 13 May; quite the contrary. Yet the Government has been unmoving so far and it offers no response. It has offered no hope of relief. It has offered no hardship provision for those families with members of the family enrolled in education courses-not just higher education courses, but in schools; Austudy reaches to secondary students.

In these circumstances, the Opposition again urges the Government to act and immediately to introduce hardship provisions so that those being hurt by the present operation of the assets test can be granted relief. I am not confident that the Government will act on the merit of the argument, even on these quite persuasive words, without some further pressure from the Senate. Therefore, after careful consideration, on behalf of the Opposition I propose that the Senate refuse to approve the Bill until the Government makes the response called for by the Senate motion of 13 May. Accordingly, I move this amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time:

Omit all words after ``That'', substitute ``consideration of the bill be deferred until the Government reports to the Senate on the action it proposes to take in response to the Senate's resolution of 13 May concerning hardship provisions for those affected by the assets test on Austudy''.

Of all the current problems that Austudy has, the effect of the assets test on rural families suffering hardship is the single most urgent problem. The Senate has decided that already and the Government should accept that decision. As soon as the Government gives its response, the Opposition will give its support to the passage of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. If the Government responds by Friday, it will be a matter of minutes, as the final stages of the Bill can be completed and the Bill can head for the statute book. The Opposition does not have any substantial amendment to the Bill, although it will listen to continuing debate on it in the Senate.

I conclude by making it quite clear to Senator McMullan, the Deputy Whip and the advisers on their left that we seek to defer consideration of the Bill until the Government responds. We do not want to give any particular test to the Government's response; we want a genuine and substantial response. We want the Government to come back to the Senate and report directly on the terms set out in the motion that the Opposition has moved and which the Senate has adopted. As soon as that is done, as soon as we get a substantial, genuine response, we will proceed and, of course, move to adopt the Bill. It is in the Government's hands to make that response and I urge that the response come later this week.

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I agree with Senator Teague, who said at the outset of his address that the Student Assistance Amendment Bill tackles Austudy and refines the administration of the scheme. He described, in the first instance, some six or seven amendments which were agreeable to the Opposition; in fact, the Australian Democrats also welcome those initial half a dozen amendments.

speech.para: We are not impressed at all with the extension of the tax file number and its usage in the way that the Bill proposes. We see a concentration on the bureaucracy of the scheme to the blissful disregard of the sorts of criticisms that are being made by students and also criticisms that have been made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which recently reviewed student financial assistance. It seems that many of those criticisms are totally disregarded in favour of a concentration on the bureaucratic nature of student assistance.

We have before us the latest proposal regarding the extended use of the so-called tax file number. There is no doubt that the tax file number scheme, with its slow and methodical extension, has become a de facto Australia Card. This small Bill-it is, in fact, an omnibus Bill-hides within it yet another extension and invasion of privacy. The Bills Digest for this legislation dated 14 March 1991 states:

The requirement to produce a tax file number has been compared by a number of commentators to an `Australia Card by stealth'. The Australia Card proposal would have effected many of the areas that the tax file number now has been extended to . . .

According to some commentators, including Dr Roger Clarke from the Australian National University who makes the point at page 17 of his September 1990 report, The Expansionary History of the Enhanced Tax File Number Scheme, the tax file number system has been arguably extended to undertake even more than the original Australia Card tasks.

The Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, has stated that the use of the term `tax file number' is now a misnomer. The Commissioner has stated that the extension of the tax file number raised `significant privacy concerns' while its use to increase data matching has `infringed basic privacy principles'. He made those comments as long ago as 23 August and 24 August 1990 and they were reported in the Age newspaper.

In the current Bill, the requirement to produce a tax file number is contained in proposed new section 44a-that is, clause 17-which would be inserted in the principal Act. Clause 17 would require students to provide their tax file number as a precondition for payment of student income support. The tax file number of a student's parents and the tax file number of a student's spouse, if relevant, would also be required where their incomes or assets were taken into account when calculating payment. The fact is that in the vast majority of cases the income of the parents and spouse are taken into account.

Clause 22, which amends the regulation-making power under the Act, should also be noted. In the reviewed version of the Bill, clause 22 has been amended to broaden the power of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to require information, including the tax file numbers of students and other persons. It is at least pleasing to see that the Government amendment, which embraces the tax file number, acknowledges the concern expressed by the Privacy Commissioner about the Department's authority in this area. Nevertheless, the Australian Democrats will oppose clause 17 of the amending Bill.

While the coalition has supported the Government's extended use of tax file numbers, the Democrats will continue to voice their concerns and objections about this de facto Australia Card. According to the December 1990 report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled The Proposed Tax File Number Provisions and Data Matching Program, provisions extending the use of the tax file number `should only proceed for the most compelling of reasons'.

Even the Privacy Commissioner, in his October 1990 report entitled Data-Matching in Commonwealth Administration: Discussion Paper and Draft Guidelines, recommended `the provision of a clear statement of the justification, costs, benefits and safeguards for programs' to help protect privacy. We do not see that here; we do not see a clear statement of the justification of costs, benefits and safeguards.

In relation to clause 17, there is clearly a lack of evidence and argument to support the requirement for provision of not only the student's tax file number, but also that of his or her parents and partner. That provision would actually require many students to apply for a tax file number which they had not had before and that raises even greater concerns about the Government's intentions here. The Australian people are entitled to a clear and compelling case for any proposed extension of the tax file number system.

The use of the tax file number is increasing incrementally and significantly, in many cases in a way which is subverting the way we carry on our daily affairs. It is true that, in purely practical terms, the increasing use of the tax file number perversely supports its continued expansion. Given that the system is already in place, it is difficult to deny the cost savings that will be brought about by its extension rather than the use of some other method. It is becoming all too easy. Because it exists and because the system works, it is easier to extend it than to think up a more equitable way of ensuring that departments operate efficiently or that they disburse their funds efficiently. It is being extended because it is just so easy to extend it.

In facilitating links across different areas, there is increased transgression of privacy and greater potential for abuse. The Democrats believe that it is necessary to stop the proliferation of people who can use tax file numbers and gain access to them. The Australian community has many valid concerns about the dangers of a national identification system, including the increasing scope for misuse of personal information. The community has also witnessed the Government's broken promises; the use of this tax file number is yet another one to add to the litany of broken promises.

In September 1987, the Federal Government withdrew its Australia Card proposal in the face of overwhelming public disapproval. Instead of introducing the national identification system, the Government announced its intention to enhance the tax file number scheme. At that time, the Australian public was assured that this was not a multi-purpose register. Explicitly and repeatedly we were told that the tax file number would be used exclusively by the Australian Taxation Office for taxation purposes only.

According to Dr Clarke, a reader in information systems in the Australian National University's Department of Commerce, whom I have already quoted, the assurances and protections provided by the Government in 1998 have proved `worthless'. I agree with him. In his recent paper, Dr Clarke evaluates the Government's early assurances regarding the limited nature of the tax file number scheme. I seek leave to incorporate that section of his report which includes relevant quotations and responses, namely Exhibit 6 on pages 16 to 18 of the report.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Bell seeks leave to incorporate some material. Is leave granted?
â€”I would like to see what he seeks to incorporate before granting leave.
â€”We will delay the granting of leave until the end of Senator Bell's speech.

â€”In that material Dr Clarke states that the initial scope of the enhanced tax file number was wider than had been commonly understood, while additional uses had accumulated through `function creep', as he describes it. The tax file number scheme, instead of applying exclusively to taxation, now applies to any statute administratively moved under the Australian Taxation Office's control and any purposes deemed-we like that word deemed; it is appearing in a lot of places these days-by statute to be taxation law.

speech.para: The main areas to which the scheme has been widened so far include the administration of virtually every benefit and pension paid by any Commonwealth Government agency, such as unemployment and sickness benefits, the sole parent's pension, family allowance, and family allowance supplement-it is continuing. It also applies to the location of defaulters and the matching of personal data from all major client-oriented agencies.

The requirement to furnish a tax file number has also been extended to new programs including the training guarantees scheme and the higher education contribution scheme where tertiary fees are paid through the tax system. Students who cannot afford to pay up front are also penalised by having to pay 15 per cent more. It should also be noted that several data matching programs are already conducted in the Department of Employment, Education and Training as well as by other departments.
In Alert Digest No. 5, 26 March 1991, the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills raises serious concerns about clause 17. The Committee states:
. . . while such provisions may be seen as necessary to prevent persons defrauding the student assistance system, they may also be considered as unduly intrusive upon a person's privacy.
Accordingly, the Scrutiny Committee states that clause 17:
. . . may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, in breach of principle 1(a)(i) of the Committee's terms of reference.

These and other problems raised by the Scrutiny Committee have not been answered or properly addressed by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin. In its eighth report of 29 May 1991, the Scrutiny Committee reproduces and discusses the Minister's response to these and other concerns.
In relation to clause 17 and the privacy issues involved, the Minister raises two points. First, he states:
We have been careful to ensure that the legislation does not go beyond the periodic checks to prevent abuses of the assistance and taxation systems.

On that point, I ask all honourable senators to consider what difference it makes whether one's privacy is abused periodically, regularly or occasionally. If it has been abused, it has been abused. This response by the Minister that the checks would be periodic is simply no help at all.

Secondly, the Minister responds by actually misrepresenting the position taken by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Minister states that the majority of the members of that Committee in its December 1990 report entitled Proposed tax file number provisions and data-matching program `concluded that use of the tax file numbers in the data-matching is appropriate'. The reference given is paragraph 21 on page 9 of that report. But that paragraph states:

The Committee is aware of much debate concerning the proposed extension of use of the tax file number and feels that any extensions should only proceed for the most compelling of reasons. The Committee is not insensitive to privacy concerns but the majority view is that the present circumstances are such as to warrant the tax file number's use.
I suggest that the Minister's interpretation was vastly different and that he quoted selectively to suit his needs.

As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee observes, this paragraph clearly states that any extensions of the tax file number should proceed only for the most compelling of reasons. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee's eighth report also states:

Further, the Committee notes that the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee stated that the majority view was that the use of the tax file number was warranted in `the present circumstances', that is, in the circumstances that applied in respect of the Bill that the Committee was then considering.
The Committee did not say that extension of its use was warranted in the circumstances of this legislation.

The report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs also comments on the fact that the Privacy Commissioner would not discuss the merits of the proposed legislation as it affects our privacy. On page 8 the report states:
. . . some members of the Committee felt that the statutory provisions which govern the office of Privacy Commissioner unduly limited his independence.

It is most regrettable that there should be these statutory limitations on the role and advice that the Privacy Commissioner can give. These provisions appear mainly in Part IV of the 1988 Privacy Act.

Other problems which were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have also remained unanswered. For instance, the Committee notes that, in relation to overpayment, there is no provision for review of decisions about whether or not to waiver the payment of a late payment charge or interest. The Minister's reply does not rectify this problem.

The Minister's answer here is familiar, and I am sure that Senator Baume has also heard this one before as he seems to have heard some of the other answers. The answer is that guidelines relating to recovery of overpayments will be introduced. It appears that we must rely on appropriate guidelines. Yet these could easily be framed in favour of not waiving debts, while the matter of review remains a problem.

The Scrutiny Committee also notes that the legislation of which this amendment is to form a part is almost impossible to follow and should be reprinted as a matter of urgency. The Student Assistance Act 1973 was re-numbered and re-lettered by a Bill passed at the end of 1989, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No.2) 1989. The Committee observed:

Since the last reprint of the Act was published in 1986, in order to find the relevant section referred to by this amending Bill, it is necessary to take the 1986 reprint and manually re-number it, taking into account the several other amendments that have been enacted to date.

Unless one maintains a personal set of cut and paste Acts, the only people who know what is going on with the current proposals are the bureaucrats in the Department. This is totally unacceptable. It is obviously a self-serving arrangement to remove from the public area the knowledge of how to get around this business. The Minister's response here is that reprinting will be arranged after this Bill is finalised. That does not help.
In a letter to the Department dated 13 May 1991, the Privacy Commissioner, Mr O'Connor, writes:

It is regrettable that the information handling provisions are to be included in the Regulations rather than in the Act, although I accept that there is now no alternative given the limited time available.
This comment is really quite disturbing. Of course, the Government's haste in pushing through this amendment is no excuse for failure to make crucial legislative provision.

In his letter to the Department, the Commissioner also welcomes the undertaking to enable direct quotation by parents and spouses. He states that it is important for pamphlets and forms to clearly present this option. This is another example of the sort of thing which is necessary to make sure that people actually know what has been involved when they first tangle with the bureaucracy associated with these sorts of assistance areas.

The Commissioner also suggests that the exemption categories should be extended to give discretion to exempt students from obtaining a parent's or spouse's tax file number in unforeseen and exceptional circumstances. We expect to see legislation cover all situations and contingencies but, of course, we see it not often enough. Here it is taken up as a suggestion by the Commissioner.

Furthermore, the Commissioner believes that all clients, not just Abstudy clients, should be able to receive assistance pending the issue of a tax file number. The assumption here is that there is only a certain category of students which do not already have a tax file number and may have to apply for and receive a tax file number. Therefore, only a certain category of students will need assistance in the interim. That is a false assumption. I agree with the Commissioner that the possibility should be there for all clients to receive some sort of assistance in that pending period which can be an extensive period of time.

We are after an increase in flexibility, that is, the flexibility to be able to meet the unforeseen circumstances which the bureaucrats cannot imagine and which exist in the real world. We want to see in legislation, through flexibility, the capacity to meet those situations. That is the sort of thing which will reduce the likelihood of hardship. That is the sort of thing that eventually requires the very sort of amendment which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are so keen on seeing happen. Flexibility in the legislation reduces the need for other hardship provisions.
I continue to quote Mr O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, because it just adds a little strength to that point:
Moreover, if a client has applied for a tax file number direct to the ATO, rather than through DEET, this should be sufficient, as it is in the case of DSS and DVA benefits.
As a minimum it should be within the Department's power to commence assistance without quotation of a tax file number in extenuating circumstances.
That is the case with these other departments. Why should it be any different with DEET? Mr O'Connor continues:
A client may suffer considerable financial strain, for example, if the application for a tax file number was lost by the ATO and the client was without financial assistance for an extended period.

I suggest that that situation could quite easily occur. Apart from the tax file number, the other main area in this Bill which gives cause for concern is the restructuring of the late payment charge and interest in relation to overpayment of a benefit-clauses 13 to 16. At present, a person who is notified of a debt but does not repay it within three months is liable for a late payment charge of $15 plus 10 per cent of the outstanding amount, up to a maximum of $515. Interest also accrues from the end of that period.

Under clause 13, which amends section 40 of the principal Act, three months after the notification of the debt the debtor would be liable to a flat charge of $100, while the interest would accrue from the date of notice, not three months on. The interest provision represents an unambiguous worsening of the position of student assistance debtors. This fits with the declared intention to spur quicker repayments. There must be efficiency of those repayments. That seems to drive the desires of this Department.

The late fee changes represent a worsening of the position of those debtors who owe less than $850. They are being harassed, harangued and hurried and it is a much worse situation. This suggests that most overpayments are of relatively small amounts. Otherwise why would there be this fascination with this section in the legislation? If it were not the case that most were small amounts, it would not be worth even drafting this legislation.

According to the small amount of research that has been undertaken and been available to me, only a tiny proportion of overpayments are due to deliberate fraud. The sorts of things that result in overpayment are the inability of people to estimate their spouses' projected income for the next year or the fact that they, or somebody else, have worked a little more overtime and were unable to estimate it at the time of application. These are the sorts of the things which are humanly impossible to estimate. Sometimes they result in an overpayment of $400 or $500, which is impossible to keep track of during the year. It may only be a few dollars each week, but at the end of the period to be asked to pay for that in toto is an imposition which causes a great deal of hardship to a number of small debtors.

The Democrats believe that there should be some differentiation between overpayment due to the departmental error, applicant error and cases of deliberate fraud. It should not be beyond the talents of those who devised this to actually differentiate between these things, but that seems not to be the case.

For instance, under clause 14, which amends section 41, the Minister or a prescribed officer may determine that interest or a late payment charge is not payable. It is suggested that the exercise of discretion to waiver or write off the late payment charge and interest should be limited, with more grace perhaps where the Department has made a mistake. As noted by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and referred to earlier, there is currently no provision for the review of these decisions.

This Bill contains various other proposals, including deletion of references to competitive postgraduate awards; provision that written decisions of the Student Assistance Review Tribunal are available within 10 working days; and provision that ministerial determinations under the Act be tabled and subject to disallowance.

The Democrats also support the Privacy Commissioner's advice in his recommended guidelines regarding the expansionary use of tax file numbers that data-matching programs should be subject to annual report by the Privacy Commissioner. The current Bill does not address the many problems and inequities of the Austudy scheme, as was made clear in the speech of the previous speaker from the coalition, Senator Teague. This Bill could have redressed a number of problems but it is concentrating on things which were not really a highlight of the review conducted by the committee from the House of Representatives. If we are going to review Austudy, we would prefer that greater priority be given to a number of other things.

Last month, the coalition and the Government declined the opportunity to modify regulations which govern Austudy and which represent the worst anomalies and inequities under the Austudy scheme. Concern was expressed by Senator Teague and others during this debate. There was concern with the assets test. There was the opportunity a few weeks ago to redress that by accepting the Democrats position to remove that regulation in its entirety. Those changes would drastically have improved the scheme, but that opportunity has passed us by. We may have missed that chance, but we will continue to follow whichever means are available to us to attempt to improve this scheme, and its administration, for the benefit of the students that are supposed to be benefiting from it now but are not.

This scheme has attracted widespread criticism and is currently the subject of a government appointed consultancy report. By definition, it is inadequate and must be addressed more widely than in this Bill. Many people who cannot afford to pay for their studies have been denied support and excluded from education because of the unfair operation of both the income and the assets tests. Rural students, in particular, as was mentioned by Senator Teague, are penalised because of their parents' assets, despite the fact that they are income-poor. We have had that opportunity and we have disregarded it.

The Democrats will continue to take any opportunity to redress that situation. We are most entertained by the proposition put forward by the coalition; we will carefully consider it. If that is a way of redressing the problems with Austudy, then that may be the only way we can proceed. It may be the way that will force some sort of action on this.

interject.speaker: Senator Bolkus

talk.start.para: â€”I have looked at the document that Senator Bell was attempting to incorporate. I have no objection to its being incorporated.

interject.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Exhibit 6: Evaluation of the Assurances
Regarding the TFN Scheme's Limited Nature
Press Release by the Treasurer, No.47 of 25 May 1988
* ``[The Tax File Number] will not establish a citizen identification system''
The extended TFN scheme of August 1990 applies the Number to every person who is a client of any of the major agencies, and is therefore a general-purpose citizen identification system.
* ``The Tax Office will be the only government agency which uses the tax file number for the purposes of identifying and registering its client base''
In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, use of the TFN is made by every major government agency for identifying its client base.
* ``The tax file numbering system will be administered exclusively by the Tax Office for tax purposes''
In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, the only function which is restricted to the ATO is the allocation of the number, and this largely for reasons of administrative convenience.
* ``The circumstances in which third parties will be required under these proposals to seek a person's tax file number will be limited to those being announced today''
A succession of additional circumstances have been added following the original announcement, none of which were contemplated by the original statement of scope.
* ``The advice to taxpayers of their tax file number is not to be used as a method of identifying that person''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, the TFN is explicitly to be used as a means of identification of individuals, not only in their roles as taxpayers, but also as benefits recipients, tertiary students, in-service trainees and child and spouse maintenance payers.
* ``There will be no offence for people failing to quote a tax file number when asked of them''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, there are as yet no offence provisions, but the economic sanctions have been extended from a withholding tax at the marginal rate to disqualification from benefits.
* ``Exchanges of information between the Tax Office and other agencies will continue to be limited to those authorised under the very strict secrecy provisions of the tax law''
In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, these provisions have been very significantly extended beyond those that prevailed when the statement was originally made.
* ``The new measures are designed solely to help reduce tax evasion''

Whether or not they were designed for that purpose alone, in the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, they are also used to address benefit fraud, locate defaulting maintenance payers, and any other uses not strictly precluded by the terms of the various statutes.
* ``The requirement for taxpayers . . . to quote their file number will be limited to the following areas:
* The reporting of income paid by employers . . .;

* The reporting of Government benefits or pensions which constitute salary or wages for taxation purposes-the quotation arrangements will not apply to pensions or benefits where it is presently the practice not to require that tax instalments be deducted, e.g. age and service pensions. Nor will it apply to exempt pensions, e.g. invalid pensions . . .;
* . . . the reporting of interest income paid by financial institutions . . .;
* the reporting of dividend income . . .;
the reporting of unit trust distribution entitlements . . .''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, a large number of additional requirements have been added, relating to `exempt pensions', every other benefit paid by the four major client-oriented agencies, superannuation and the payment of child and spouse maintenance.

* It must be stressed that the employment quoting arrangements will not apply to assessable pensions where it is presently the practice not to require that tax instalments be deducted, e.g. age and service pensions. Nor will they apply to exempt pensions, including invalid pensions.''
In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, it applies to all pensions, including assessable and exempt pensions.
The Treasurer's Answer to a Question in the House from the Leader of the Opposition, 3 June 1988
* We have no intention now or in the future of extending the basis of the tax file number to do anything like some of the Australia Card tasks''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, the scheme does not yet apply (directly) to the Health Insurance Commission or the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, but does apply to the Department of Social Security, and to a number of additional agencies (Veteran's Affairs; Employment, Education &Training; and Community Services &Health). It has therefore been arguably extended to rather more than the Australia Card tasks.
The Treasurer's Second Reading Speech to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, 1 September 1988

* No other government or non-government agency will have access to the Tax Office file number registration system, nor will it be able to use an individual's TFN for any registration system of its own''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, the registration scheme itself (which is only a number-allocation mechanism) is restricted to the ATO, but the TFN is widely used by many agencies as a partial (although perhaps not yet exclusive) person-identifier.
Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, `Report on Feasibility of a National ID Scheme: The Tax File Number' October 1988

* ``10.26. The Committee recommends that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, if enacted, be strictly limited in its terms, so that it applies only in relation to taxation purposes and those purposes be so framed as to prevent a progressive extension of the ambit of the Bill''

The extended TFN scheme of August 1990 applies to far more than just taxation purposes, and those purposes have proven to have been framed in such a way that the ambit of the original Bill has been readily extensible, both by administration and legislative means.
The Treasurer's Speech Amendments to be Moved.
Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, December 1988
* ``The amendments the Government has agreed to accept are designed to guarantee that the tax file numbering scheme is completely voluntary''

The extended TFN scheme of August 1990 is voluntary, but the cost of staying outside it is no longer merely the payment in advance of top marginal rates of taxation; it is also the complete exclusion from all forms of government benefits.
Privacy Act 1988, Schedule 2-Tax File Number Guidelines
* ``1.1 The tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means''
The extended TFN scheme of August 1990 is used by so many agencies already that it is reasonably described as a national identification system.
* ``1.2 Tax file number recipients . . . shall not act in an unauthorised manner to use TFN information as a means of matching personal information about a person''

4.3(c) Government agencies, including the Commissioner of Taxation, shall not directly or indirectly disclose tax file number information or use tax file number information to cross-match information about a person, except in authorised circumstances . . .''

In the extended TFN scheme of August 1990, DSS is Authorised to undertake data matching, and in order to do so, to demand large quantities of personal data from any organisation. Organisations which were precluded from supplying data have been relieved of the constraint.

speech.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”I will respond very briefly, without going into much rhetoric, to the arguments that have been put. Senator Teague asked whether the consultant's report would be made available to him and other members of Parliament. Essentially, as Senator Teague knows, this is very much a matter for the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin. It is not possible for me to give a definite response at this stage. That is as much as I can say at the moment. Obviously Senator Teague's interest in this report will be conveyed to Mr Baldwin. I hope that he takes that into account when making an assessment as to whether to make it public or not.

speech.para: Senator Teague also asked how long it would be before a reprint of the Student Assistant Act is ready. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that a reprint should be available in about six to eight weeks after the Student Assistance Amendment Bill receives royal assent.

There is also some question as to the status of guidelines on late payment charges. I am informed that ministerial guidelines on the administration of the late payment charge and interest charge will be considered by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) some time in the next few weeks, but hopefully some time later this week.

The major point that was raised by Senator Hill goes to the tax file number and in that respect he quoted correspondence from the Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor, and correspondence to the Department on this Bill. The Government respects the views of the Privacy Commissioner and takes them into account. To that extent, there has been a consultative process with him on this particular piece of legislation.

The Government considers that there is a need to apply the tax file number here. That need was expressed some months ago in the second reading debate on the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Bill 1990. It was probably towards the end of last year that we made it clear that, as a Government, we would move to apply the tax file number to these payments that are the subject of this legislation. The essential reason behind that is that, because of the application of the tax file number in this area, savings arising from student assistance participation in data-matching will be in the vicinity of $7m a year. That was the prime consideration of the Government in applying the tax file number in this particular area.

We are concerned that there would be increased debt if payments were made before clients submitted their tax file numbers. As a consequence, the range of exceptions to prepayment before registration of the tax file number is limited in the Bill before the Parliament. The exception of course has been included for Ab-study students because of the special needs of this group. This aspect of the scheme will be kept under review. As Senator Bell rightly said, the Privacy Commissioner does have a particular concern about making such an option available to other clients and the need for some flexibility.

Consultations have been undertaken with the Privacy Commissioner. As the Senate should know, as part of those consultations the Bill does provide that regulations may specify additional classes of exemptions. Pursuant to those provisions in the legislation, it is proposed that regulations be made to cover the following categories: parents or spouses who are temporarily overseas, as well as the ones who are permanently overseas, as is specifically provided in the legislation; parents or spouses estranged from the student; parents or spouses who have died; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who live in remote localities; and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who are required to attend traditional ceremonies.

I am told, and in fact the correspondence has indicated, that the Privacy Commissioner does endorse this level of exemption, although it can be acknowledged that he does want more. As I have said, the Government's response is that we feel that the financial return is something that should not be jeopardised.

I will refer to a couple of points that Senator Teague raised in pursuing his amendment during the second reading debate to defer consideration of this legislation. I can give two assurances to Senator Teague. I anticipate that he would be satisfied by them. In turn, given the role that Senator Bell has taken these days of supporting the Opposition as often as he can, I anticipate that he may also feel inclined to review his position on this matter.

talk.start.para: â€”Maybe he is dealing with things on their merits.

â€”He is dealing with Senator Faulkner. In terms of the hardship provisions that Senator Teague raised, in response to the motion that was passed in the Senate on 13 May calling on the Government to develop hardship provisions, I can say that a proposal has been developed to provide Austudy to all students whose parents or spouse are in receipt of a Department of Social Security (DSS) pension or benefit or the relocation adjustment scheme provided under part C of that scheme. A proposal has been developed and, if circumstances permit, the proposal may be progressed either before or during the Budget session. We are taking this particular proposal seriously and work has already been done on it with a view to having something apply as soon as is practicable.

speech.para: Senator Teague also raised, in response to the motivation for his deferral motion, the question of the valuation of assets. Valuations will be undertaken from 1 January 1992 and can be reviewed at any date on the basis of a request by students. I can give an assurance that valuations will be up to date. Payment of allowances will be backdated if it is found that asset values have fallen. Guidelines to this effect are currently being prepared and will be circulated and made publicly available. On these two points I hope I have satisfied Senator Teague's interest and his motivation for moving a deferral motion. I do not think I should say much more at this stage.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I welcome the three specific answers that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gave to my three specific questions in the body of my speech. I also welcome the two broad but quite detailed assurances that the Minister has given in response to my calling for assurances on two aspects of the motion that the Senate adopted on 13 May.

speech.para: First, I welcome the assurance that valuation, as it applies to the assets test, will be in up to date values and that the assets test will not deny, from a point during the year, the availability of Austudy when a valuation has changed to allow that to happen. Secondly, I note the Minister's reference to hardship provisions directly in response to the Senate resolution of 13 May. Where parents or spouses are receiving the Department of Social Security benefit under the hardship provisions that have been brought in under that Act, and under parallel hardship provisions in regard to other areas, such persons, and their dependants, will be able to gain Austudy provisions.

I query whether that is lawful given the state of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. I do not deny that the Government can give that assurance now. It is the assurance that I have been asking for. In the light of that, I regard this as a significant day for the Senate in its role in debating legislation in that the Opposition did bring some pressure upon the Government to come up with those assurances before this Bill could proceed.

I thank the Minister and I thank the Government for giving me, with sufficient substance, the assurances that the Opposition seeks. As a result of the debate today and the earlier debate six weeks ago in the Senate, I believe that rural families who otherwise would not have been assisted will be directly assisted by Austudy. We will be able to monitor that during the Budget session. I wish every speed to the measures that the Government has announced.
