speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats oppose clause 17 of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. An amendment has been circulated in my name. The Australian Democrats and the Australian community reject the continued extension of the tax file number system. The Government has broken repeated assurances about the use of the tax file number and its extension. Australian citizens are rightfully angry and disturbed about the growing demands in public and private sectors for the disclosure of personal information.

speech.para: In 1988 the Government guaranteed that the tax file numbering system was completely voluntary. However, the cost of staying outside it is no longer just a payment in advance at top marginal rates of taxation. As I noted in the second reading debate when I quoted Dr Clarke, the cost to those who attempt to stay outside the provision of tax file numbers is also the complete exclusion from all forms of Government benefits.

Many valid concerns about the dangers of this system also applied to the previous proposal for an Australia Card. These concerns include the serious erosion of privacy and the increasing scope for misuse of personal information, including action taken on the basis of inaccurate material or incorrect analysis. The Australia Card proposal was opposed by the Australian Democrats. We will be continuing to strenuously oppose and reject the imposition of a national identification system under another name. We see the insidious creep which is facilitated by clause 17 and for that reason we oppose it.

talk.start.para: â€”For all the reasons I mentioned in my summary to the second reading, the Government will proceed with clause 17. We are not swayed by Senator Bell's arguments.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition has given careful consideration to Senator Bell's speech on this matter in the second reading debate and to his remarks made during the committee stage, but it will support the Government in this matter. I make it quite clear that, as I said in my second reading speech, the Opposition will continue to look most carefully and cautiously at any use of the tax file number beyond its immediate use in the Australian Taxation Office. Although Australian citizens are not compulsorily required to register their tax file number with their bank accounts by the end of this month, if they do not do so the Tax Office will be able to deduct tax at the top income tax rate. It will be sorted out eventually in the tax return of any individual. So a great majority of Australians, wherever they have moneys deposited, will be giving their tax file number to banks all over the country in these weeks.

speech.para: Secondly, with regard to social security benefits, unemployment benefits, there are requirements for the giving of tax file numbers. The position is similar with regard to student benefits. However, a person's tax file number is still a private matter that is not to be disclosed in an unauthorised way. Because taxpayers' money to the tune of $1 billion is concerned, the Opposition sees that this is an appropriate use of the tax file number consistent with its other uses.
Clause agreed to.

talk.start.para: â€”One of the justifications for those amendments was that apparently the Government will save some money. Will that money simply return to Consolidated Revenue or will it be tagged for an increase in the Austudy allowance, which is patently insufficient at the moment? Is there any possibility of this saved money being extended to the present recipients of Austudy?

â€”The answer is not all that simple. The $7m anticipated will be a saving on outlays and as such will appear in the Budget documents in that way. How it is then dispersed and where it goes is very much up to the Government to decide. As I say, it will be registered as a saving on outlays.

â€”I find that a less than illuminating answer, but it seems that the illumination is not available for the Minister to provide to us anyway. As I recall from an answer to a previous question I asked of the Minister that we are talking about a scheme which pays out something of the order of $820m and costs something of the order of $30m to administer. Is the saving of $7m in outlays a saving in payments made to some people or a saving in administration costs? If that is a $7m saving in administration costs, it would then seem to me to be most appropriately directed to payments to students.

â€”What we are talking about here is a saving on outlays, a saving on payments that would otherwise be made, but will not be made because of the better capacity to match data by the use of the tax file number and, accordingly, reduce the level of either fraud or overpayment.

â€”I thank the Minister for at least clarifying that matter. Will step-parents also be required to furnish their tax file numbers, regardless of whether or not they contribute to a student's expenses? I remind the Minister that under changes in last year's Budget, if a step-parent lives in the same house, he or she is assumed to contribute to the student's upkeep, despite the fact that there is no legal obligation to do so. We could replace the word `assumed' with the word `deemed'. It is another of those bureaucratic demptions, if you like. But whether or not step-parents contribute to students' expenses, will they be required to furnish their tax file numbers?
â€”Yes, in the circumstances where they are contributing or deemed to be contributing to the students' upkeep.

â€”The final question is in relation to the issue of overpayments and the exercise of discretion to waive or write off the late payment charge in interest. Will any distinction be drawn between overpayment due to departmental error, applicant error or cases of deliberate fraud?

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to conclude the Opposition's assessment of this debate and to say that not only was a small improvement in the several measures of this legislation achieved in this hour and a half in the chamber today, but more significantly-and all rural families suffering difficulties in the rural crisis would be very interested in this matter-we have assurances from the Government that the Government is responding to the Senate resolution of 13 May that Austudy be able to be provided to students of families suffering in the rural crisis in the ways that have been defined in this debate. speech.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: â€”The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, which has just been called on for debate, makes some very extensive amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and some amendments to the Remuneration Tribunals Act.

speech.para: The Opposition is not opposed to the proposed amendments to either Act. However, we have some amendments in relation to both pieces of legislation to be amended by the Bill before us. I do not, in fact, propose to say very much about either of the Acts that are being amended. The Bill before us seeks to amend quite extensively the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. That is the Act which introduced what is known as Comcare which was brought into operation in 1988.

Most of the amendments proposed by the Government are designed to remove some restrictive and inflexible provisions to make Comcare work more effectively. The Opposition has no criticism to offer of any of these amendments which, as I said, are designed to make Comcare, in light of the experience of the last few years, a better operation.

The Opposition's amendments relate only to the question of discrimination on age grounds; namely the provisions which refer to people being unable to serve on the Commission once they reach the age of 65. Also, there is a definition of employee that is restricted to those people who have not reached the age of 65; that is, no doubt, as a result of similar restrictions on Commonwealth employment which we think should be removed. The amendments that we will seek to move are on a very important matter, but are not detailed.

This legislation proposes amendments to the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973. The Government in this legislation has proposed quite a significant change in the eligibility for membership of the Tribunal in relation to a group of people who would obviously have conflicts of interest if they were able to serve on the Tribunal immediately. Those are officers of the Public Service, holders of public offices, holders of judicial office and members of the Parliament.

The existing provision of the Remuneration Tribunals Act prohibits the appointment of anybody who has served in any of those offices during the immediately preceding period of seven years. The Remuneration Tribunal's jurisdiction extends to the determination of salaries for these people, although its powers now, in relation to members of parliament, have been somewhat restricted as a result of legislation passed about a year ago. Nevertheless, the Tribunal's jurisdiction does give extensive powers in relation to various aspects of the remuneration of members of parliament other than salary.

Judges and members of parliament receive pensions which are related to their salaries. The holders of public office or those in public service may well have attitudes of mind which still prevail after they have ceased to serve.

There seems to be good sense in the provisions which put a substantial space of time, namely seven years, between the service of these officers and their subsequent appointment to a position which determines such important conditions of service. As I said, in the case of judges, there is also a direct relationship between the salary received by those holding the office and the pension received by those who have retired. That is not as direct a relationship as it used to be in relation to members of parliament as the jurisdiction of the Tribunal has now been restricted, at least for the time being.

The Opposition has some concerns about the Government's proposal to reduce the period of seven years to one year. The reason the Government has given for this decision is that it is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain people with the necessary qualifications to serve on the Tribunal in the light of this particular restriction. As one can see, that is clearly a practical problem.

We are proposing a compromise; that is, we amend the legislation to remove that restriction from seven years to the one year, which is the Government's proposal for holders of public office or judges, but not for members of parliament. Whether we like it or not, there is clearly a sensitivity in relation to parliamentary salaries which does not apply to salaries and pensions for public servants or other holders of public office, and it certainly does not seem to be the case in relation to judges.

We believe that it would be very unwise to permit the appointment to the Tribunal of people who have served as members of parliament after a period of only 12 months. I think that it is reasonable to leave that barrier in place; namely, a period of seven years. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill, but we will be moving amendments in accordance with the matters that I have referred to.

speech.speaker: McLean Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to indicate our essential support for this legislation and our reaction to the amendments that will be proposed by the Opposition. Of course, all Australians have many common hopes and expectations and we rely upon governments to assist us in achieving them. Probably three of the most commonly shared expectations are a secure work income, a secure retirement income and protection against unforeseen accidents, particularly those that might occur in the workplace-in other words, the assurance of compensation for unforeseen accidents that may be associated with fulfilling work tasks.

speech.para: It is not an unreasonable expectation of Australians to have the support of government in this regard. In that respect, this nation is fortunate in that we have procedures in place which are designed to offer us a secure work income, secure retirement income and protection against unforeseen accidents in the workplace.

The essential intention of this legislation is to tidy up some of the difficulties, inconsistencies and anomalies which are associated with the third expectation; namely, the administration of Comcare. It spills over into a number of other associated legislative areas.

We are confronted, therefore, with an omnibus Bill containing a number of largely non-contentious amendments, mostly to expand, clarify and streamline existing features, plus amendments of a technical nature. None of the amendments would appear to adversely affect individuals; indeed, they would appear to have the contrary effect. In that respect, this is positive omnibus legislation that we are addressing.

The main changes relate to premiums payable to Comcare, requirements for certain authorities to discharge Comcare liabilities and changes associated with leave of absence, disclosure of interest and appointment to the Remuneration Tribunal and commissions. A number of deficiencies in the performance of Comcare have been noted and the Auditor-General has identified various problems. Two of these concern breaches of section 98 of the principal Act which deals with premiums. Various proposed amendments correct these anomalies as elaborated and cited by the Auditor-General.

Other proposed amendments are intended to improve the operation of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation (CERC) Act and associated legislation by clarifying certain transitional provisions and correcting some errors and omissions. Others are proposed to make it clear that employees who are entitled to compensation under the Act of 1971 will remain entitled to compensation under the CERC Act without having to satisfy the tests contained in the 1988 Act. Amendments are also proposed to ensure that employees who were parties to proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the day in which the CERC Act commenced, or who incur costs as a result of an appeal by the Commonwealth against a decision of Comcare, will be entitled to recover those costs. There are a series of quite technical amendments, all of which are directed towards apparent anomalies and, we hope, to the subsequent advantage of individuals.

The Opposition will propose three quite constructive amendments which we see as directed at valid areas of concern in relation to this legislation. The first, as Senator Durack has indicated, is to extend the definition of employee to include persons 65 years of age or older. The Australian Democrats have pursued the issue of discrimination on the basis of age in a variety of contexts and have attempted in the past to highlight discrimination on the grounds of age in this country. I think we are all aware of the fact that Australia is, in fact, an ageing nation and we have to address that demographic fact of life.

If we are to be the clever country and continue to enjoy the standards of living that we have enjoyed in the past, we must have access to our expertise beyond traditional retiring ages, where individuals feel able to continue in the workplace and where employers feel it appropriate to employ people beyond the ages of 60 and 65. In other words, we believe that the time has arrived to free up our attitudes towards compulsory retirement and break down discrimination in the workplace against people who have previously been considered to be too old, so to speak, to contribute to the work force, when clearly quite often they can continue to do so very effectively. So the Democrats will be supporting the amendment that is being proposed by the Opposition to extend the definition of `employee' to include persons aged 65 years or older.

There is a Government amendment which seeks to extend the maximum age for members of the tribunals beyond the age of 65. We support this recommendation. The situation is that the Government is finding it difficult to fill positions because the present provisions exclude people of suitable age and suitable qualifications; in other words, potential members of tribunals are excluded by the present provisions that people beyond the age of 65 cannot serve.

In line with the principle that I have previously outlined and in view of the fact that many of the people who have the talents necessary for such appointments may have served close to age 60 or beyond, the present exclusion for seven years beyond their retirement age means that much of the talent is simply not available. It is not available for what are now not regarded as valid or sustainable reasons. So the Democrats support an amendment to that age exclusion.

We do not accept the arguments of the Opposition, however, in relation to the last of its amendments, namely, to exclude parliamentarians from this freeing process of eligibility. We simply argue that to identify parliamentarians as being potentially untrustworthy because they may be able to manipulate the circumstances of their employment is a very negative attitude to adopt towards those in our own profession. We do not believe there is any reason, any justification, for seeing parliamentarians as being potentially any greater abusers of that opportunity than people who may be chosen from other professions.

Indeed, we suggest that it casts a slur, both upon former members of the Parliament and other members of the Remuneration Tribunal, as it assumes that members of parliament will manipulate perquisites of office to their own advantage, despite the rigorous preselection procedures for appointment to the Tribunal and the wishes of other members of the Tribunal. We believe that there are quite adequate safeguards within the selection procedures that would ensure that any potential abuse by members of parliament simply would not eventuate. We will not be supporting that amendment by the Opposition by virtue of the fact that it is unnecessarily discriminatory. So, in essence, I am saying that the Australian Democrats see this as constructive legislation. We join with the Opposition in supporting it. We will be supporting two of the three amendments that will be proposed by the Opposition.

speech.speaker: Crane Sen W.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise during the second reading debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 to raise a number of issues concerning the industrial relations situation in this country. My colleague Senator Durack has covered the detail of the Bill. I will not go into that in view of the necessity to save time due to the program we have in front of us.

speech.para: Looking at what has occurred in Australia, particularly in the last day or two, it is apparent that the time has come for the Government to make a very clear statement on where it stands in terms of the future of industrial relations in this country-whether the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission under its policy position will in fact remain, or whether it will walk right away from it.

I say this against the background of a number of areas. The most recent issue is the situation on the Australian waterfront. It is worth noting the response of Mr Bull of the Waterside Workers Federation to yesterday's decision of the Industrial Relations Commission. In doing so, one must turn to yesterday's decision. Today's Australian Financial Review states:

In yesterday's decision, the Full Bench said that the commission should not change or abandon the April national wage decision ``unless there has been demonstrated a change of circumstances which justifies this departure''.

That is a very significant statement. The Full Bench also said that the Commission should not be setting wages and conditions in future until the wage fixing guidelines and principles are established later this year. The national wage case is in total disarray in this country. Reform on the waterfront is in total disarray and people do not know where they are going. The Government needs to make up its mind whether it will operate within the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or whether it will operate outside it. Currently, it is trying to operate both inside and outside it. We see that with the waterfront agreement and we see it with what is happening currently in the meat industry in this country.

Wage fixing, which impacts on employment and business confidence, is being totally eroded and destroyed. I put it to Senator Button, who is sitting on the other side of the chamber, that one of the most important things confronting this nation is the need to sort out whether the Labor Government will move to a true enterprise agreement situation or whether it will not, because the whole thing is in absolute total disarray. The waterside will be closed down for at least 24 hours and Robb Jetty, the main meatworks in Western Australia, was closed down for a week. During that period fat lambs which were ready for export actually died in the yards. It is truly a very disgraceful situation.

On top of that, yesterday, in answer to a question I asked, Senator Button made it quite clear that he thought it was acceptable for unions to defy, for economic reasons, decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission. To me that is an absolutely hopeless, disgraceful situation.

talk.start.para: â€”A hopeless and disgraceful distortion of the answer, too.

â€”It is not a hopeless, disgraceful distortion of the answer. I would suggest that Senator Button read it because that is what he said. If we are going to have this system-I do not agree with it but that is beside the point-it is absolutely imperative that, when the Commission makes a decision or recommendation, there is a mechanism to ensure that these decisions are abided by. Otherwise, the so-called umpire-which I have heard about often over the last 12 months-is not an umpire at all.

speech.para: In the remaining time available to me-I agreed to restrict myself to seven minutes-let me make the point that I believe it is absolutely essential in terms of the current chaos that exists in this country that the Government make up its mind very quickly and clearly on whether it is going to take a firm stand. It has to adopt a firm policy direction in terms of where wage fixing and productivity agreements are going and how existing work practices, which are pulling this country down, are going to be fixed. In view of the undertaking I gave, I will conclude my remarks.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to thank honourable senators for their indication of general support for the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, and for the comments which have been made. I foreshadow that the Government will be opposing the Opposition amendments. The first Opposition amendment relates to the extension of the definition of an employee for the purposes of Comcare. I indicate that the Government will be opposing this amendment because it raises quite complex issues which deserve more thoughtful consideration than we believe has been given it by the Opposition. Those considerations include the relationship between the workers compensation and the social security systems, the whole issue of age discrimination, the issue of age 65 retirement and the role of superannuation.

speech.para: We see the amendment as being-if I might say so without offence, because these are very complex issues-a superficial approach to the matter which shows no signs of grasping these important issues. They are important issues and they have to be debated and grappled with but this amendment is not an appropriate way to do it.

The Government, of course, needs to proceed with this legislation as quickly as possible. We do not want to see other elements of the Bill delayed by amendments of this kind. Those other elements of the Bill are critically important to the operation of Comcare and they have to be progressed through the Parliament as quickly as possible. That is not something for which I necessarily blame the Opposition. But the content of the amendment is such that it is not appropriate to be dealt with at this time.

The second amendment relates to whether persons aged 65 years and over can be appointed to the Comcare Commission. The Government will advance its view about that issue in the course of the committee stage debate. The third amendment relates to former members of parliament being excluded for seven years from appointment to the Remuneration Tribunal. That amendment will be opposed by the Government for reasons which will be indicated in the course of the committee stage debate. I do not wish to delay the Bill. I commend the second reading of the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

speech.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: â€”In view of the remarks of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in replying to the second reading debate, I think we should take amendments (Nos) 1 and 2 separately. I was going to move them en bloc, but I think the Government may have a different attitude to each amendment.
â€”In the interests of time, I will be blunt. We propose to divide on the first amendment; we will not divide on the second, although we will indicate opposition to it.
â€”We will have to put them separately. I move:

speech.para: 1. Clause 4, page 3, line 6, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(3) Section 4 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of the definition of `employee' the following:
`, and also applies to persons 65 years of age or older'.''.

As I said in the second reading debate, the Opposition has adopted a policy against discrimination on the ground of age. The Opposition is well aware that the implementation of such a policy is somewhat complex, simply because of the great variety of legislation in which this restriction appears. Nevertheless, we take the view that where there is the opportunity of changing this in legislation as it appears before the Parliament we will do so.

The Government seems to feel that it has to give further consideration to this question of principle. The Minister has said that it is very complex and difficult. I concede that it is a difficult matter, but the Opposition is not as troubled about this matter as the Government, because we have already considered all these difficulties and we have adopted the principle that we are opposed to discrimination on the ground of age. That is the basis of the first two amendments.

Implementation of the first amendment could be more difficult for the Government to manage than the second. The fact that the Government may be prepared not to divide on the second amendment is a hopeful sign: it shows that perhaps the Government is starting to recognise the problem. The only trouble with the Government is that it has not tackled the problem or thought it through, as with so many other things, and apparently it has not been able to come up with a solution. It is for those reasons that I have moved the first amendment. I am very pleased to hear from Senator McLean that the Australian Democrats take the same view as the Opposition on the question of discrimination on the ground of age.

talk.start.para: â€”I endorse the comments of Senator Durack. As the Minister suggests, there are inherently complex and demanding challenges in this amendment; we accept that there is potential for substantial cost involved. But the time has come for Australian society, through its Government, to address those complexities and costs. By supporting this amendment we place those challenges before the Government.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: â€”I do not want to say very much about this. Senator Durack puts this in terms of an Opposition policy of not wanting to discriminate against the aged. So this amendment is moved, this Bill being the vehicle for expressing that anti-discriminatory policy. I do not think any- body wants to discriminate against the aged; indeed, I think that current views around the world not only about discrimination but also about the issues of employment and appropriate retirement ages differ from those that were held a few years ago. But the fact of the matter is that the amendment in the context of this Bill creates difficulties because of a whole range of complex relationships between superannuation legislation and provisions generally and their interface and interaction with this Bill. It is difficult to embrace all this and what follows from this amendment in the context of all those inter-relationships. From the Government's point of view, that is a difficulty we have with this proposal and, for that reason, we will be opposing it.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

interject.speaker: The CHAIRMAN

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being almost 12.45 p.m., the question is that I do now report progress.

interject.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
The Chairman having reported accordingly-

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to order of this day, the Senate will now proceed to Government Business order of the day No. 8.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 15 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Act 1978 to provide that the rate of departure tax be increased from $10 to $20 with effect from 1 August 1991.

The decision to increase departure tax to $20 follows the announcement by the Government in December last year to increase, by $23 million, funding for the promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. The increase in departure tax will serve to offset this additional tourist promotion expenditure.

The increased promotion will allow Australia to capitalise on recent growth in tourism and will lead to significant job creation. It is estimated that 8700 jobs are created for every 10 per cent increase in international visitor arrivals.
Australia's departure tax will remain on a par with similar taxes collected in a number of other countries.

The proposal to increase the rate of departure tax to $20 is expected to double the revenue generated by departure tax and, allowing for tourist growth, is likely to result in an increase in revenue of approximately $35 million in 1991/92 and $37 million in each subsequent year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen I.D.

talk.start.para: â€”The purpose of the Departure Tax Amendment Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Act 1978 to provide that the rate of departure tax for those leaving the country by air be increased from $10 to $20 with effect from 1 August 1991. This brings the departure tax back to what it used to be before 1988, and will earn the Government an estimated $35m next year and $37m in each year following.

speech.para: The increase is intended for the purpose of funding another $23m-worth of promotion of Australia as a tourist destination by the Australian Tourist Commission. We applaud the Government for its long overdue decision to increase promotion to help the industry recover from the 1989 pilots strike and, consequently, we will be supporting the Bill.

It is unfortunate that the tax increase is necessary when one considers that currently the Government spends only around $40m on tourism promotion out of the $2.7 billion in taxes it already collects from the tourist industry. The Tourist Commission's campaign, which was delayed by the Gulf war, has begun in the United States of America, Japan and Korea, and is apparently receiving a very good response with overseas bookings already increasing substantially.

As my colleague the shadow Minister for tourism and aviation, Mr David Jull, pointed out in his speech at the second reading stage, the passage of this Bill, which more than adequately covers the cost of promotion, will assist in tourism growth and development in Australia-assistance which is much needed. Living in north Queensland as I do, I am well aware of the way in which the tourist industry was brought to its knees by the pilots strike. My colleagues from various other parts of Australia-Senator Newman from Tasmania, those from the west, even those here in Canberra-are aware of the devastation which was caused to tourism in Australia by the strike which was so badly handled by the Government.

One wonders just how much less damaging that strike would have been had Sir Peter Abeles not held that very secret information about the Australian Labor Party (ALP) at the time of the pilots strike. One can only speculate as to whether the pilots strike might have been over much earlier if Sir Peter Abeles, the head of Ansett Airlines of Australia, had not had information which, had he made it public, would have meant the annihilation of the ALP in the election. That is something we will speculate on for a long time, but it always seemed to us on this side that that strike was carried on for much longer than it should have been by the way that the Government chose to handle it.

Even now, there is an enormous failure on the part of the Government to recognise the importance of the industry to Australia's economy. Tourism is our largest export earner, generating $6.5 billion in foreign exchange and contributing 5.4 per cent to our gross domestic product. It is also the single biggest private sector employer, providing half a million Australians with jobs. It produced a total of $22.5 billion in tourism expenditure in 1989, $16.5 billion of it in domestic tourism.

Also, new tourist projects totalling $21.2 billion were firmly committed or under construction as of March last year. These are very telling figures indeed. Quite clearly, the attention paid by this Government to the industry is drastically insufficient. Until there is a wholesale change in its outlook on tourism, the country will continue to reap only a fraction of the benefits there are to be had.

In Townsville, where I am based, the ALP-run council has turned the discouraging of tourism, wherever possible, into an art form. The council's flat-earth approach to high-rise development, combined with its tendency to abuse Qantas Airways Ltd, has, more than any other factor, been responsible for the fact that the city's international airport is now practically defunct, that many domestic jet services in and out of Townsville have evaporated, and that it is now cheaper to travel the 400 kilometres to Cairns by bus or plane and then fly south than it is to fly south from Townsville direct.

In the deregulated market, Cairns is far more competitive because it encourages tourism. I am informed that the ALP Mayor of Townsville, Alderman Mooney, refused to meet with executives of Compass Airlines Pty Ltd when they visited the city recently because they chose to operate out of Cairns before they chose to operate out of Townsville. We should compare this attitude with the attitude in Cairns, where the non-government owned and operated airport was told recently by Japan Air Lines Co. Ltd that its only worry about the brand new international terminal constructed in Cairns by the Cairns Port Authority was that it might prove to be too small for its future plans.

It all comes down to the way one approaches tourism. If one turns away opportunities, as Alderman Mooney and the ALP council in Townsville do, and as this Federal Government does by refusing to liberalise bilateral air agreements to allow foreign carriers in to service Australia, one has to expect to wear the consequences of that sort of attitude and that sort of approach.

This Bill is not contentious. However, my colleague David Jull, as shadow Minister for tourism, did mention that one of the things that has concerned him over the last 13 years of operation of the departure tax is the way that the tax is collected. Many of us who have travelled overseas have lined up at booths at various airport terminals in Australia to pay the $10 or $20 departure tax. We have been subjected to standing in queues. We have even been embarrassed by the way in which some tourists, who have found that they did not have enough money to pay the departure tax, have been treated.

In years gone by, collectors have not even accepted American Express or Diners Club credit cards. Some tourists who did not have money would have been amazed to learn that they could not proffer a credit card but that they could sign an IOU. I know that this is hard to believe but it is true.

I have been told about a Japanese tourist, leaving Australia after a good holiday and, hopefully, having spent $4,000 or $5,000 while he was here, being told by uniformed people to sign an IOU, after discovering that he did not have the money for the departure tax. A little further down the track he started to get dirty pay-up-now notes from the Australian Government saying that he owed this money. This absolutely ridiculous set-up needs to be looked at.

As the shadow Minister has said, there must be some way that we can make sure that the departure tax is collected in a better way. It could be a component of the airline ticket, as is done in so many other parts of the world. That would seem to be the sensible way to collect the departure tax. The tax could be part of the airline ticket and the sellers of the ticket would be accountable to the Government for it. This is already done domestically at the Cairns and Hamilton Island airports, just to name a couple, and that is the way it should be done at our international airports.

Some people have argued that maybe the increase in the departure tax from $10 to $20 is too much, but in actual fact our departure tax compares fairly favourably with those in most of the countries in our immediate sphere of influence. I should mention that some of the highest passenger handling fees in the world are in the United Kingdom. The total charges at Heathrow airport are in excess of $80, but at Heathrow people do not line up in front of little booths where someone in a brown uniform demands that they pay their money. It is collected in another way, and it becomes much more acceptable because of the means of collection. I think Australia and the Government should learn a lesson from that.

Although domestic tourism in Australia provides about 80 per cent of business at this time of economic downturn, the domestic industry is at the present time still very much in real trouble. One would hope that the contribution made to the promotion of Australia as an international destination by this increase in the departure tax will see those numbers increase quite dramatically.

We should realise that our share of the world tourism market presently is quite minuscule: we get only about 2 per cent of the North American market and about 4 per cent of Japanese travellers. When we consider that every year some 17 million Americans travel overseas and that some 10 million Japanese will travel overseas this year, we see that our percentage of that business is very small. If we could just double those numbers coming from North America and Japan, the effect on the Australian tourist industry would be absolutely enormous and tremendously beneficial.

I know that this debate today is on a time limit. I close my remarks by saying that the Opposition welcomes this increase and the fact that money is being poured virtually directly into the promotion of Australia overseas as a major international destination. We have to make sure in these times of economic hardship that we get international visitors here because tourism is one of the few industries that is presently going ahead and that Australia has going for it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without request or debate.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: â€”Today I will be acting on behalf of the shadow Minister for administrative services, local government and the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Parer, in the carriage of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. I say right at the outset that the Opposition will be supporting this Bill because we believe it reflects a majority of principles that should be afforded to local government.

speech.para: In discussions with local government over many years one of the big objections that local government has had to previous distribution of funds has always been the lack of predictability of funding. One of the highlights of the Bill is that in real terms the Minister will be guaranteeing funding for the next three years. In one way, it could be said that this Bill is a mark-time Bill because the Government has put on hold the options on local government funding that were given to it by the Commonwealth Grants Commission report presented in February. My understanding is that guaranteeing financial assistance to local government for the next three years will give local government and the Federal Government breathing space to resolve the very contentious issue of the methodology of funding local government in the future.

The Senate would know that the question of fiscal equalisation for local government has been a very contentious issue. The options in the Grants Commission report under `Complementary Relativities' would certainly favour the smaller States. The shadow Minister and I have had plenty of correspondence from the smaller States to support that. Conversely, it would seriously disadvantage and be disruptive to funding for New South Wales and Victoria. We also have plenty of letters to support that contention. It is interesting to note that, to my knowledge anyway, the Australian Local Government Association has not made its position clear on the Grants Commission report and the findings therein.

By retaining the per capita method of funding for the next three years and guaranteeing the same amount in real terms the Government will be able, hopefully, to resolve the manner in which local government will be funded in future. The only warning I would add is that the Government has allowed itself a safety clause in this legislation; that is, if the economic conditions are not satisfactory or there is a major deterioration in the economy, the Government will have a let-out clause that allows it to reduce its funding to local government. I think it very unlikely, the economy being as bad as it is today, that, having not used that clause already, it would be used.

One of the questions put to me by local government is why local government should be funded differently from the States in the way that it receives its financial assistance grants. There is no doubt that is a fair question but, in my experience in local government over 14 years, the method of funding for local government has always been a political football. It has always been rather difficult to come up with a fair and equitable manner of funding. I remember quite a few years ago that the Government received a far-reaching report by Professor Peter Self who conducted an inquiry into local government funding. Unfortunately, some of his major recommendations about the problems in some of the smaller States were not taken up by the Government and, in fact, it opted for the per capita system which we have now.

Likewise, after this latest report from the Commonwealth Grants Commission, the Government has taken what I believe is the least line of resistance after having been severely criticised at recent meetings, particularly by South Australia. Even though in the Grants Commission report the Office of Local Government and the Department of the Treasury favoured fiscal equalisation in principle, the Government has decided to retain per capita funding. I will not go through all the complexities of the report today because we do not have the time, but many queries were raised in the report about the database and the lack of information that was available for the Commission to come up with a report in which it could recommend fiscal equalisation.

However, I agree that there is a need to examine further the options for more equitable funding for local government. This Bill will allow breathing space for that to happen. The Bill also gives the Treasurer discretion to set levels of general purpose assistance grants to local government. It allows changes without frequent amendments to legislation, which I think is most important. Local government is protected in the Bill because the Treasurer has to disclose any changes to the State Minister or the Commonwealth Minister for local government if he is going to use that discretionary power.

Over the last few years there have been some examples of unnecessary amendments to legislation which have caused inconvenience to local government. The Senate has had to deal with unnecessary legislation and problems. I believe that this particular discretionary power given to the Treasurer will be of assistance. Honourable senators may remember that in 1988-89 health grants adjustments were identified that had to be legislated for. In 1989-90 adjustments were made because of State housing grants alterations. This year-it is covered in this Bill-the transfer of the debits tax base to the States and Territories has had an effect on the methodology by which local government is funded. Such changes have to be the subject of needless legislation and I think this particular discretionary clause is very good.

The contentious part of the Bill as far as the Opposition is concerned is the proposal to attach local road funding to general purpose funding for local government. I know that a lot of people in local government see it as a first stage of absorption. Although the Government has indicated that next year road funding will be identified for roads, it will be coming from Consolidated Revenue, not from the land transport budget. In fact, future funding for local roads will be tied to movements in the level of general assistance grants.

The coalition believes that local government has been hoodwinked by this Government into believing that road funding will be identified, when it looks as though it will occur for only one year. I think local government has a genuine concern that the Government has transferred funding for local government for roads from Consolidated Revenue and not from the land transport budget, which means that further down the track we will probably have absorption.

We endorse the part in this Bill that proposes to allow local government to use its road funding allocation with more flexibility. I think that has been one of the bugbears of local government for many years. It feels it has been restricted too much in its road funding allocations. As I said earlier, we are fearful that in the future road funding will not be identified and ratepayers will be denied the opportunity to see how much of their fuel tax, which this Government has been thieving from the petrol bowser and putting into Consolidated Revenue, will actually be spent on their roads.

I note that Wal Murray, the Deputy Premier in the New South Wales Government, has already urged the Dungog Council to strongly resist any moves by State or Federal governments for local road funding to be untied and paid to local government via general purpose grants. The concern out there is already building up. The coalition has decided not to seek to amend this part of the Bill as it was accepted by the Australian Local Government Association at the recent Premiers Conference. The Bill will also have the effect of allocating to local government a vast amount of its funding in a block grant instead of by the fragmented approach that now exists. This should be applauded. For example, the total amount going to local government at the moment is something like $1.2 billion. The adoption of this Bill will mean that approximately $1 billion in one sum is to be allocated on a quarterly basis and only $200m will be left to be distributed by other means. To some extent it reduces the amount of pork-barrelling that has been going on for many years.

Under this arrangement, local government also will now receive their moneys promptly and there is no excuse for State governments to retain those funds, which they have done from time to time. I have received correspondence in relation to the fact that some local government areas believe that State governments have sticky fingers and hang on to money for too long, thereby denying funds to those local government areas. Under this arrangement, there will be no excuse for the States to hang on to that money. In fact, I believe that in this particular year local government will have a windfall in that they will have the funds paid from last year plus, under this new arrangement, an up-front payment. That could increase their funding, although it will be over only a temporary period.

Basically, we do not oppose this Bill. We draw attention to the fact that we are concerned about the low level of road funding. We believe it is essential that the taxpayers and ratepayers of our community know how much of their fuel tax, which they pay at the petrol bowser, goes back into their local roads. We support the Bill because it improves the lot of local government. I know that my colleague Senate Panizza will have more to say about that.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Calvert has pointed out the basics and the main thrust of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, and I will not go over them. I wish to address the matter of funding for local roads, as against regional arterial roads and so on, coming out of the land transport budget into general funding. We have been told that there will be an equivalent reduction in the land transport allocation, but we cannot find where that will occur-unless it is to be part of a land transport Bill later on. It has now been declared that funding for local roads will be untied. As Senator Calvert pointed out, the coalition has decided to go along with that. But that does not mean that we went along with it without a great deal of debate. I can tell the chamber that we did have a great debate on this issue.

speech.para: I agreed with the idea of untying funding, as we know it. I have a long experience of local government and can say that when funding was given for local roads we were given a budget that was tied to roads and tied to where it could be spent. In other words, a submission had to be put in and a decision would be made to spend it on road No. 37-for instance-between kilometre 45 and kilometre 65. That was ridiculous because some shires were far more efficient than others and could make much more use of their money.

Therefore, I applaud the idea of getting away from such tied grants, but I strongly agree with the tying of funds to roads. I believe strongly, and always will, that money allocated in the name of roads should be spent on roads and not on anything else. Otherwise, shires are given the flexibility to use funds allocated in the name of roads on libraries, cultural centres and other things. This could be open to abuse by councils controlled by taxpayers that are not ratepayers as the money could be spent on facilities other than roads. It is not that they do not need such facilities; but I believe there are other ways of funding them. For example, organisations that want a facility may raise a third of the money, local government may put in a third and, hopefully, they may obtain a State grant. However, I will not belabour the point any longer. I believe that funding allocated for roads should go on roads and nothing else because, after all, it is raised in the name of roads. The explanatory memoranda to the Bill tells us that all road funding will be identified at all times, but I presume, as Senator Calvert pointed out, that that might occur for one year and then disappear.

My final point is that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) said, in his second reading speech, that local government was in favour of all these points. I cannot speak for all local government in Western Australia, but I certainly had submission after submission from individual councils, as well as the Country Shire Council Association of Western Australia, the Urban Shire Council Association and the Local Government Association. They are not happy with the situation. They would prefer the funding to be identified and tied to roads as at present, rather than there being open slather, which may well be the case. As has been said, the Opposition will support the Bill, but I will continue my argument in the party room to amend the legislation when we are in government.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate for the support of the Bill.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1991

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The coalition will be supporting the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill because once again it underlines the bipartisan approach to most environmental matters that exists between all the major parties in Australia. I must say, though, that last night's Cabinet decision on Coronation Hill has managed to ensure that there will be a lack of bipartisan support in that area. A political decision was made on the basis of the need for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to continue to appeal to the left wing of his party in order to retain his position as Prime Minister. Where decisions are made by this Government on the basis of merit, as in this legislation, that bipartisan support will, of course, continue to exist.

speech.para: There has been a tendency towards politicisation of the environment in recent times and I hope that the evidence of that, which is so clear today in the Coronation Hill matter, will subside in time. There is no doubt about the bipartisan support over the last 15 years or so for the preservation of one of Australia's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef.

This Bill, which adds a degree of protection to the reef, has the unqualified support of the Opposition. The Bill is intended to decrease the risk of oil and other toxic substances damaging the Great Barrier Reef by requiring all ships over a certain length and carrying specified cargoes to carry pilots while in reef waters. It is aimed at something like only 10 per cent of the 2,000 or so ships in the specified cargo and size categories which are not adhering to the current voluntary system of pilotage. That voluntary system has worked well but it is not comprehensive.

By requiring 10 per cent of the 2,000-odd ships in this category to comply, the Government considers-and the Opposition supports it-we are looking at removing the potential risk of damage to the reef. We do have some reservations about the manner in which this pilotage is to be imposed and whether the most efficient system has been introduced by the Government. In view of the pressure to get this legislation through and as this time slot is a non-contentious one, we will not be moving an amendment along the line of argument that was progressed in the House of Representatives. It is self-evidently absurd that the Government has refused to allow individual shipping companies to have their own qualified pilots with the capacity to pilot and has required companies to use an individual and specific pilotage company.

We will not be pursuing this matter, although I would be grateful if the Minister could outline a rational reason that individual shipping operators will not be allowed to employ suitably qualified pilots for this purpose. The absence of an appropriate explanation in the other chamber is, at best, disappointing, particularly in the context of the bipartisan approach that has been experienced over time on the need to protect the Great Barrier Reef. I stress the bipartisan nature of the approach because it was a coalition government that inscribed the Great Barrier Reef on the World Heritage List in 1981, so our credentials in this area are certainly high.

There has been some suggestion-and we support this view-that other areas equally merit this kind of protection. However, we understand that international law inhibits any Australian Government's capacity to broaden the requirements that are in this legislation to require pilotage in this very sensitive area. The coalition supports the Bill.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to support the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill. I was a little disappointed to hear Senator Michael Baume again use the term `bipartisan'. I wish the Opposition and the Government would learn to use the term `multipartisan' because we have a number of parties now in this Parliament and, in this particular case, there is multipartisan support for this legislation.

speech.para: As Senator Baume pointed out, the legislation seeks to make compulsory something which has been observed to the extent of some 90 per cent in recent years and that is the carrying of a pilot through the very sensitive inner channel of the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef. Senator Baume pointed out that the 10 per cent of ships that do not currently carry pilots will now compulsorily be made to carry such pilots.

I will comment on the last point that Senator Baume made in which he argued that this Bill does not allow ships to use their own pilotage if they have a suitably qualified person. I just wonder what proposed section 59f of this Bill actually means, because there is a section which exempts the requirement to navigate with a pilot on written application by the owner of, or the master of, a registered ship. I would have thought that if the ship were carrying a suitably qualified person, that section would allow the Minister to exempt the ship from the application of this legislation.

I want to make a few remarks about risks of this nature because it seems to me that the risk to the Great Barrier Reef of ships which may be carrying oil or toxic chemical cargoes foundering is in a class which is interesting and there has been quite an extensive debate in the literature, particularly scientific literature, about how one calculates the cost of measures to protect against these sorts of risks. The class is one in which the risk of an accident occurring is small. Many thousands of ships have travelled through this channel and to my knowledge there has been no serious damage to the reef hitherto.

The risk is small but the consequences, should an accident happen, can be vast. The debate has really hinged around how one carries out an assessment of the cost benefit analysis of taking measures to prevent those consequences from occurring. Of course, the economists have gone into the area of cost benefit analysis and have attempted to do something that mathematicians know is fraught with a great deal of difficulty; that is, to multiply a factor which is vanishingly small, it approaches zero, with a factor which is very large. If anybody contemplates that simple mathematical operation for a moment, he will realise that that multiplication produces a very rubbery result. Infinity multiplied by zero produces a nonsense result.

Of course, there are a number of other examples in this class. One can think of the possibility of nuclear accidents, where the risks of an accident occurring have been put at very small levels, but the consequences, as we know from Chernobyl, of such an accident occurring in dollar costs and the cost to human life and health are very large. Clearly, some other method of making a judgment as to the measures one puts in place to protect against these unlikely but, should they occur, very costly events is very difficult indeed.

I would certainly like to congratulate the Government. Having approached this difficult area, nonetheless, and in the light of no serious accidents having occurred so far, it has still sought to legislate for compulsory pilotage through this northern part of the reef, and in so doing increase substantially the protection which will be afforded to the reef and the area immediately to the north of Australia, because I understand the channel extends to the western side of the channel in the vicinity of Thursday Island.

There are other areas of the reef in which I believe the Government is not adequately managing its responsibilities. I was recently on Magnetic Island in the Townsville region to which Senator Macdonald made reference a moment ago. Magnetic Island is in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It has suffered the imposition of a Magnetic Keys marina development which, by any stretch of the imagination, is a disaster and has put a great deal of silt on the reef. Consequent upon the development of that marina, Magnetic Island faces the prospect of a very large intrusion of tourism and the consequences of a large sewage management problem in that effluent will go out on to the reef.

It was a disappointment to me to note that, in relation to the proposed multifunction polis in Adelaide, the Government is contemplating using techniques such as MEMTEC, membrane technology, to handle the sewage discharges into a marine environment-I am not disagreeing with that-but in the case of imminent damage to an existing world heritage area, Magnetic Island, is not prepared to contemplate the application of that MEMTEC technology to sewage treatment.

I appeal to the Government to reconsider that sort of situation. Throughout the Great Barrier Reef greater attention should be paid to using some of these tourist development areas as test areas for better managing things such as general effluent run-off and discharge from sewage. Even though the sewage may be treated, it is nutrient rich and has damaging properties to the marine environment.

As Senator Baume has indicated, we are very grateful that the Government is bringing this legislation forward. We support it. We believe that it will add significantly to the protection of the reef against accidents which may be small in terms of the likelihood of them happening, but could be extremely disastrous should such an accident happen involving a large tanker or a ship carrying a noxious chemical cargo.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate for its enthusiastic support for this Bill.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 10, page 7, proposed subsection 59h (2), lines 14 and 15, omit the subsection.
(2) Clause 10, page 7, proposed section 59h (3), at end of section, add the following subsection:
``(4) Any defence established under subsection (1) or (3) need only be established on the balance of probabilities.''.

I move those amendments to rectify clause 10 in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and also in accordance with the undertaking given by the responsible Minister in the other chamber.

Section 59h of the principal Act deals with the defences that an accused may raise in relation to navigating in the compulsory pilotage area without a pilot. The accused, under subsection (1), can raise the defence of stress of weather or other unavoidable cause. Subsection (2) provides that this defence must be proved by the accused on the balance of probabilities. An accused owner of a vessel may raise the defence under subsection (3) that he did not aid, abet, counsel or procure or was not in any way party to the navigation of the ship in the compulsory pilotage area.

The way the section is currently drafted, it is not clear what the level of proof should be in subsection (3). The drafting implies that a different level of proof is required for the defence provided in subsection (3) than that provided in subsection (1). The amendments I have moved correct this problem and make it clear that proof on the balance of probabilities applies to the whole section. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Section 59, to which the Minister has just moved some amendments, also contains a matter on which I asked for his guidance and assistance during the second reading debate. I stress that we have done the Minister the courtesy of debating this Bill at a non-controversial time. As I pointed out during the second reading debate we did not proceed with an amendment which we may well have wanted to proceed with in order to allow this matter to proceed at a time when votes are not taken.

speech.para: Our concern is that section 59 does grant an exemption, as Senator Coulter has just said, but Senator Coulter's exemption bears no relationship whatsoever to the point I was making, which is that under these requirements the pilot is not permitted to belong to the vessel; in other words, there cannot be an employed pilot. An operator, for example, who provides a provisioning operation in those waters, and who has continual trips in that region, cannot employ his or her own pilot and, in effect, a pilotage company must be employed.

The cost of such pilotage can be very great. It can be up to $10,000 a trip. I ask the Minister to tell us as a courtesy why shipping operators are not permitted to employ their own pilots? I stress that proposed new section 59f, which allows exemptions, does not allow exemptions on the basis of someone having a pilot. It specifically excludes that. It only grants exemptions if, in the Minister's opinion, the use of a pilot would not improve the environmental protection of the reef. Senator Coulter's misreading of that clause--

talk.start.para: â€”I am not misreading it.

â€”Senator Coulter's misinterpretation of that clause does not deal with the issue because, as I stressed earlier, the definition of pilot is `a person who does not belong to, but has the conduct of, a vessel'. The exemption in proposed new section 59f does not deal with having a pilot who is not attached; it deals with not having a pilot at all. I ask the Minister whether he could respond, as a matter of courtesy, to this matter, which was raised in the other chamber.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am struggling to catch up, because I am obviously not familiar with the legislation. If the problem lies in the definition of `pilot' not extending to an employed pilot, it seems to me as a lawyer, rather than as the Minister in charge, that section 59f allowing exemptions from the use of a pilot would be applicable in this situation. If `pilot' means anyone other than an employed pilot elsewhere in the Bill, it must also mean that for the purposes of the exemption provision in section 59f. Under these circumstances, it is possible for the Minister to grant an exemption from the use of an external pilot if in the Minister's opinion to require that ship to navigate with an external pilot, that is a non-employed one, would not improve environmental protection, and so on. In other words, if the definition is as Senator Michael Baume says, then it is also that definition for the purpose of section 59f and the exemption provision would apply.

speech.para: There is some policy reason which underlies, I am told, the legislation as a whole for not normally allowing a pilot to belong to a ship and creating a situation where the master is the pilot as well. There is a good policy reason for not accepting that as the normal state of affairs. In a specific case of the kind Senator Baume describes, where there is a separate employed pilot with designated pilot responsibilities and is so qualified and that case can be made to the Minister, then it seems to me that, subject to any correction, section 59f would do the job of exemption in the circumstances described, which seem perfectly reasonable ones in which to seek such an exemption.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Minister for his explanation, but I hope it is as a Minister and not as a lawyer. I hope that under the Acts Interpretation Act, the discussion that we just had now will add meaning and teeth to the proposition that I have been putting. Otherwise, the absence of such a statement appears to us to leave a most unsatisfactory situation. We hope that the Government will monitor this to ensure that unless there are very sound reasons approvals are given for individual ship operators to have employed pilots without its being up to the whim of the Minister; rather, the onus should be on him to allow it to happen.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am able to say, having further consulted the officials, that the explanation that I gave is entirely consistent with their understanding of both the legal interpretation of the Act and also the underlying policy considerations.

speech.para: There is no intention, I am told, to create any monopoly. A company can employ its own qualified pilot. The policy issue is the one that I indicated-the need, in particular, not only for local familiarity, requiring a qualified person with familiarity with that area, but also a second pair of eyes devoted exclusively to navigation. That is the particular issue that will be addressed in the policy sense if an application for an exemption is sought. That is how the pieces come together.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
