talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Cook was absent overseas last week. Today he is absent because he is attending his father's funeral. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio should be directed to me. Questions in relation to those portfolios he represents should be directed to Senator Bolkus.

question.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports that the Foreign Minister will seek to meet with Ratu Mara, the Prime Minister of the interim government of Fiji, when he represents Mr Hawke at the South Pacific Forum in July. I further refer to the statement by Ratu Mara in Hawaii last October when he said:

question.para: If he-Senator Evans-comes into my office and says `I don't like your Constitution and I think there should be changes', I would say `Get out the door'.

Will the Minister persist with the attitude displayed on his South African sortie, or will he now adopt a different approach to relations with Fiji? Specifically, will he refrain from making statements aligning himself with one political force in Fiji? Will he distance himself from relations between the Victorian Australian Labor Party and the Fiji Labor Party? Will he seek to represent Australia as an honest broker interested only in the future peace, stability and prosperity of Fiji? If not, would Australia's interests be better served by sending Dr Blewett instead?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I think there is an unnecessarily offensive tone to that question, if I may say so, and one that is wholly uncalled-for by anything on the public record in relation to recent times, last year or at any other time. Australia is concerned to develop an appropriate relationship with Fiji as a regional friend and neighbour. We are concerned with the human rights situation in that country, as are a number of other countries around the region and the world. We will not shrink from taking appropriate opportunities to articulate our concerns. I notice Senator Hill's repeated references to the inappropriateness of my statement about the Fiji constitutional situation in the United Nations last year and remind him that he was sitting in the Australian delegation seats at the UN at the time and made no adverse comment, as I recall it, in relation to any aspect of that speech; not least that relating to Fiji. He has been a very late and delayed learner so far as his belief in the inappropriateness of making public comment is concerned.

answer.para: Australia and other countries around the world do remain concerned at the situation whereby the Fiji Constitution represents a significant lessening of the rights of some of the citizens of that country as compared with the case previously. We recognise the reality that that Constitution is now in place and is likely to remain so for the foreseeable future. We will act accordingly in gradually rebuilding our relationship. We still have an inhibition on the re-establishment of defence cooperation with that country for reasons that are obviously associated with the fact that the present government is still an interim one. It has not been sanctioned by any election and owes its existence originally to a military coup. We will reconsider that position-as will New Zealand, as indicated by Mr McKinnon in his visit yesterday-after the next election is held in Fiji.

I will take such opportunities as are appropriate and available to seek contact with Fiji colleagues, including the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, at the occasion of the Forum and will endeavour, as we do in the conduct of all our relationships, to discuss the sensitive and difficult issues in an appropriately patient and low key way. I am sure that His Excellency the Prime Minister will respond accordingly.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the Minister's sensitivity, I ask: does he not recognise that being a party last year to the substantial donation by the Australian Labor Party to the Fijian Labor Party colours his position in relation to Fijian affairs and demonstrates an intervention in Fijian domestic politics?

â€”As I explained at the time in response to a similar question from Senator Hill that has now been recycled, there is an obvious distinction between decisions made by a government as a government and decisions made by a political party as a political party. I happen to be, ex-officio, a member of the Australian Labor Party's external relations committee. It was that particular Party that made a decision last year, on a fraternal basis, to assist a certain party, the Labor Party in Fiji, with some of its administrative expenses. I was a party to that decision as a Party member, not as a Minister and not as a member of the Government. If that distinction is too subtle for Senator Hill's mind, I regret his inability to cope with these realities of contemporary political life.

â€”I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The Minister will be familiar with the success of community legal aid centres in providing greater access to legal advice and education about the law. However, is the Minister able to report on the extent to which community legal aid centres throughout Australia have been dispersed to outer suburbs of our cities and to regional areas and country towns? Will the Minister ask his Department to report to him on the planning of community legal aid centres to ensure that resources are shared equitably around Australia so that everyone who needs legal aid can have access to it?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”I am glad that Senator Reynolds has raised the question of the funding and the location of community legal aid centres throughout Australia. These legal centres provide a tremendous opportunity for members of the community to obtain advice in a very accessible and friendly way in the various centres distributed, I have to admit, mainly around the capitals of Australia rather than in the provincial areas of Australia and in the outback areas with which Senator Reynolds is particularly familiar as a representative from northern Queensland.

answer.para: That has to be put against the historical context. The genesis of many of these community legal aid centres was in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Groups of lawyers, particularly in the inner cities of, say, Sydney or Melbourne-Redfern, for example-got together and established these community legal centres. It was not a Federal initiative; it was a matter that came out of community concerns-well based concerns-amongst lawyers and other community workers in the inner cities of Sydney and Melbourne in particular. Eventually those legal centres attracted Federal funding and support. That has been continued because they provide an exceptional service in those communities. I think that has been recognised in respect of the advice which they give, the educational services which they provide and the law reform initiatives which they sponsor, foster and promote.

As a result, Senator Reynolds would acknowledge that it has been difficult in these constrained times to provide funding for the expansion of the community legal centre (CLC) services throughout Australia in the provincial towns and in the outer suburban areas of our major cities. At the moment the most that I have been able to do is to keep the funding for existing community legal centres up to real terms, given the inflation that has occurred in recent years.

As far as northern Queensland and other regional areas of Australia are concerned, I acknowledge that there are inequities in the provision of community legal centres. At the most recent meeting of the committee advising me on CLC funding, the national representatives acknowledged the legitimacy of the claim upon those scarce funds by such areas as Townsville. As a result, it has been suggested that the funding guidelines ought to be reviewed to try to switch some funds from the cities to those provincial centres. I look forward to a further report on that matter.

A national conference of Australian community legal centres will be held in Adelaide next month and I am sure that that matter will be on its agenda. I hope the community legal centres can help me in a re-ordering of funding priorities to assist in the way that Senator Reynolds and other honourable senators would like to see. This process of re-ordering of priorities has to enjoy the confidence of the community legal centres movement around Australia, and I can assure the Senate that whatever steps are taken will have the benefit of full consultation with those community legal centres and their representatives.

question.speaker: Knowles Sen S.C.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer him to his answer to Senator Kemp yesterday in which he said:

question.para: there is no question of any of these moneys-
that is, moneys provided under the Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians (SAPSAN)-
being allocated to purposes other than development assistance properly so broadly defined

I also refer the Minister to answers provided to Senate Estimates Committee questions in November last year where the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) supplied details of grants totalling $77,861 made through the Australian Embassy in Pretoria to organisations including, among others, the Building Industries Workers Union, $14,795; the South African Black Hawkers and Informal Business Association, $12,391; and the training workshop for panel beaters and spray painters, $17,804. Is the Minister aware that AIDAB advised the Senate Estimates Committee that the monitoring and acquittal responsibility for these grants lies with the Australian Embassy in Pretoria, and that no information on acquittals is readily available in Canberra? Can the Minister assure the Senate that none of these grants has been allocated to purposes other than development assistance? If so, will he advise the Senate of the basis for this assurance?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”It is the practice in embassies, in some appropriate countries where there is scope for this sort of expenditure, for ambassadors to be given discretionary funds for utilisation in appropriate small-scale projects, often of a community welfare or education assistance nature. That is separate and distinct funding from the SAPSAN funding that we were talking about in Question Time yesterday. At least subject to checking, it is my clear understanding that it is in a separate and distinct category from the funds administered by AIDAB itself: as such, one would not expect AIDAB to have auditing or monitoring responsibilities in relation to them.

answer.para: I will need to check the precise details that Senator Knowles has referred to, as well as the particular system that is adopted in Pretoria and Cape Town for the administration of these funds, and I will be happy to supply further information to her as soon as it becomes available.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the AIDAB review of the Special Assistance Program for South Africans and Namibians. Is the Minister aware that this review stated that `the postmonitoring capacity in Pretoria has been limited'? Has the Minister taken any real interest in ensuring that Australian funds given to projects in South Africa have had real developmental benefit, or does his interest in and knowledge of the $15m pledge begin and end with a desire to support the African National Congress?

â€”That is a rather tendentiously phrased question. I have made it perfectly clear that the Government's commitment to South Africa is a nation-building developmental commitment; it is not a political commitment in the sense of party political support for any particular participant in the political process in that country. Accordingly, I have nothing to add to my answers.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to reports of the imposition of tougher listing and reporting requirements by the Australian Stock Exchange. What is the Government's attitude to these new initiatives by the Australian Stock Exchange? Are they consistent with Government initiatives in corporate regulation through the Australian Securities Commission? Do the new requirements go far enough? If not, what areas are in need of attention by the Australian Stock Exchange, the Australian Securities Commission or the Government?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Government has not yet had an opportunity to look at the new listing requirements and rules put out by the Australian Stock Exchange-they were only released in the past few days-but certainly the Stock Exchange is to be congratulated on the initiative it has taken in publishing these proposed listing rules. Any move in the marketplace to improve company reporting and disclosure requirements is obviously very desirable.

answer.para: The Government does place very high priority on the need for listed companies to provide investors with all relevant information relating to the affairs of the company and, in particular, the company's financial position. It is for that reason that only today the Attorney-General released a press statement indicating that he believes there is a great deal of concern amongst investors that they may not be as well informed as they ought to be about the ongoing state of the companies in which they have invested. For that reason, he has commissioned an examination by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee of the need for a legislatively based continuous disclosure regime and the nature of any such scheme. The Committee has been asked to report within two months.

In the light of that initiative, the publication by the Australian Stock Exchange of its draft new listing rules is extremely timely and I expect that that draft will form part of the basis of the consideration by the Advisory Committee of the question of continuous disclosure regime in relation to the financial affairs of companies.

Certainly, the Attorney-General and the Government take very seriously the new sole responsibility placed on them by this Parliament in relation to giving political direction to the regulation of companies and securities matters throughout Australia. I am sure that this Parliament will also respond when it is required to do so in relation to the provision of such matters as the disclosure of very necessary information for investors in our companies trading in Australia.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given Australia's concerted action to bring about the implementation of the United Nations Security Council resolutions on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, what action has the Government proposed to take to pressure Israel to comply with Security Council resolutions 242 and 338 on the occupied territories? Given also the Government's support for sanctions against South Africa, will it impose or propose sanctions on Israel until Israel complies with resolutions 242 and 338? Does the Minister accept the widely held view that the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) enjoys strong support amongst the Palestinian people? Finally, recalling that the Minister this week produced an opinion poll showing strong support for the African National Congress amongst black South Africans, will he now seek opinion polls on support amongst the Palestinians for the PLO and consequently review the Government's policy towards that organisation in light of the results?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”So far as the first part of the question is concerned, Security Council resolutions 242 and 338 were adopted after the Arab-Israeli wars in 1967 and 1973 in quite different circumstances from those in which the 12 Iraq-Kuwait Security Council resolutions were adopted in the past few months. Resolutions 242 and 338 were aimed at concluding active hostilities between the conflicting parties. The question of who was the aggressor was far less clear cut. The international community, including the Security Council, was deeply divided about the rights and wrongs of the wars and the issues which led to them.

answer.para: Resolutions 242 and 338 set out provisions to be met by both sides of the conflict and required negotiation between them. One of these issues was, of course, the settlement of boundaries between the then warring parties of 1967 and 1973-boundaries which have never been determined; whereas in the case of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, established and recognised boundaries were blatantly violated. The onus for the implementation of those resolutions has thus never rested exclusively with Israel. Indeed, Senator Coulter will recall that the Arab side which had lost territory in both wars was, for several years, quite ambivalent about those resolutions, mainly because they implied recognition of the state of Israel.

As to the second part of the question, Australia has supported the sanctions against South Africa in order to put pressure on a government which had institutionalised racism through its constitution and through its whole legal system. That is not the case with Israel, as the Australian Parliament overwhelmingly agreed in 1986. I hope Senator Coulter will again recall the resolution calling for the overturn of the United Nations General Assembly resolution 3379 equating Zionism with racism. For this reason, and for the other distinctions I mentioned earlier, sanctions, in our judgment, are an inappropriate way of achieving implementation of resolutions 242 and 338.

However, we do wholeheartedly support the very determined efforts that are being made by the United States-and Jim Baker in particular-in the aftermath of the Gulf war to bring about a Middle East peace conference based on those resolutions and the principle of land for peace. We continue to urge all states in the region to cooperate with those US efforts.

In relation to the third part of Senator Coulter's question about support for the PLO, Australia has accepted for many years that the PLO does represent the opinion of a significant proportion of the Palestinian people and we have certainly been prepared to deal with the PLO on that basis. We do not, however, accept the PLO's claim to be the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people.

As to the last part of Senator Coulter's question about opinion polls, the polls to which I referred with regard to South Africa were aimed at demonstrating the relative support within sections of the black community for competing political parties and organisations. No readily comparable situation exists with regard to competing organisations among the Palestinian people. But I certainly acknowledge, as I have already just said, that the Government does understand clearly that there is a very significant level of support for the PLO among Palestinians. We have made clear our position with regard to the PLO and we see no reason at this time to review our policy in relation to that organisation.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister accept that in recent years, at least, it is the intransigence of Israel which is preventing resolutions 242 and 338 from being implemented? What further action will Australia take to ensure, as far as possible, that those resolutions are fulfilled?
â€”I have no further comment that I would wish to make on that subject at this stage.

â€”Has the Minister for Social Security seen a report in the Age newspaper of 13 June 1991 in which serious allegations were made concerning the disclosures of personal medical information and the possibility that treatment and medical examinations will have to be undertaken before payments will be made under the Newstart program or the proposed disability reform package? What measures will be taken to ensure the privacy of clients? Under what circumstances will medical examinations or treatment be made mandatory for clients?

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Of course, it was not just a matter of announcing a new package on disability reform before one could have medical examinations mandated by the Department of Social Security. Clearly, the basis has always been there in relation to invalid pensions for medical examinations to be ordered-there is nothing new in that. If anything, under the new package-which, of course, the Parliament will not debate for some time yet-the actual level of medical dysfunction becomes even more important in determining eligibility for payment. So I could not promise that medical examinations will not be ordered because, on occasion, they will be absolutely necessary in order to determine whether there is any eligibility in the first place.

answer.para: I did see this report. I think it confuses Newstart and the disability reform package. But, most importantly, it ignores past practice, current practice and what has been promised for the future. When it comes to the disclosure of information, obviously in the announcement of the package it is clear that at some point in time the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and my own Department will have officers sitting down and looking at a person's disability and whether that person ought to be eligible for a training program. If eligibility for the training program is determined, obviously that person will be expected to take it up. If rehabilitation is expected, that person will be expected to take that up as well.

I think it is important to note when talking about the disclosure of medical details that there is no way in the world that the Department can break the Privacy Act, the Social Security Act or any other restrictions that are placed on the release of information. Medical records cannot and will not be made available except in the sharing in that meeting that I have just explained between departments, and even then they will take place under those Acts with the restrictions that have always applied still applying.

More importantly, when it comes to the Commonwealth Employment Service placing a client who has some disability with an employer, medical details can be made available to the employer-and often are-but always with the client's consent. It is important to note that none of that changes with the announcement of the package.

In terms of its strictness, it is worth noting that we have been careful to make sure that penalties will not be applied straightaway in the disability support areas and will not take place for the first two years so that we can work through the new system and see what penalties for failure to attend examinations, rehabilitation or whatever seem appropriate. When there is a major reform of this kind, we do not race in with heavy penalties. Rather, we see how the system works and, with disabled organisations, we can determine later what penalties ought to apply to organisations for failure to meet reasonable requirements later on.

talk.start.para: â€”I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In light of the Minister's answer yesterday to Senator Hill that the direct payment of $83,000 of Australian taxpayers' money to a foreign political party-namely, the African National Congress-was not approved by Cabinet and that he is mysteriously unable to recall just who authorised and/or instigated the payment, which in turn has fuelled the belief that the payment was in fact made to ensure that Mr Mandela agreed to see him, will he confirm to the Senate whether the growing concern that the payment was indeed a condition precedent for Mr Mandela to receive him is correct; and, if not, will he provide the Senate with details of the precise chronology and copies of bureaucratic advice received by him to justify the political payment?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I think one would need considerably more than $2m as a condition precedent for seeing Senator Bishop. Be that as it may, I reject entirely that there was any such conditionality about the payment in question. The visit and my meeting with Mr Mandela proceeded entirely on a separate basis. I did undertake yesterday, in answer to Senator Hill, to check my recollection of the detailed approval process that had taken place for that $2m two-year program of assistance for the development of economic planning capacity in South Africa, which I announced on 11 June.

answer.para: I have done so, and the situation is that, as has already been indicated in answers to questions in the Senate by me on 14 May and by the Prime Minister in the other place on 29 May, the initiative for this program came from the Prime Minister; its general outline and its proposed order of magnitude were agreed in various discussions between the Prime Minister, me and the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development in the month of April; and its detailed content was the product of recommendations received from the mission led by Professor Garnaut which visited South Africa at the Prime Minister's request from 9 to 16 May.

A Cabinet submission incorporating the proposal with an indicative first year figure of $1m for 1991-92 was lodged by me back on 3 May following consultations with my portfolio colleague with responsibility for aid matters, Dr Blewett. Following consideration of new policy priorities by a subcommittee of the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC), consisting of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, and the Minister for Finance, that proposal was specifically considered and endorsed as appropriate new policy by the full Expenditure Review Committee on 6 June. That was in my absence overseas; thus my imperfect recollection yesterday. I knew the matter had been dealt with, but I could not specifically remember the occasion: it was in fact when I was overseas.

As is the case with all new policy proposals incorporated in the Budget, consideration and endorsement of ERC decisions by the full Cabinet will not occur until the details of the Budget are finally settled in early August.

The timing of the Government's decision on this program was governed by several considerations: the view of Professor Garnaut's delegation that the efforts should be commenced quickly; the timing of the Commonwealth high level advisory group meeting in London, which had been scheduled for 10 June; and my own visit to South Africa. The announcement was made in Johannesburg on 11 June. For the record I now seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard at the conclusion of my answer.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”The detail of this program is and was quite comprehensively set out in the terms of that press statement. While I am on my feet in this respect, I will say something about the proposed monitoring of this $2m because that is the subject of attention on the other side of the chamber.
â€”Do make your statement outside Question Time. Don't take up Question Time.
â€”You asked the question; I am giving you the answer.
â€”This is not in answer to a question. It is a ministerial statement.
â€”Order! There are too many interjections.

â€”It relates squarely to the nature and character of how it will be administered and how it will be monitored. The situation is as follows: in all cases, in accordance with all the various objectives--
â€”My question related to the authorisation of this payment.
â€”Never mind about your question; listen to my answer. In all cases, funding will be conditional--

â€”Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is not answering the question that was just asked of him. If he wants to make a political statement or answer a question that was asked of him yesterday, the appropriate time for that to be done is after Question Time. We would welcome the Minister's statement or answer to a question then, but he should not take up Question Time today.
â€”There is no point of order. Senator Evans, it is becoming a very long answer.

â€”It is an important issue, Mr President. The question was about a conspiracy, and I am giving an answer about the reality. The situation is that in this $2m two-year program, in all cases funding will be conditional, where institutions are involved, on a formal agreement with the institutions concerned as to the nature of the services to be provided. Implementation of the agreement will be monitored by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) and funds will be provided progressively as programs achieve their targets.

answer.para: Seventy-five per cent of this funding will be provided to South African universities and tertiary institutions, which will apply their normal auditing procedures. Twenty-one per cent of the funding is proposed to go to consultancies and visits to Australia which will be provided via AIDAB and audited by AIDAB. Four per cent for the establishment costs of the Department of Economic Planning of the African National Congress will be provided directly to the ANC, as I have said previously. It will not be in the form of cash, but rather as equipment-namely, computers, office furniture and a library of relevant economic and development texts. The recent appointment of an AIDAB officer as a first secretary in Pretoria will greatly facilitate the monitoring process in the future.
The document read as follows-
No. Date 11 June 1991
AUSTRALIAN FOREIGN MINISTER ANNOUNCES ASSISTANCE FOR DEVELOPMENT OF ECONOMIC PLANNING CAPACITY IN SOUTH AFRICA
The Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, made the following announcement today in Johannesburg:

The Australian Government will sponsor a new program to help develop the capacity of the democratic anti-apartheid movement to play an effective role in the sound economic management of post-apartheid South Africa.

The program looks ahead to the day when South Africa has completed its transition to a non-racial and democratic system of government. It will focus on improving the quality of economic debate, analysis and policy development among members of the anti-apartheid movement and on helping improve training in economics, especially among the Black community.

The program will be a practical and concrete contribution by Australia to the capacity of future democratic governments in South Africa. It will see an expenditure of about R4 million (about $A2 million or $US1.5 million) over the next two years, and will be additional to pledges already announced for the present triennium under Australia's Special Assistance Program for South Africans (SAPSA).
The program will include the following elements.
- Short term: the establishment costs of a Department of Economic Planning for the ANC; exchanges of visits to and from Australia.
- Medium term: the establishment of an Institute of Economic Research at a South African university; consultancies and training and research projects.
- Long Term: economic scholarships.
Full details of the program are attached.

The program, an initiative of Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke, arises from Mr Hawke's long-standing concern, discussed on a number of occasions with leaders of Black opinion (most recently with Nelson Mandela), about the vital importance to the future of South Africa and its region of a well-managed, post apartheid economy. At Mr Hawke's direction, a delegation led by Dr Ross Garnaut of the Australian National University visited South Africa from 9 to 16 May 1991 to open a dialogue on economic policy and to develop recommendations on ways in which Australia could assist the ANC and other elements of the democratic anti-apartheid movement in their economic analysis and policy making capacities. The delegation held discussions with a wide range of individuals and organisations including the ANC, PAC and COSATU, the business community, Government officials and academic economists at several universities.

The delegation concluded that a package of assistance in this area could help ease the transition in South Africa and enhance the capacity of a democratic government in South Africa effectively to run the economy.

The delegation considered that the economic challenge facing such a government will be immense, that the assistance is needed, and that it should begin soon. In accepting the delegation's recommendations, the Australian Government is taking a practical lead in helping South Africa meet the economic challenge that lies ahead.
SOUTH AFRICA-PROGRAM OF ASSISTANCE IN ECONOMIC POLICY AND PLANNING
1991-92 (1992-93 figures where appropriate in brackets)
Short Term Impact
(A) Establishment costs of the Department of Economic Planning of the ANC (including library/documentation). USD 63,000
This will allow the central economic policy arm of the ANC to function more effectively.
(B) Visits to Australia (can also include short term visits to South Africa by senior Australians concerned with economic management). USD 120,000

If Australian ideas and experience are going to help inform democratic movement thinking, one of the quickest routes is via brief, focused visits to Australia by senior figures who would meet with senior Australians concerned with economic management and economic issues in government, the ACTU, business and Universities. This would not exclude a smaller element of visits by Australians who could contribute to the discussion of economic policy.
Medium Term
(C) Consultancies (four from Australia and printing costs for the resulting work). USD 100,000 (USD 100,00 in 1992-93)

Australian contributions to the economic policy discussion can be effective through focused consultancies in specialised areas (e.g. aspects of taxation policy). Australian experts would come to South Africa following the identification of priorities in consultation with the democratic movement. They would be based at university research centres but would have internal travel funds for consultations with the democratic movement and workshops at other Universities where serious work is being undertaken on economic policy.
(D) Institute of Economic Research, at a selected University (Director plus establishment costs, some establishment cost and printing year two). USD 188,000 (USD 90,000 in 1992-93).

The ANC is negotiating with the economics discipline at a South African University on the establishment of an independent Economic Research Institute which would nevertheless focus on policy issues of priority to the democratic movement. Subject to a satisfactory outcome guaranteeing (a) independence, (b) professional standards, and (c) University support, funding will be provided to cover the salary of the Institute's Director and the establishment costs of this small unit (including a documentation centre).

Such an Institute would fill a real gap. Traditionally South African Universities have produced little economic policy research. Business organisations have been able to produce their own research, but issues of special concern to disadvantaged groups have in the past been largely ignored. The University chosen should have a good academic reputation for economics, a central location and a continuing contact with the democratic movement.
(E) Upgrading training at a University (Salary for 1 teacher for three years plus student scholarships). USD 160,000 (USD 160,000 in 1992-93).

This specialised course is intended to upgrade Black economists, including democratic movement leaders whose economic training needs to be updated. The course is designed to cover approximately nine months, embracing theory, practice and research. It represents an optimal means of increasing the number of qualified Black economists as rapidly as possible whilst ensuring that they can make a contribution to the South African debate. Provision for short secondments to economic and financial institutions should encourage the eventual employment of the upgraded economists in positions of influence. Funding would depend on the University agreeing to accept this as a diploma course.
(F) Economic policy research project. USD 50,000 (USD 60,000 in 1992-93).

This ongoing project is based at an academic institution closely involved in the analytic study of issues of concern to the democratic movement. The project focuses, inter alia, on the relationship between bargaining structures, wage growth and macroeconomic performance. There is also a special emphasis upon spreading awareness of the results of research (e.g. the March workshop on budgeting for redistribution in which the union and civic leaders). The project is also able to draw on the resources of the Association of Democratic Economists which incorporates economists who focus on policy issues at the three Cape Universities and elsewhere.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Prior to putting my supplementary, I ask: is it appropriate now to seek leave to take note of the Minister's answer or should that be done at the end of Question Time?
â€”I suggest it would be at the end of Question Time, or else we might not get too many more questions.

â€”In light of the Minister's statement that there would have to be supplementary addition to the existing aid budget, which clearly indicates that there is no designated appropriation for the political payment, will the Minister give an undertaking not to attempt to use the Advance to the Minister for Finance or another appropriation, but to introduce legislation so that this matter can be properly debated by the Australian Parliament?

â€”The question is quite inappropriate, given the nature of the funding and approval process that I have described. This will be a normal part of the Budget. It will be dealt with in the Appropriation Bills and the Parliament will have an opportunity to debate it in that context, as with all matters involving both new and old policy that are the subject of budgetary appropriations. It will not be applicable to this financial year; it is the next financial year that we are talking about. The question of utilising the Advance to the Minister for Finance is totally irrelevant.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Defence in his own capacity and as representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. It refers to the decision of the Government to reduce the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) work force by around 700. As a result of this, is it a fact that the Review of Resource Priorities Committee is considering the closure of the Materials Research Laboratory (MRL) in Scottsdale, which is the heartland of north-east Tasmanian potato, pea and other food production? Does the Minister realise the drastic effect that this would have in Scottsdale and, indeed, in Tasmania? Does the Minister realise that the MRL closure would result in the Australian Defence Force losing its expertise in food technology, food analysis, engineering and nutrition and energy expenditure, and that the Australian Army would have to import freeze-dried rations from New Zealand? Finally, in view of the fact that an effective army marches on its stomach, how can the Minister himself stomach the closure of the MRL, thus denying the Australian Army self-reliance in this vital area?

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: â€”This is one of those sorts of questions when we run up the flag and see who salutes. It is quite clear, though, that in the force structure review we indicated that we regarded DSTO as overstaffed, especially in the support staff area. We have been trying over a number of years, but with increasing acceleration, to get the ratio between support staff and scientists to a level that we find acceptable. DSTO within the Australian context is the second largest employer in the sciences. There has been no decision at this stage in regard to Scottsdale. Obviously, every facility in DSTO is being examined and, once that examination is complete, recommendations will be made to me. I cannot anticipate now whether or not Scottsdale will be closed, but I can acknowledge some of the points Senator Harradine has made-that it has had a very good track record in regard to food technology; that the Australian Defence Force's ration packs, et cetera, are the envy of many other defence forces around the world. Indeed, if we had had an enormous stock of them, I guess the United States of America have bought them all during the Gulf war. It certainly did make inquiries at the time as to the number we could make available. We did not have a couple of million in stock; otherwise I think we could have disposed of them.

answer.para: Senator Harradine mentioned the effect on the local economy, and these are tough decisions if they are ever made. I have had to make some tough decisions and I have made them irrespective of the effect on local economies and, indeed, of the political allegiances in a particular area. I also make the point that wherever Defence has decided to wind up an involvement-I am not anticipating here-we always try to leave something behind that is of equal value. I could go through several other examples around Australia where we are intending to close down but, by redevelopment, leave as many jobs as we take. But at this stage I cannot give Senator Harradine an assurance, as I cannot give an assurance in relation to any facility, that it will not close down. Yet, on the other hand, I can say with all honesty at this stage that there is no plan to close that facility. It is just that every facility in DSTO right around Australia-and there are a large establishment at Salisbury, two large establishments in Melbourne, an establishment in Cairns and an establishment in Tasmania-will be looked at and a final decision made. Given the importance of food technology for the armed services, it has to be said that they have a strong case for continuation. But I have to await the report back from DSTO. It may not come for another year as it does its forward plans through to the twenty-first century.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the pusillanimous decision of the Cabinet last night to ban mining at Coronation Hill for the reason, according to Senator Richardson, `To do the right thing and give Mr Hawke a win'. What is the position with regard to compensation for the joint venturers of Coronation Hill who have spent about $14m in exploration work there, based on the exclusion of that area from the stage 3 extension of Kakadu National Park- apparently, until the decision last night-and on every indication by the Prime Minister and the Government that the mine would be allowed to proceed?

â€”It is true that there has been a long history of debate about Coronation Hill. I accept the figure which Senator Durack gave as to the expenditure by the companies-collectively, I suspect-on exploration, feasibility study work and so on, associated with the Coronation Hill site. As far as the question of compensation for that expenditure is concerned, it is not a matter about which I can pronounce at Question Time in the Senate. As I understand the legal advice, there is no entitlement to compensation. If there is any such claim, I presume that it would be dealt with on that basis at the appropriate time.

â€”I ask a supplementary question. In view of Senator Button's answer-and putting aside the question of legal entitlement-will the Government, before it makes its decision, carefully examine the statements which have been made since about 1986 by the Prime Minister and various Ministers as to the likelihood that mining at Coronation Hill would be allowed to proceed?
â€”I am sure that will be done with care.

â€”I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether he has read a paper by Dr Herb Feith and Alan Smith of Monash University on the Kurds and self-determination. In the light of suggested proposals for the United Nations (UN) to develop a procedure for working out a form of self-determination for minority groups in multi-ethnic states, I ask the Minister whether the Government feels that such an approach would be viable and whether Australia could take an initiative at the United Nations along the lines suggested by the authors of the paper. I also ask the Minister whether the Government has any other general policy initiatives to work out ways of resolving the issue of self-determination in areas of conflict around the world, including those in our neighbourhood such as West Papua, East Timor, the Moslems in the Philippines, the hill people of Myanmar, the Tamils of Sri Lanka and Bougainville.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I have recently received a copy of the paper by Herb Feith and Alan Smith entitled The Kurds and Self-determination. It does raise some interesting ideas about the treatment of self-determination. The paper is now being studied in my Department. It has also been referred to our permanent mission to the UN in New York seeking its comments on how such a proposal might conceivably be handled in the UN.

answer.para: I can say that, as a general principle, Australia does support a stronger role for the UN in strengthening collective security arrangements, but the UN does not have carte blanche to unilaterally intervene in a nation's domestic affairs. United Nations action which impinges upon the domestic jurisdiction of a member state is governed by article 2.7 of the Charter, which states:

Nothing in the Charter shall authorize the United Nations to intervene in matters which are essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of any State, or shall require the members to submit such matters to settlement under the present charter; but this principle shall not prejudice the application of enforcement measures under Chapter VII.

What all that means is that the UN, unless it undertakes enforcement action of the kind that we saw, for example, in the Gulf conflict, has to have the agreement of the respective member state to take any action in relation to questions of self-determination. Thus, UN involvement in the resettlement of the Kurds in northern Iraq has resulted from an agreement between the UN and the Iraqi Government to enable such a UN role to be established.

The Australian Government's general approach to the resolution of questions of self-determination in areas of conflict has been necessarily to address these on a case by case basis with respective governments, while indicating that we respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of those governments. As Senator Vallentine will be well aware, we have also been very active in discussing human rights matters, including the problems of the various minorities mentioned by her. We do have a very strong record in urging those countries to respect the individual and collective human rights of their peoples. But in each case, as I guess again Senator Vallentine will be aware, there are complex and individual problems which do require careful handling.

We have been particularly active in our region with the proposal to President Premadasa that Sri Lanka's government, for example, consider using the good offices of the Commonwealth in finding a solution to the problems faced by the Tamils. I have also detailed on a number of occasions what we have been doing in Bougainville. I think our commitment to and engagement in the region is well known. It would be far too tedious for me to go through all the other specific instances that Senator Vallentine mentioned, but I would of course be happy to talk to her at any stage about those specific cases.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission rejection of key elements of the Prime Minister's much vaunted waterfront deal. What implications does this decision have for the Government's deal with the public sector unions under accord mark VI? Will the Government take Senator Cook's deal with the public sector unions to the Industrial Relations Commission?

â€”In so far as the decision given yesterday in relation to the waterfront is concerned, the Government will be consulting with both employers and unions to examine how the waterfront agreement may be progressed following yesterday's decision by the Full Bench. As has already been indicated, it is vital in the national interest that the current situation is resolved quickly. Industrial action by the waterside unions today is regrettable and the Government does not support the strike, although I suppose it is fair to say that at the end of a long process of negotiation the circumstances in which the strike has occurred are understandable. I was asked what the implications of this present situation are for other sectors, particularly the public service sector. I think it is too early, until this matter is resolved, to draw any implications for other sectors of the economy at all.

â€”As a supplementary, would the Minister please answer the last part of my question as to whether the Government will now take the public sector union deal to the Industrial Relations Commission as the waterfront deal went to the Industrial Relations Commission?
â€”I will obtain some advice about that and give an answer as soon as I can.

â€”The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would be aware that influenza and the common cold once again are striking down Australians at work and in the home. These ailments not only cause suffering to many people but also, more importantly, reduce Australia's labour force productivity. They are perhaps the major cause of lower labour force productivity. I ask the Minister: is the Government helping in any way to find a cure to the common cold?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”As Opposition senators well know, this Government is always about a process of healing and improving the situation for people in this country. It is also about a process of change. Let me say that I am very grateful to Senator Maguire for this question because it does give me the opportunity to say something about the important relationship between research and industry and community problems generally. The Government recently, for example, approved a grant of $91,000 made by the Industry Research and Development Board to a Melbourne based researcher developing a--
â€”He is writing it down. Go slowly for him.

â€”The honourable senator does not need to write it down. I can give him a further briefing on this issue at a later stage. That grant has been made to a Melbourne based researcher developing a rapid response influenza diagnostic which could be used around the world. The project builds on work done under a major grant under the scheme. It is one of 13 announced by the Minister for Science and Technology this week. The grants will help Australian researchers collaborate with overseas counterparts in the United Kingdom, France, Germany and a number of other countries including the United States of America and Japan.

answer.para: Most of the grants will be for three financial years, beginning in 1991-92. Three of the grants are in the area of advanced manufacturing, three in biotechnology and biomedical, and two in information and communications. Others are in energy, mining and agricultural engineering.

Senator Patterson, by way of interjection, has introduced what I can only describe as a domestic, even suburban, solution to the problem. What I am talking about is a collaborative international solution to a problem which concerns people worldwide.

This international collaboration program is an important means of integrating Australian research into the international research environment. Grants will support the cost of international collaboration elements for research with existing Australian government funding. I must say that, in terms of applications for this international research collaboration program, there has been a continuing emphasis on international contacts in both research and industry. There were 117 applications involving collaboration with 25 countries. The significant interest in the scheme shows the increasing importance which researchers and industry are placing on the use of international collaboration for the benefit of Australia.

I thank Senator Maguire for his question. In terms of all the questions we get here, this is one which strikes at the concerns of every Australian citizen and family. It is something which perhaps the Opposition is not particularly interested in, except for the purpose of making a bit of political rhetoric and noise in this chamber. The questioner is to be congratulated on an intelligent approach to a very important problem.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to questions that I raised with him during the Appropriation Bills debate relating to his Department's improper use of media monitoring consultants for political purposes and to his response to me on 6 May wherein he confirmed that the charge for media monitoring for the period July 1990 to February 1991 averaged less than $4,500 a month, and that for the months of March and April this year the charges were a whopping $18,260 and $17,700 per month. I ask: what was the purpose of the media monitoring and how does he justify using taxpayers' funds through his Department for purely political purposes?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”This is very much a recycled question. As Senator Parer indicated in his foreword to the question, he has asked it before and had the answers before. I cannot add anything further to what I said in this place some few weeks ago during the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill, and that is that he should take into account that, as public interest increases in issues related to the Department, obviously there will be a greater need for information to come to us.

answer.para: The other point I made at the time was that the resources of the media monitoring facility are used by both me and my office, as well as senior departmental officers. That was also given in response to Senator Parer at an earlier time. As I said then, the basic value of media monitoring is that the Government, the Department and all involved in public administration have a very clear and direct idea of what public attitudes are and what points are raised in public debate, with a view to taking them into account when making decisions. As I also said at the time, the use of such a facility is one that is widespread, not only I would believe on a Federal government level but also on a State government level, as well as internationally.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to his response to me of 6 May. I ask him why he attempted to mislead me and this Parliament by erasing crucial matters in the departmental response which, regrettably for the Minister, were not erased when the response was provided to me? I seek leave to table the Minister's letter and attachments which clearly show his clumsy and unsuccessful attempts at censorship. I ask the Minister: is this not exactly the same sort of dishonesty that we have all come to expect from his Prime Minister?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”There is nothing new in the sorts of allegations that have been made by Senator Parer in his supplementary question. In fact, I see it as a routine game plan that we come in here and Senator Parer from time to time--
â€”It is in your handwriting. You have drawn the line through it.
â€”Do you want an answer or not? Just sit down and behave yourselves for a minute.
â€”Order! I will chair Question Time.

â€”Mr President, I raise a point of order. I accept your intervention, and I simply invite you to indicate to Senator Bolkus that that sort of conduct to which we are rapidly becoming accustomed is not acceptable, and he ought not to do it again.
â€”Order! There is no point of order.

â€”The point I was making was that there is a game plan. Senator Parer comes in here with a press statement that has already been written out and is about to be circulated in the boxes, making allegations of misleading Parliament. We go away and 24 hours later, 24 minutes later, we discover that the allegation-as has been consistently shown on every other occasion it has been raised-has been wrong. But it does not stop the allegations of my misleading Parliament and it does not stop this great incapacity of those on the other side to address issues fairly and responsibly.

answer.para: Firstly, I have not misled anyone. Secondly, I deny and refute totally any allegations of dishonesty by this side of the Parliament. If there is any dishonesty in debate in this place-and we have experienced this-it is Senator Parer's incapacity to tell the truth in his press statements.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Is leave granted to either table or incorporate the letter and attachment?

interject.speaker: Senator Parer

talk.start.para: â€”Incorporate, Mr President.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Minister for Social Security to an article in the Age by Margo Kingston on 7 June 1991 titled `Richardson goes in to bat for sole parents'. I also refer to the fact that sole parents are permitted to earn $15 a week in maintenance income for one child and a further $5 a week for each additional child in maintenance income before their pension is reduced. This contrasts with a limit of $40 a week for income from other sources before their pension is reduced. Firstly, does the Minister acknowledge that failure to address this situation has disadvantaged custodial parents, in particular those who are reliant on only the sole parent pension and maintenance? Secondly, in view of his reported concern for sole parents and their children, will the Government be moving to treat maintenance income on the same basis as other earnings for the purpose of the income test for the sole parent pension; and, if not, why not?

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not have a copy of the article with me, but I recall seeing it. The figures that Senator Lees gives on the maintenance income test for sole parents, at what point the penalty is suffered and the other penalty-free area are correct. It has to be noted that, from memory, there was a wrong figure in that article. At the moment, about $10m a month is paid in maintenance as a result of the setting up of the Child Support Agency, so many thousands of sole parents and their children have been the beneficiaries of that maintenance. It means that custodial parents are taking on responsibilities that they have never had before. It should be acknowledged that for many sole parent families that has been of particular benefit. I mention that because the figure in the article is $40m a month. I wish it were true, but that is quite clearly an exaggeration.

answer.para: I do have some plans for sole parents and something that affects the maintenance income test that I will be suggesting to the Government's Expenditure Review Committee and to the Cabinet for the Budget, but I am in a very difficult position in that I cannot really explain my plans to the Senate before I explain them to those bodies. answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator O'Chee would be aware, on 13 May the Government decided that negotiations should proceed with all potential purchasers of the Associated Plywoods Sales sawmill in Ravenshoe regarding some Commonwealth financial assistance to ensure that the mill could continue to operate. talk.start.para: â€”At Question Time on 15 May, Senator Watson asked me a question about the basis of livestock valuations for primary producers. I have obtained an answer to that question from the Treasurer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
TREASURY
SENATE
(Question Without Notice)
SENATOR BUTTON: On 15 May 1991, at Hansard page 3373, Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

Is it a fact that the Commissioner of Taxation is denying primary producers the right to change the basis of valuation of livestock in these recessed conditions from cost to market price under a section 33 discretion of the Income Tax Assessment Act? This refusal is based on the grounds that a general fluctuation in livestock prices, where the market movement is one occasioned by widely prevailing economic circumstances, is not sufficient to warrant a change in the manner in which taxation on livestock is assessed. Is not such a decision uncaring, unreasonable and destructive? Will not such decisions cause unwanted financial hardship to primary producers caused by a collapse in sheep livestock market prices?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has, wherever possible, adopted a sympathetic approach in exercising his discretion under section 33 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, the Commissioner as a matter of public duty must take into account all considerations relevant to the intent of that section in order to exercise his discretion.

Until 1936, a primary producer's election to adopt either cost or market value for stock on hand was irrevocable. This was changed with the enactment of section 33. Section 33 provides that a taxpayer shall not, except without the leave of the Commissioner, adopt a basis of valuation of his live stock taken into account at the end of the year of income different from the basis on which the valuation of his livestock was made when it was last taken into account at the end of a previous year.

The Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the amendment stated that the election to change may be made, for instance, where a partnership is created and the various members desire a common basis for bringing the value of the livestock of the partnership to account.

The Commissioner takes the view that the enactment of section 33 was made to apply in very narrow circumstances, such as where there was a change in the business arrangements, and that it was not enacted so as to allow primary producers to change the basis of valuation of stock on hand because of mere price fluctuations.

If a primary producer was able to change the basis of valuation because of changes in seasonable or economic conditions the Commissioner could be placed in the situation of never being able to arrive at the true profit of the primary producer. This state of affairs could be maintained on an indefinite basis, due to the rise or fall in prices in the rural sector. A consistent method of valuation is needed for the Commissioner to make a proper assessment of a taxpayer's income.

Moreover, few primary producers if any, would be able to ascertain accurately the cost price of their live-stock after having adopted market value for one or more years. This would be a particular problem in relation to live stock acquired by natural increase in the year following acquisition.

Primary producers are entitled to average their incomes over five years and can also participate in the Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme. It is these provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act which have been designed to compensate farmers for the fluctuations in their incomes. Few other taxpayers have these or similar entitlements.

talk.start.para: â€”On 17 June, Senator Spindler asked me a question as Minister representing the Treasurer relating to the possible takeover of Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd by Tate and Lyle. answer.para: Leave granted.

TREASURY
SENATE QUESTION

interject.speaker: Senator Button

talk.start.para: â€”on 17 June 1991 (Hansard page 4644)

interject.para: Senator Spindler asked me, as Minister representing he Treasurer, a question without notice concerning Tate &Lyle's takeover of Bundaberg Sugar. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government welcomes direct foreign investment which is consistent with the needs of the Australian community.
- Proposals in the majority of industry sectors are approved unless judged contrary to the national interest.
The foreign investment policy was significantly liberalised in 1986/87 when the net economic benefits test was replaced by the not contrary to the national interest criteria.
- Since then few proposals have been rejected on national interest grounds apart from those involving developed residential real estate.
- Investors can expect that approval will not be withheld from a proposal on national interest grounds other than in unusual circumstances affecting Australia's vital interests and development.
Against the background of Australia's current account deficit and foreign debt burden, it would be singularly inappropriate to be tightening foreign investment policy across the board.

- To do so would have an adverse effect on the long term direct foreign investment necessary for Australia's future growth and development, the creation of jobs, the restructuring of the economy to make Australia competitive internationally and improved living standards.
- The foreign investment policy of the Democrats would greatly curtail foreign investment in Australia and that policy would undoubtedly be contrary to the national interest.

In the case of Tate and Lyle, policy does not require the parties to demonstrate net economic benefits and the Government was satisfied that the proposal was not contrary to the national interest after taking into account:
- The views of the Queensland Government and the Trade Practices Commission;
- Representations from interested parties including the Queensland Cane Growers and Bundaberg Sugar Co Ltd;

- Tate &Lyle's actions as soon as its executive became aware of a potential restrictive trading agreement with British Sugar PLC in ending the arrangement and informing the appropriate authorities; and
- the fact that although Bundaberg is a significant sugar miller, a successful Tate and Lyle takeover would only put the UK company in control of 5% of the Australian refined sugar market.
There were no conditions attached to the Government's approval of the Tate and Lyle proposal.

As noted by him, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) review team's report on the special assistance program, which I tabled earlier-it is part of AIDAB's auditing process-picked up some instances where some small non-government organisations operating within the front-line States of South Africa, in dealing with training and educational programs for refugees and/or disadvantaged black South Africans, have not always been timely and sufficiently detailed as far as listing students' courses and the like is concerned. For example, the education office in Lusaka was one of those bombed in 1988. In all cases appropriate follow-up action has been initiated. Post activities, including this funding, in Harare, Lusaka, Nigeria and Pretoria were audited in 1990 by the Department's auditors.

answer.para: Most of the aid projects funded from the SAPSAN allocation are administered through Australian or international voluntary organisations such as Austcare; the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad; Community Aid Abroad; the Overseas Service Bureau; and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. These organisations themselves are also subject to periodic audit under their specific charters.

A fuller outline of projects reporting processes, approval guidelines and summary of expenditure to June 1990 was given in my answer to a question from Senator Kemp on 27 November and also to question on notice No. 639 from Mr Cobb in the House of Representatives. talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented during Question Time. After I had asked a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, he began his answer by saying:

As my question was about the completely improper payment that the Minister was responsible for making to a political party in South Africa, I find it highly offensive that he should imply that I would act in a way similar to him. As I read the press release that Senator Evans had incorporated into the Hansard as part of his answer to me when he fully misrepresented me, he has, on any reading of that document, misrepresented points in it in two ways: firstly, nothing in the report by Professor Garnaut justifies--

We have also been patient in listening to the range of extra matters that have been introduced subsequent to Question Time. On the grounds of equity alone I ask that, as Senator Bishop gives her personal explanation, you simply permit her the same degree of liberty that you allowed Senator Evans.
â€”Order! I think there should be tolerance on both sides. It is a personal explanation, Senator Bishop, and you did say you were going to be brief, but you may continue.

Senator Evans chose to say that $2m would be necessary to arrange an appointment for me to see such a person, whereas I only raised the sum of $83,000 as being a condition precedent. However, reading the South African program of assistance on economic policy and planning, which Senator Evans provided, I see that far more than $83,000 was paid; indeed, one could say that most of the $2m was provided, as there is an intent to equate the African National Congress (ANC) with the democratic movement. speech.para: I was making the strong point that far from there being a necessary payment of $2m to make an appointment for me to see anyone in a foreign nation, as it is necessary for the Minister, the justification that the Minister gives of Professor Garnaut's report somehow justifying the payment is totally without foundation in the document that he has tabled. debate.sub1.title: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I have received a letter from Senator Parer proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interject.para: The need for the Senate-

(a) to condemn the decision of the Hawke Labor Government to permanently ban mining at Coronation Hill as the price Australia has to pay for the Prime Minister's position as a hostage of the ALP Socialist Left;

(b) to condemn the Prime Minister for breaking yet another promise which will ultimately cost the nation millions of dollars in lost investment and thousands of jobs in the `recession we had to have';

(c) to condemn the Prime Minister for destroying opportunities for the Jawoyn people in particular and the Australian people in general, making all Australians the losers in his campaign to save his own leadership.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: â€”Last night we witnessed yet another act of economic vandalism perpetrated on every Australian by a scared little Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who has yet again shown he is totally incapable of keeping his word. On the strength of assurances from this discredited Prime Minister, the Coronation Hill Joint Venture proceeded to spend some $14m on exploration and feasibility studies with a view to developing a resource. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which was then involved, in fact received a letter from Mr Hawke dated 9 October 1987 stating:

speech.para: I can assure you that there has been no change in Government policy on the Conservation Zone concept or in relation to Coronation Hill.
No-one told Brian Loton that the only way to deal with this Prime Minister was to line up Sir Peter Abeles and Bill Kelty as witnesses-and even then he does not keep his word.

Just what is Coronation Hill? It is part of the buffer zone for the Kakadu National Park, described by Senator Evans-I am pleased to see him in the chamber-as `clapped out buffalo country'. It was previously mined by United Uranium in the 1950s and 1960s and some 25,000 to 35,000 tonnes of ore were extracted from the area. However, relying on the Prime Minister's written guarantee, the Coronation Hill Joint Venture went ahead and proved up deposits of gold, platinum and palladium.

These reserves have the potential to employ some 200 people during the development phase and 200 to 250 Australians in the operational phase, of which at least 30 would have been Aboriginals from the Jawoyn race. Because of the flow-on multiplier effects, a further 175 jobs would have been generated elsewhere in the economy.

Export or import replacement earnings would have been in the order of $62m per year, plus $43m generated from the multiplier effect. It is very sad that I have to stand here today and say `would have been', because that is past history. It is ironic that the platinum and palladium are used, among other things, to help cut car exhaust emissions and that Australia spends some $40m a year importing these metals from South Africa.

Towards the end of 1989, this project and this long sorry saga which had satisfied all the environmental demands of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories was put on hold. Our discredited Prime Minister was not prepared to discuss the issue with the much respected Sir Arvi Parbo, but happily spent some 90 minutes on the phone with Phillip Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation.

As Senator Richardson, the engineer behind this campaign, who is looking across the table will appreciate, this environmentally-approved, export-oriented project was put on hold for purely political purposes-the pending Federal election. This nation, suffering from the recession we had to have, was to be sacrificed to the green vote marshalled by Senator Richardson and Phillip Toyne.

After the election, Coronation Hill was referred to the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC), although it was understood that there were no environmental constraints. The RAC discovered that the Australian Conservation Foundation-knowing that the environmental card was worthless-now concentrated attention on the Aboriginals who had previously supported mining. No-one will dispute that. It was claimed on their behalf that the area housed a spirit called Bula who, if disturbed, would bring catastrophe to the local area and perhaps to the universe. However, there is no conclusive evidence, as members of the Australian Labor Party would realise, of Bula's presence, and there was no suggestion of his presence until some five years ago.

In 1989, Senator Bob Collins, a humble backbencher at the time, but now a Minister in this Government, who was a party to this decision, accused those orchestrating this change of mind of being `consummate ratbags', acting against the long term interests of the Jawoyn community. They were the words of Senator Collins in 1989. I think that that is an apt description of the Labor Government itself.

Surprise, surprise-what happened next? Our discredited agnostic Prime Minister found an escape route-a rat hole-which would enable him to reward the loony Left of his Party for saving his hide in the recent leadership challenge. What unmitigated hypocrisy! This person, who thumbed his nose at his own Christian principles and bragged in his biography of his religious disbeliefs, would now have us accept that he is a `born again Bula'.

Make no mistake about it, this spineless Prime Minister could not care less about the Jawoyn people or Bula. He has not acted from integrity-he has proved over and over again that he has none. He has acted out of sheer and utter terror-terror of the socialist left; terror of the greenies; and, of primary concern to him, terror of the honourable member for Blaxland who is waiting to pounce, and pounce he will. The Prime Minister does not care about the Jawoyn and does not care about Australia. To his utter disgrace, he is simply using-or should I say abusing-the Jawoyn peoples as pawns in his little game. It is a disgrace.

We have a recession in Australia which has been imposed upon the Australian people by this Hawke Labor Government. Every time the Hawke Labor Government pulls a political stunt like this, it consigns thousands of Australians to the unemployment scrap heap. It is not just a matter of people directly or indirectly missing out on employment at Coronation Hill; it is also a disincentive to investment in the only industry which can make a major contribution to lifting Australia out of the economic disaster inflicted upon us by this pusillanimous Prime Minister.

Treasurer Kerin says that Coronation Hill has been blown out of proportion. Most people would have expected something better from John Kerin. He, of all people, knows of the damage to investor confidence that will follow this opportunistic decision. The Prime Minister's craven cowardice will cost Australia dearly. It will cost jobs; it will cost export income; and it will add to our import bill. Our foreign debt will continue to soar. The standard of living of every Australian will continue to decline. It is apparent that Treasurer Kerin, for whatever reason, has caught the Hawke disease. He is living proof that if one lies down with the dogs, one gets fleas.

The losers are not the joint venture partners; they have competing sources of scarce resources. Regrettably, because of this decision, few of those sources in Australia will be attractive. The losers will be the Jawoyn people who are deprived by this decision of the opportunity to negotiate with the joint venturers-it has been cut off. This decision consigns those people to continued poverty. They will remain reliant on welfare, with little future and little hope for independence. The losers will be the people of the Northern Territory. The losers will be every Australian.

Coronation Hill joins a growing list of projects which have been torpedoed for political expediency. Because of the decisions on Coronation Hill and Wesley Vale and because of the crazy three-mine uranium policy, the cost to Australia is some $1,000m a year. This is the cost in respect of just those three areas. Is it any wonder that we are in the worst recession in 60 years? Because of the actions of this Government, there is no end in sight.

I challenge people on the other side to tell me where this recovery will come from. All people in the Labor camp must be very proud indeed of the havoc and devastation they have wreaked on Australia-a country which should be prosperous but which, because of the Government's actions, is wallowing in the despair of a recession.

talk.start.para: â€”I call Senator Richardson.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
â€”Who are you speaking for today?
