â€”I wish to speak for the Government. There are three elements to this matter of public importance. The first condemns the decision and refers to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as being a hostage of the Australian Labor Party socialist left. I think it is probably worth addressing this nonsense, but not for long.

speech.para: The position of the Prime Minister on this issue and on a host of other issues going back decades which have involved Aboriginal people ought not to be put in question. Those opposite may attack the Prime Minister for all sorts of things, as indeed they can attack any of us. But the Prime Minister's record on the heritage and beliefs of Aboriginal people is first-class and goes back decades. It should be remembered that in the leadership challenge that occurred some weeks ago my close friend and colleague Senator Robert Ray was a very strong supporter of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is not a hostage of Senator Robert Ray, Senator Gareth Evans, anybody else who supported him, or the Left. The Prime Minister has shown time and time again on this issue that he is the hostage only of his own conscience. That is what all prime ministers ought to be.

On the question of Coronation Hill, I note the opening phrase in Senator Parer's speech, which I think sums up the attitude of the coalition on this decision and a host of other decisions, and that is the phrase `economic vandalism'. At any time the Government takes a decision against any development, for whatever reason, we are considered to be economic vandals. The truth is that there is a host of reasons for decisions that are taken that will never satisfy the likes of Senator Parer or the Opposition.

For Senator Parer and the Opposition, the type of technology that would be used at a pulp mill at Wesley Vale is irrelevant. Whether or not organochlorins or anything else were to be pumped into Bass Strait is irrelevant. Senator Parer has no worry about that at all. But he must understand at some point that millions of Australians have that worry. One of the reasons that I know that is because Senator Parer is sitting opposite and I am sitting here. Millions of Australians have that concern. If one takes Wesley Vale as an example-and Senator Parer raised it today-the very same people who walked away from Wesley Vale because they could not abide the Commonwealth guidelines are now queuing up to do it again under those same guidelines.

The truth is that the Government had at the time set up some tough guidelines. Australians believe and are entitled to know that the Government did not walk away from them on that occasion and will not in the future. But the really offensive part of Senator Parer's contribution was this business about there being no conclusive evidence of Bula's presence and their having no idea of him until five years ago.

talk.start.para: â€”In that area.

â€”They are Senator Parer's words. I refer to the report of the Resource Assessment Commission which examined this issue under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Stewart. It is quite obvious that Senator Parer has not read it. It never takes long in times like these for reactionaries to crawl out from under every rock in the country. My God, the rocks have been emptied this morning and again this afternoon in the Senate! We had Marshall Perron this morning dismissing any Aboriginal beliefs in Bula in the region as `superstitious mumbo jumbo'. While we have not had much colour from Senator Parer-and that figures-we have got this phrase `no conclusive evidence of Bula's presence'.

speech.para: I quote from the second reading debate on the Bill to set up the Resource Assessment Commission. The then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, said:

It will provide a transparent, consistent process that can be used by all interested parties as a means of having their information and their views impartially and independently assessed and considered . . .

That is what he said and that is exactly what has happened. The problem for Senator Parer is that it did not go the way he wanted it. There are two passages in Justice Stewart's report that I think dispel this nonsense on Bula which Senator Parer was parroting about today. The first passage says:

The question of whether the Bula tradition is a living religion or an archaeological relic is ultimately subjective. The evidence presented to the inquiry and confirmed by the inquiry's consultants confirms that Bula ceremonies are no longer performed. But the beliefs are still widely held. Men still sing some associated songs. Restrictions continue to be placed within and around Bula sites and those who believe in Bula still feel the consequences of disturbing him. In the minds of many Jawoyn people the Bula cult is a living religious belief.
That is what Mr Justice Stewart said.

talk.start.para: â€”Not at Coronation Hill, and you know that, too.

â€”I do not know that at all; I have been to Coronation Hill with the custodians too many times-I wish Senator Parer had. There is no way that Senator Parer will, because any time that an Aboriginal belief stands in the road of a mine, he will ride over the Aboriginal belief in a bulldozer-he will drive it himself. But some of us do not accept that that is an appropriate or respectable way to behave.

speech.para: I note the interjections of Senator Crichton-Browne on Merlan and the consultants. I will have something to say about that later on, because he is not the first person to attack the consultants, and he is not the first to have his allegations about them and their objectivity smashed. What Mr Justice Stewart says in section 761 of the report is interesting in relation to the five years of Senator Parer. He says:

There is no doubt that it was well established and known in detail by senior Jawoyn Aboriginal people over four decades ago. It is obviously not a modern invention and many contemporary Jawoyn people hold a sincere belief in its power.
The report, at 7126, says:

The concepts of the `sickness country' and multiple Bula sites occur in the first anthropological records of the area, which date back to the early fifties. By the early eighties Bula's presence and influence is recorded by anthropological observers as connecting focal sites by a network of sensory links. Coronation Hill, known to the Jawoyn as Garatba, is part of the Bula tradition.
At 7128, Justice Stewart says:
Whatever the combinations of reasons and influences might be, it is clear to the inquiry that the custodians regard Garatba as being associated with Bula and as containing the essence of Bula.

There is the answer to the `What about Coronation Hill?' interjection of Senator Parer. After a very lengthy, painstaking examination of Aboriginal traditions and beliefs, that is what Justice Stewart and his commissioners had to say. Senator Parer's problem is that it does not accord with his predetermined views.

talk.start.para: â€”Prejudices.

â€”`Prejudices' is certainly a far better word to use in this context. However, in looking at the reports by consultants on the anthropological aspects of this, the mining industry did much to trumpet a report by Dr Brunton. We were told that this was the report that we had to take notice of. There are two things to say about that. Firstly, while Dr Brunton may have an excellent track record in Melanesia, in looking at kava use and so on, one wonders about his expertise in looking at the Jawoyn or the Aboriginals of northern Australia.

speech.para: To run opposite to that, that report was prepared by the Institute of Public Affairs. Whatever one may think of the Institute of Public Affairs, as far as I can see, it has never been known as a champion of the rights of the underprivileged in Australia and it never will be.

talk.start.para: â€”That is not true.

â€”It is a champion of the rights of privilege for people like Senator Crichton-Browne. Dr Brunton claimed that the RAC's anthropological work was inadequate and the RAC itself had uncritically accepted that work. In criticising Dr Francesca Merlan and Dr Ian Keen in the same way that Senator Crichton-Browne did by way of interjection, the inquiry itself then made sure that it got two senior anthropologists to examine and review the work of those consultants. Dr Hiatt, one of the anthropologists, said:

speech.para: The Keen-Merlan report is a document of which any anthropologist would be proud.

He commended the honesty and the fullness of the empirical records submitted to the Commission. That is what he said. Dr Maddock, the other one who had been nominated to review it-and another person favourably looked upon by the mining industry-could find nothing in that work to criticise.

talk.start.para: â€”He supports Bula.

â€”That is right; and as far as Senator Crichton-Browne is concerned, anyone who does must be wrong. The problem is that every time an independent expert looks at this, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Parer think he is wrong. The kind of high quality research into the environmental, economic and cultural issues that we are talking about here, which were examined in this inquiry, must be taken into account. At the end of the process we cannot simply wipe the lot because the preconceived, predetermined notions do not happen to be borne out by the evidence. I for one am proud of the decision.

speech.para: From an environmental point of view, I had always had the concern that there may have been environmental damage, particularly if other mines in the Coronation Hill conservation zone area were to go ahead. But it is obvious from the attitude of the companies in recent times that El Sharana did not turn out to be what they had hoped and that the pressure that would have been on the tailings dams at Coronation Hill from an additional very large mine simply would not exist. So the idea that the conservation zone should go into the park is not locking up a whole lot of sites, a whole lot of potential mines; it is locking up one. When we try to work out what this one site is worth, what we are saying--

talk.start.para: â€”Are you saying that mining can go ahead at El Sharana?

â€”No, I am not saying it could go ahead there. I just said it would not. I wish that the honourable senator would listen, and I wish that people would take some account of the real economics that are involved here. Coronation Hill on its own-and in the end that is how this turned out, as I said, because of the reports that did not verify that El Sharana would in the end be a commercial proposition-is not some big deal project. It could perhaps, at full capacity in several years time, contribute something like one per cent of Australia's gold production-not some great bulk of production in Australia but only a tiny bit. The mining companies placed an advertisement in the newspapers the other day that suggested that the Prime Minister should not make a $38 billion mistake. There were those of us who scratched our heads and tried to work out how Coronation Hill was going to be worth $38 billion.
â€”Million?

â€”No, billion. It turned out, of course, that that is the value of the mining industry in Australia all up. The idea that in some way the whole of the mining industry in Australia is at risk because one decision is taken about one much smaller mine leaves me a bit cold. But the RAC has said that the direct net benefit of the Coronation Hill mine to the Australian economy is $82m. Furthermore, if mining had proceeded in accordance with the guidelines that were put up by the RAC, that benefit would have been reduced to an estimated value of $64m, which figure was arrived at by the Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics. So the kind of money we are talking about here goes nowhere near the billion dollar figures that are bandied around in this debate.

speech.para: Even this morning on commercial radio, according to the first report, the mining industry put the figure at $500m. By the time we got to the third news report, the figure was $10 billion. What the mining industry is doing on this occasion-and it is quite dangerous-is to hugely exaggerate the value of what would have been one relatively small goldmine, and that ought not to be done. When one considers the value of this area to the heritage of the local Aborigines-and I have quoted at length from what real independent experts have had to say about it-I do not think we can put a price on those beliefs. When I look at one of the great national treasures of Australia in Kakadu, I do not want to see it wrecked and ruined by the greed of anyone and, in particular, of Senator Parer and those opposite.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats strongly welcome the decision which the Government has made. Although we have some reservations about the reasons which lie behind that, we do not in any way question the sincerity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to his concern about Aboriginal beliefs. I would here and now totally dissociate the Democrats from the derision which Senator Parer a moment ago sought to heap upon the beliefs of some of the original Australians and which one of his former colleagues, Senator Stone, did in an article in the Australian Financial Review a few weeks ago.

speech.para: Three separate matters are at issue here: the exploitation of a non-renewable resource, the mining in a natural area in relation to a national park, and the exploitation of a site of cultural and religious significance to the Aboriginal people.

In relation to the first matter-the exploitation of a non-renewable resource-nothing indicates more vividly than the discussion which has surrounded this decision the fundamental flaw which lies at the basis of economic analysis of resource exploitation being carried on by the Government, the Opposition and, indeed, by most economic journalists in this country. This concerns the way in which the accounting methods fail to recognise the real world and have led, and continue to lead, to wrong conclusions about the benefits of resource exploitation.

Every company accountant knows that companies keep a capital and a cash flow account. Capital must be maintained or, to use the in term, sustainable. If expended, it appears in the accounts as a transfer from the capital to the cash flow account. Nationally, however, economists have developed a measure of cash flow-it is called the gross domestic product (GDP)-but have never developed a national capital account.

The economists' view of the world is one of infinite resources and, therefore, one in which it is unnecessary to keep national capital accounts. Essentially, according to this view, resources are indefinitely and infinitely renewable and/or there is no such thing as a non-renewable resource. This is the basis of the Government's and the Opposition's economic analysis. It does not accord with the real world and it does not accord with the most fundamental law of science-the second law of thermodynamics.

Proper national accounting would recognise that there is no such thing as developing a resource. This false notion is analogous to saying, `You are developing your bank account by taking money out of it'. In the case of Coronation Hill, the gold, platinum and palladium are capital assets. They will remain there as capital assets as long as they are not exploited. I use the word `exploited' repeatedly rather than the word `developed' for the reasons that I have just indicated.

talk.start.para: â€”That is like dying with your money in a bank. There are no pockets in a shroud.

â€”I would not expect Senator Crichton-Browne to understand this at all. If, in 50 years time, our grandchildren find an overwhelming need for these resources, they will still be there, probably even more precious than today. We cannot develop these resources, we can merely exploit them or transfer their value from the non-existent national capital account to the cash flow account or to the GDP. I interpolate here that Senator Parer mentioned earlier the exploitation which had already occurred at Coronation Hill, yet we find this country going down the gurgler. So much for the benefit which flows from exploiting non-renewable resources.

speech.para: The absence of a national capital account gives us the illusion-and I stress that word-of becoming more wealthy by exploiting these and other non-renewable resources. It is an illusion; it is a trick of the defective method of accounting which we practise which, in turn, is based on a falsehood in relation to our perceptions of the real world.

Secondly, Coronation Hill sits within the catchment area of the Alligator River system. It is upstream of the important wetlands of the existing Kakadu World Heritage area. The conservation movement has correctly held for many years that, in setting areas aside, natural boundaries such as catchment limits rather than arbitrary lines on maps should be used. Accordingly, it is argued that the whole of the Alligator River system should be within the Kakadu National Park.

Although I said I would resist assessment of value of natural areas based entirely on dollar values, real or imputed, from what I have already said such exercises should be a part of a comprehensive and realistic system of national economic accounting. The totality of the values of Kakadu are represented in the decision to declare it a World Heritage area. Part of this totality, and part only, can be represented in dollar terms. As such, damage to this dollar value would be shown in my suggested proper national accounting system as a debit against the claimed benefits of exploitation. An attempt to do this was made by the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC).

I do not think the RAC would claim its dollar assessment was a comprehensive one of all values or that its methodology was not open to criticism. Nonetheless the attempt to place a dollar value on certain aspects was correct, as is the implication of that exercise that if one is to exploit a non-renewable resource within environmentally sensitive areas, these assessed costs, the costs of environmental damage, must be offset against any claimed benefits. As everyone knows, that process very substantially reduces still further any claimed benefit from exploiting this non-renewable resource. Thus a proper accounting of the costs and benefits of mining Coronation Hill would show that the value of the resource was not gained by the act of exploitation but merely transferred from capital to cash flow and that in the process environmental costs were borne which together show that the act of exploiting this resource-and again I stress the words `exploiting this resource'-produces no benefit at all.

Finally, there is the matter of the mining and its considerable impact on the cultural and religious significance of the Jawoyn people. Very briefly, I say that here we totally dissociate ourselves from the lack of respect which has been shown by members and former members of the Opposition with regard to Aboriginal beliefs. We welcome at long last the fact that the Government has given some official recognition to the legitimacy of those beliefs and, in so doing, is seeking to protect the area of Coronation Hill.

speech.speaker: Vallentine Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to thank Senator Coulter for sharing his speaking time with me so that I can record a response to this historic decision by the Government on behalf of the Greens in Western Australia and on behalf of so many thousands of Australians who applaud and congratulate the Government for once having had the guts to do what is right. In particular I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and I rarely feel moved to do so-for standing firm on this issue, having listened to the wisdom of the Jawoyn people. I also congratulate the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, and their hard working staffers, for their untiring perseverance. I also applaud the efforts of countless Australians who have lobbied the Government to ensure that, finally, sanity prevailed on this issue.

speech.para: It is absolutely appropriate that Coronation Hill should be returned to Kakadu National Park and subsequently included in the World Heritage area. It is an absolutely right decision on two grounds-both cultural and environmental. While I support the Jawoyn people in their spiritual attachment to the area, and I am delighted at the outcome on their behalf, it must also be acknowledged that on environmental grounds alone, and quite separately, Coronation Hill should have been returned to Kakadu because it is an ecologically sensitive area and should not be subject to mining. The South Alligator River system would have been subject to contamination had mining been allowed, and this of course could have affected the entire wetlands system, the fundamental asset of Kakadu.

Contrary to some statements which have been made about the decision, the Resource Assessment Commission clearly questioned both the likely environmental and cultural effects of mining within the conservation zone. These factors were weighed up against the net benefit to the country from mining which was assessed by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics to be $63m. I believe that the mining industry should be charged under the Trade Practices Act for misleading advertising in relation to the outrageous claims it has been making. The mining industry should be wary of trying to portray this as a test case for all mining projects. Rather than trying to discredit the process by which the decision was made, the mining industry should learn from it and accept that even in hard economic times the community wants respect shown for social and environmental values.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Senator Vallentine, your allotted speaking time has expired.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”In the moments I have let me touch on matters which Senator Richardson raised. Let us get it clear from the outset. The decision, with respect-through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator Vallentine-was not as a result of commonsense prevailing; it was simply because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to be saved from the ignominy of being rolled in Cabinet and having his leadership undermined all the more. This is all about survival for Hawke-let us get that part clear to start with.

speech.para: There is a claim put that some of us do not believe in Bula. Frankly I do not want to get into that debate today because it is not germane to my contribution, but what I do bring into question is the matter of sickness country. Let me quote this to honourable senators:
Since its establishment the ASSPA-
the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority-

has only extended registration and protection to individual sites or site complexes. It has never afforded protection to the `Sickness Country' despite its unfettered opportunity to do. It was only in 1987 that the current concept of `Sickness Country' was first raised by David Cooper, an officer of the ASSPA (and perpetuated without question by the Josif Report). Far more qualified researchers in work published over a period of twenty years failed to record or support any of the claims now being made by Cooper and Josif. Based on its consultations with its nominated custodians and in accord with their (recorded) instructions the ASSPA has in fact given a number of formal approvals for work to be carried out on Coronation Hill. Only one nominated custodian, Peter Jatbula, has ever had any consistent reservations about work on the area. All other nominated custodians and senior Jawoyn leaders have expressed support for the proposal.

Senator Collins, a Minister of this Government, brings into question the integrity of the argument in respect of sickness country. I seek leave to table a map which shows three different boundaries for sickness country. They keep changing the goal posts as the exploration goes on.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Senate. I want to touch on one other matter that was raised by Senator Richardson. I am not questioning Dr Francesca Merlan's integrity. I am questioning the compromising situation she has been put in. She was responsible when working for the Jawoyn people to identify and have sacred sites registered. She then worked for the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority checking the validity of her own work. Then she worked for the Northern Territory Land Council when it was debating the question of whether the Aboriginal community was entitled to a land claim. If that is not compromising, I do not know what it is, Senator Vallentine. I regret that I have only five minutes in which to complete my speech. I think it is absolutely impossible to get any sort of responsible judgments made as a result of those matters.

speech.para: Can I just quickly go to a number of other matters. Firstly, I refer to a document that was prepared by Senator Collins himself. I want to go to this question of whether or not the Aboriginal community support mining. Senator Collins said:

It is acknowledged that Nipper Brown is the only person still alive who has attended what appears to have been the last Bula ceremony. He attended that ceremony as a boy of fifteen in about 1940. All evidence indicates that it has never been performed since. On his own evidence Nipper has no personal knowledge now of any of the Bula songs or ceremony and all other persons related to that ceremony are now dead.
I asked, Mr Ellis, the Director of the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority, some questions under oath. The transcript reads as follows:

talk.start.para: â€”Does the Authority think that Coronation Hill is a Bula site?

speech.para: Mr Ellis-No, it believes it to be a sacred site.
And further, I said:
One hears of Nipper Brown whose caveat ultimately on mining on Coronation Hill was whether a Bula site could be identified on Coronation Hill.
The transcript continued:
Mr Ellis-The last time I spoke to him, his concern was whether he would get any money.

talk.start.para: â€”Why do you say that?

speech.para: Mr Ellis-That is what he said to me. The last time I spoke to him, the issue of whether to go ahead with exploration was in terms of whether they would get any money.

talk.start.para: â€”So he is not worried about sacred sites? Are you putting him down?

speech.para: Mr Ellis-No. I was referring specifically to Coronation Hill.

talk.start.para: â€”So he does not have a problem with mining on Coronation Hill?

speech.para: Mr Ellis-No, nor does his wife . . .

When I asked whether there are any custodians who do object, he said, `Few'. I asked, `What about the majority?'. He said that they have no objection to mining on Coronation Hill. It is not without significance to note that the application to make Coronation Hill a sacred site was allegedly signed by Nipper Brown, Sandy Barraway and Peter Jatbula. I asked those people individually, `Have you ever or do you ever remember signing an application form for Coronation Hill to be a sacred site?' They replied, `No. Never. Nothing. It is free'. In this respect, the transcript reads:

talk.start.para: â€”Have you ever thought of Coronation Hill as a sacred site?

speech.para: Sandy Barraway-No.

talk.start.para: â€”There is no Bula on Coronation Hill?

speech.para: Nipper Brown-Nothing.

talk.start.para: â€”So the Coronation Hill area is not a sacred sites area?

speech.para: Nipper Brown-Nothing. It is free.

talk.start.para: â€”Did some people make a mistake and think Coronation Hill was a sacred site?

speech.para: Nipper Brown-It is free.

The irrefutable evidence, which was given under oath by the custodians, the Jawoyn people, is categorically, without qualification, that they do not believe it is a site of significance, a sacred site or a site that presents any barrier or bar to mining; yet we now have the Prime Minister telling Australia that we shall not have mining at Coronation Hill because of the concerns of Aboriginal people. He knows that the truth is that it is a phoney excuse. Senator Collins has been asked on numerous occasions whether he supports mining on Coronation Hill. I do not have time to quote from what he has said, but his answer has been, `Yes, without question'.

The truth of the matter is that this Government finds itself seeking to prop up a failed and failing Prime Minister. The price that this country has to pay for this is $500m of export earnings simply to keep Bob Hawke in The Lodge. This has nothing to do with realities, economic decisions, the Jawoyn people or the environment; it is all to do with keeping Bob Hawke in his job. As Senator Graham Richardson himself said in Cabinet last night, `We have to go along with you to save you. Don't you know that the vote is 12 : 8 against you? The truth of the matter is that we will stick with you, even though it is a wrong decision, simply because we cannot afford to damage you any more and roll you. Therefore, we will compromise ourselves, this country, the taxpayers, the company and vote in a way which we know is an aberration of reality and truth'. Is it not sad--

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”I just want to speak very briefly in this debate and, in doing so, I wish to put the record straight with respect to a number of points that have so far been made. I am glad that Senator Crichton-Browne is here at the moment. He asked me a question yesterday on the Jawoyn people's approval of exploration and mining in some other parts of their territory. The inference of the question was that in their agreements they had agreed to mine on sickness country.

speech.para: I refer Senator Crichton-Browne to a press statement put out yesterday, I believe, by Poseidon Exploration Ltd and the Northern Land Council. They put out this press statement in order to clarify `a misunderstanding that appears to have surfaced regarding exploration licence applications in south-west Arnhem Land'. The statement, which is essentially one paragraph, reads:

The terms and conditions of the proposed exploration agreement between the Northern Land Council and the joint venture involving Poseidon Exploration Ltd preclude exploration on any area of exploration licence 6354 which may fall within what is known as the sickness country.

I put that on the record. It is a statement from both the exploration company and the Northern Land Council. No matter how much the Opposition wants to maintain a framework of misinformation and disinformation on this, there are some undisputable facts about this debate. The real task of government is to make decisions.

talk.start.para: â€”That is a back-off: it is a change.
â€”Senator Crichton-Browne has had his go. Would he mind just letting me get my nine minutes in from now on? Then all those opposite can enjoy themselves.
â€”Order! There are too many interjections from the left.

â€”The basic thing we must remember about the area we are talking about is that Coronation Hill is a registered sacred site under Northern Territory legislation. It has been so registered since October 1985. There are also within that conservation zone area a number of other registered sacred sites. In addition, there has been an application to register the sickness country as a sacred site.

speech.para: The first point I make is that we have this degree of disinformation, but also ignorance, on the part of the Opposition with respect to the latter point on the sickness country. It is stated that it is only a recent invention and that it has only been in the last five or 10 years that the sickness country has evolved as a concept. To highlight that degree of ignorance, we have the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, saying on 17 May:
But if you know anything about Aboriginal heritage, Bula didn't exist 10 years ago.

No more ignorant a statement could be made on the issues involved than Dr Hewson's statement. It shows once again that he lacks the capacity, the intelligence and the application to become a successful leader in this country.
The basic point is that as long ago as 1962 the concept of sickness country in this area was recognised. It is documented and it has been recognised by the Stewart report. That cannot be denied.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 4.00 p.m., because of the order agreed to earlier today, the Senate should now return to the motion by Senator Hill for the reference of a matter to a committee. I suggest that, with the concurrence of the Senate, the debate on the matter of public importance be concluded first, and we then proceed to Senator Hill's motion. That being agreed, I defer that matter and call Senator Bolkus to continue with his speech.

â€”I make the point that the concept of sickness country has been established for a long time. But I also make the point that for the last 45 years or so, anthropological evidence has been documented and white people have written about the Jawoyn people and their belief in Bula. Over that period there has been one consistent factor and that is a recognition of sacred sites within that conservation zone area. To provide evidence for that, I will quote what Justice Stewart says in his Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) final report at 7126, because there is nothing more definite than what he says:

speech.para: The Bula tradition is not a modern invention. The concepts of the Sickness Country and multiple Bula sites occur in the first anthropological records of the area, which date back to the early 1950s. Subsequent records are scant, but persistent. By the early 1980s Bula's presence and influence is recorded by anthropological observers as connecting focal sites by a network of sensory links and as having spheres of influence of up to 10 kilometres around important Bula sites.

The other thing one cannot deny in relation to the conservation zone is that it is littered with archaeological sites of-to use the jargon of the trade-top cohort quality. There is no doubt in the eyes of the independent assessor, Mr Justice Stewart, that what we do have here is not only a sacred site but also sickness country and, as a consequence, the conservation zone is a sacred site. That is in his report. We also indisputably have the fact that the belief in Bula has been documented, acknowledged and respected for more than four decades.

What the law of this country does and what the law of country has been recognised and respected internationally as doing, is to recognise that the basic part of Aboriginal religion is its interwoven links with the land. There are a whole host of quotes I can go to in terms of the importance of that link with the land. Their religion lies in their land. We cannot in this place say to them, as others have tried to say, that we just do not believe that this concept is real. There is nothing more patronising than that, nothing more paternalistic and nothing more discriminatory.

I find the points of view that have been put forward by the mining industry extremely offensive. Mr Quinn, who sees himself as some sort of cavalier in this particular issue, with what is nothing more than a paternalistic and arrogant attitude stated on 13 May:
If Aboriginals and their culture are to survive they must come to terms with the twentieth century.

One just cannot dictate to people what they should do with their religion. White people's religions evolve and change but there are some basic precepts and beliefs that have not changed to accommodate the twentieth century. Why should we demand of this group of people that they conform to white man's law and white man's religion?

It goes even further than that. The degree of disregard for these people and their rights is just astounding. For what reason? What is at stake here? What we are being asked to sell out is Aboriginal religion. We are asked to do it for the price of one packet of cigarettes per Australian. That is all we are on about. Justice Stewart, an independent arbitrator, was asked by the Government under legislation passed by this place to inquire into the validity of the Aboriginal beliefs and the need or otherwise to protect them. He makes the point very clear in an economic assessment based on the practice of economists from the Industry Commission across the board. He goes to the net present value and the net present value of the mine was documented by him at $82m.

Once we take out of that figure the cost of monitoring and the other costs that would have to be involved in back filling, which would have had to be incurred by the joint venture, the price goes down to $63.9m, with a net return to the mining company of $14.4m. It is less than the price of a packet of cigarettes per head of the Australian population. We have been asked to sell out what these people believe in for that.

This Government is not going to be stood over by fallacious arguments, by mythology and by the sorts of fabrications and ignorance that are perpetuated on the other side. We are on this side of the chamber because we make rational assessments. In coming to our assessment on this issue, we took into account the threat of a capital strike. Two or three years ago everyone in this place talked about how international capital would flow out of Australia because of our deferral of this particular decision. A couple of things have changed over the last few years. In respect of this mine, the joint venture structure, there has not been a flood of capital out of the country. There has been a 23 per cent increase in foreign interest in this particular venture. If there is a buck to be made the mining companies will make it, and good luck to them. Let us not deny that. The assertion that we are threatened with a $38 billion disaster, as has been put forward in the newspapers recently, is fallacious, intimidatory and dictatorial. The mining company took its case to Justice Stewart. It had it assessed and re-assessed and it was rejected. CRA Ltd is on the record and documented in paragraph 6.43 of the RAC report as saying:

If a mineral exploration company chooses to explore an area which has high conservation-or other-values, it does so in the knowledge that finding a mineral deposit will not mean that it can expect automatic approval to develop a deposit. A company has to be prepared to bear that risk. If it fails to get approval, the company sustains the loss-not the public.

So be it. This Government was not prepared to set aside these people's beliefs for the price of a packet of cigarettes. We are proud of this decision. It will go down as one of the best decisions that this Government has taken. It highlights the difference between those on the Government side of the chamber and those on the other side. Those opposite are concerned about dollars and cents. We are also, but we are concerned about people and their beliefs as well.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Parer's matter of public importance focuses on three points: firstly, the price we have had to pay for the hostage of the Left by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); secondly, the broken promises of the Prime Minister that will cost the nation millions of dollars and thousands of jobs; and, thirdly, the fact that the Prime Minister is destroying opportunities for the Jawoyn people. Consider how yesterday's Cabinet meeting was written up in the Age this morning:

speech.para: Bordering on tears, Mr Hawke made a highly emotional speech to ministers, accusing the mining companies of supremist attitudes and said no one could question his integrity on Aboriginal issues.

. . . Senator Richardson, declared during the meeting that Mr Hawke obviously did not have the numbers. But it was important that the Prime Minister's position was carried because he had publicly declared his attitude on Monday.

The Prime Minister won not on the arguments but because his Ministers could not afford to dump him. What a load of opportunism and lost opportunities for Australia. The conniving between so many different groups and people who have worked on this is absolutely phenomenal to consider. The consequences to the economy and to the Northern Territory need to be considered: $500m in today's dollars; 180 direct jobs and 150 indirect jobs, plus, of course, the operating expenditure for fuels, services and supplies that would flow on everywhere; and an increase in Northern Territory employment of at least 3 per cent. They are important issues.

Other speakers today have focused on some of the Aboriginal issues. In no way do I share the patronising attitudes of so many of these people. Aboriginal culture is not static; it is flexible and it is capable of change. We do not have to cocoon people into the nineteenth century. It is very important that Aborigines can reconcile mining with spirituality. We should look at Ranger, Gove and Groote Eylandt. People and cultures do change, and this was pointed out in the Resource Assessment Commission report. The Prime Minister's stance has now jeopardised the potential for hundreds of other projects and joint ventures for many Aborigines throughout Australia.
In effect, they are trying to bypass so many other areas. What about the Constitution of Australia? Section 116 states:

The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion, and no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.
One of my constituents wrote to me today pointing that out and pointing out the inconsistency of the approach taken by the Prime Minister on this issue. She said:

Whether this fundamental basic right is breached in favour of the Jawoyn people or any other religious concern above the national interest, ie, the benefit of all the people of Australia, we will have lost forever our Australia.

The Prime Minister has shown that he is very capable of cheating, lying, scheming, compromising and ratting on his words and commitments; he has done so over and over again. For example, in this decision he relied on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Interim Protection Act. Let us go back to the second reading speech of that Act and what the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, said when introducing it in 1984. He said:

I must make it clear from the outset that this is not interim land rights legislation nor is it intended to be an alternative to land claim procedures. I will not be making declarations with respect to vast areas of land in de facto recognition of a claim which Aboriginals may wish to make later under another law.
Further, he said:
In practice the Commonwealth sees this as legislation to be used as a last resort.

That is the commitment that the Government made and the Prime Minister has now broken. What did the Prime Minister, Mr Kerin and Senator Richardson say when the Resource Assessment Commission was established? They said that the Commission would be established not to look into individual projects but to concern itself with broad policy-making on industry matters. Out of the window-not considered. Instead: get in and focus on just doing the bidding of the Prime Minister-how to achieve it-and come back to rely totally on his particular area.

The Conservation Foundation of Australia has shown itself to be both opportunistic and cynical. One only has to look at the press statement it put out yesterday with regard to how it sees the hidden agenda as being the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Federal Conference in Hobart next week to see that. The Conservation Foundation wants to put the ALP under intense pressure to oppose the freeing up of uranium mining and this decision is importantly linked to that.

The decision goes against a majority of economic Ministers in the Cabinet. We know that; it has been quite public. Hawke had to cry his way out of this one. Perhaps the opportunism of the ALP was best illustrated in the quote from Senator Collins which I used here several weeks ago, `A Greenie in the hand is worth two gold bars in the bush'. Senator Collins came into this chamber and acknowledged that he had made that statement.

Unfortunately, Senator Collins, as President of the ALP in the Northern Territory and as a Northern Territory senator, has been sold down the drain on this issue and totally compromised. It is the lost opportunities for jobs and boosts to the Northern Territory and the national economy that are important. Unfortunately, Senator Collins has failed on these counts just as much as the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) and Senator Bolkus from the Left, who have screwed the Prime Minister to the wall and thrown every bit of punching bag that they could to weasel this decision out of him, have failed. It is against the national interests, the interests of future generations of Australians and, in particular, the Jawoyn and other Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The discussion is concluded.

debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

speech.speaker: Coates Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I asked that this matter be adjourned this morning to enable a chance for consultation to take place-the consultation that did not happen before the altered proposed reference of this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

speech.para: I re-emphasise that we have a system of eight standing committees, to each of which particular portfolios of government administration have been allocated. Issues concerning the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are relevant to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Anything in that area-whether it be related to the Department, a statutory authority or any other body associated with that portfolio-ought, by definition, to be dealt with by that Committee. It is the only sensible and efficient way of dealing with things. If there is a reason for something to be referred to a committee, I suggest that it ought to go to the appropriate committee.

The main part of the motion proposed by Senator Hill is about whether the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests, and then it adds on four items that the Department should particularly have regard to. Frankly, I find it embarrassing as the Chair of the Finance and Public Administration Committee-which has Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury, and Finance portfolios within its responsibilities-to deal with foreign affairs and trade, which colleagues in another committee have the main expertise and interest in and who ought to have the relationship with the Department and other agencies. I believe very strongly that if there is something in this area to be referred to a committee, then it ought to be referred to the relevant committee and there ought to be no doubt about which is the relevant committee on this occasion.

This morning Senator Evans gave some very cogent reasons about why there was no need at all to refer the matter to a committee. His arguments were very convincing to me, but I am happy to leave him to have made those arguments. I merely want to make sure that, if there is to be such a reference, it be to the appropriate committee. In any case, I have circulated in the chamber an amendment which I propose to move to seek to modify Senator Hill's motion to recognise that the Senate has already set up a procedure for investigating and monitoring the activities and operations of departments and agencies of the Government. That is the process of formal referral of annual reports of departments and other bodies to committees for their consideration.

When committees get those reports, they can look at them in a variety of ways. One of those ways can be to have a public hearing and to call officers before the committee to examine particular aspects of the annual report or to focus on parts of the annual report that bring up issues of interest, such as items (a), (b), (c) and (d) in Senate Hill's motion. So the process is already there. That sort of thing could happen when the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade annual report is tabled sometime after 30 June, in any case. If the Senate wishes to give some guidance to a committee as to the extent of its examination of a particular annual report, let that be as well. That is what I am suggesting we should do in this case. I move:

Omit ``the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report:'', substitute: ``when the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade considers the 1990-91 annual report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in accordance with the resolution of the Senate of 14 December 1989, it pay particular attention to:''.

The remainder of Senator Hill's motion would stand, setting out the sorts of things that he wishes the Committee to look at. I see no problem with that happening within the program of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade if its members wish and, as is suggested by Senator Hill, to have a public hearing, call in the relevant officers, and even go to the extent of advertising for submissions. Senator Hill ought to acknowledge that there should be some credence given to the ability of a committee to run its program of hearings and to mesh in this particular proposal with its other work. That, of course, can quite easily be done under the referral of annual reports procedures, as I suggest.

I have to emphasise, as I did this morning, the issue of the workload of both the Finance and Public Administration Committee and the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee. I am speaking here of not just the workload of committee members themselves but also of the committee secretariats which work particularly hard looking at annual reports, dealing with Bills referred to their committees and handling major references which are already part of their responsibilities and which have been given to them by the Senate. The Finance and Public Administration Committee, for instance, is in the midst of a major inquiry into the Ombudsman and that inquiry ought to have priority.

In earlier years, I can recall being in a situation where the Committee was absolutely and totally overloaded with work. This meant that it was not possible for any of us to do with any degree of satisfaction any of the jobs that had been given to us. I certainly do not want to get back into the position of feeling that the whole operation of the Committee was out of control because far too much work was loaded onto us. I guess I speak on behalf of Senator Maguire, who chairs the Foreign Affairs Committee, in suggesting that the load of that Committee is also high. It already has major references before it.

So I urge the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to give serious consideration to supporting my amendment, which I believe is a very sensible attempt to acknowledge the sorts of things that Senator Hill wants to have examined by the Finance and Public Administration Committee but, at the same time, recognises the existing processes and does not seek to load additional work onto the wrong committee.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has built up a strong reputation for the evaluation of administrative performance. Therefore, it is not surprising that the Senate has shown its confidence in this Committee's ability to conduct an investigation into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am not surprised to find opposition from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, given the wide range of very critical Auditor-General's comments that have been directed at this Department. In fact, I remind the Senate that at a recent conference in Darwin, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was castigated by David Shand-a former Department of Finance officer who is now working for the Queensland Government-for not pursuing a number of concerns.

speech.para: I will give one example as a background to the need for such an inquiry. Ten million dollars was expended by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on an overseas accounting system which was undertaken contrary to the advice given to the Department. This $10m project was subsequently abandoned without trace. This is just not good enough. It is a not good enough discharge of responsibility by a major department of state to expend such a large amount of money contrary to advice and then abandon it.

I draw the Senate's attention to a wide number of Australian National Audit Office reports on this Department, all of which were critical. Since the major inquiry of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman is drawing to a conclusion, I believe that the planning schedule should enable the Committee to accommodate the reference, although I admit it may be desirable to second the services of an officer from an area such as the executive development scheme or from the Department of the Parliamentary Library in order that the reasonably heavy legislative program evaluations, in the number of references of Bills to the Finance and Public Administration Committee, are not impeded.

Senator Coates mentioned that the process could be accommodated within the framework of committee appraisals of annual reports processes. The issues that have been put before the Senate are far greater than the coverage envisaged within that evaluation. I have spoken to my Opposition colleagues who served with me on the Committee and they are happy to pursue that inquiry. At the same time, they reject the amendment that is currently before the Senate. We therefore have great pleasure in endorsing the original motion moved by our leader, Senator Hill, who has great expertise in the area of foreign affairs and whose concerns are reflected in this motion.

I remind the Senate that Opposition senators are used to hard work. We are keen to fulfil the wishes of the Senate and, in doing so, to discharge in a proper and professional manner our own senatorial responsibilities.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen R.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I will be brief, but I think there are some important questions about the manner in which legislative and general purpose committees should operate and the priorities which should be set that relate to this matter. I want to make some general points about that and some specific points about this motion in supporting Senator Coates's amendment. I will not go to the general questions addressed in the motion about the overall merits of having such an inquiry. They have been adequately addressed by Senator Gareth Evans, and the arithmetic of his cogent arguments is clear, so I will not waste the time of the Senate on that, as we are all busy.

speech.para: I want to make one comment about why I believe Senator Coates is correct and that it is more appropriate that this should go to the legislative and general purpose committee relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I believe that one of the very important things we should be seeking to have those committees do is develop a more comprehensive and effective familiarity with all the activities and functions of the departments for which they have policy responsibility-in this case, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

There are many references I could refer to, but let me quote from pages 66 and 67 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-a very appropriate authority in this particular debate-when it reported on Estimates committee documentation and procedures. The report said:

It is widely agreed that the Senate standing legislative and general purpose committees have some responsibility for review of the performance of agencies. This responsibility was given additional weight by a resolution of the Senate of 14 December 1989 requiring the standing committees to review all annual reports.
It went on to say:
The Committee believes that the Senate's resolution on annual reports acknowledges a need for the standing committees to be more systematic in their review of the performance of public agencies.

That is the general principle. There is a lot that could be said about it but, in the time available, essentially that is the first point that I want to put on the record. Secondly, this matter raises four specific points with regard to the procedures and operations of the Department; but all of those are particular subparts of a reference with regard to whether that Department is fulfilling its role to protect and advance Australia's foreign policy interests.

There is only one committee given the responsibility by this Senate to look at whether particular activities of any aspect of government, Australian society or broader issues relate to the protection and advancement of Australia's foreign policy interests, and obviously that is the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. To illustrate that, I remind the Senate of two similar inquiries that have been conducted into the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, subparts of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. They were conducted by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-comprehensively and adequately, as they should have been. The general principle about where this should go, the specific point, as it relates to this report, and the precedents all indicate that Senator Coates's amendment is the superior proposal before us.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen R.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to support the motion which has been moved by Senator Hill; therefore, I find it very hard to support the amendment which Senator Coates has moved. I will briefly comment on the background to Senator Coates's amendment. It seems to me that there is a disposition in the Senate that there should be a comprehensive review of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The question is whether that investigation should be carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration or the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Basically, this Senate is asking for a comprehensive review. In my view, the comprehensive review would involve the same amount of time-and, presumably, the same amount of work-by either Committee.

speech.para: The device of Senator Coates's amendment to use the annual report to try to swing this back to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs is just that-a device; because, in reality, if the wishes of the Senate are adhered to, there will have to be a very comprehensive review by either Committee. Senator Coates has drawn our attention to the fact that the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs also has a very busy program. He mentioned that that was the view of Senator Maguire, the Chairman of that Committee. We take that on board.

Senator Coates was quite right to draw to the attention of the chamber that our own Committee also has a heavy program. As a member of that Committee with Senator Coates, I do not shirk from the responsibility involved in standing committee work. I assure Senator Coates-and I am sure that my colleagues will do this-that we would be more than happy to make the time available to ensure that a comprehensive inquiry into this is carried out.

talk.start.para: â€”Do you think I would shirk if there was a finance reference?

â€”If Senator Coates reads the terms of reference involved in this motion, he will find that it is involved with issues which relate to finance, administration and valuation which are very relevant to the work of our Committee. The Senate wants a comprehensive report, and it has to decide which Committee should carry out that comprehensive report. We have two busy committees-both Chairmen say that. I speak as a member of one Committee and, whereas I accept what Senator Coates says about the work program of the Committee, I would like Senator Coates to understand that we on this side of the chamber certainly will make time available to carry out this very important investigation on behalf of the Senate.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish briefly to address the amendment moved by Senator Coates and then close the debate by responding to a few of the matters raised by Senator Evans this morning. I did not speak in the debate this morning because in December, when I first put this motion down, I put with it the reasons for the proposed reference and I therefore believe it unwise, within the time constraints of the last few days of this session, for me to repeat those matters. It seems to me that two issues arise out of Senator Coates's amendment. The first is the question of the more appropriate committee to take this task upon itself, and the second is the means by which Senator Coates is seeking to restructure the reference under the head of an examination of the annual report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT)-and I will deal with both of those matters.

speech.para: If I can deal with the question of the more appropriate committee first, I have to accept that that matter is arguable. I could not but do that, seeing that when I put the motion down in December of last year I was in fact suggesting that it go to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. However, it seems to me on reflection that, on balance, the reference, particularly in its amended form which moves it away from specific allegations of malpractice and financial irregularity within the Department, and the matters that are or would be the subject of the inquiry, are more appropriate to the Committee on Finance and Public Administration rather than relating specifically to foreign affairs issues.

When I look around to see my colleague Senator Watson and consider his particular skills and record, I would have to say, without any disrespect to anyone else in the chamber, the key part of this reference being aspects of the management systems and program evaluation procedures within the Department, that I cannot think of a more appropriate person to be addressing those very important issues. On balance, it seemed to me that the more appropriate committee was the one with the skills and expertise to deal with these general issues of departmental structure and the type of systems that can best meet efficiency requirements. Therefore, I settled for the department which is in the terms of my amendment earlier today, rather than the portfolio Department.

There is also the issue of the attempt to change the reference to deal with it under the head of an annual report, and I have to say to Senator Coates that I think that would be inappropriate also. References to and considerations of annual reports have been limited to the year in question covered by the annual report and, in my experience anyway, matters that have arisen out of the annual report. What we are concerned with in this inquiry is an ongoing series of difficulties within the Department that do not relate just to this year. The questions of the shortcomings of the systems that have allowed financial irregularities for a long time have been around well beyond the year in question. The problem arising from the lack of or inadequate security mechanisms with documents and the international embarrassment that has been caused to Australia as a result goes well beyond the year in question. Therefore, attempting to amend the reference to deal with it under the head of an annual report seems to me to be inappropriate.

I would not want Senator Coates to believe that we are, therefore, of the opinion that every other reference that deals with matters arising out of the management of a department should also go to his Committee. Several notices of motion were given by the Australian Democrats this morning that will obviously have to be addressed carefully and the same test applied to them as I have sought to apply to this one. One notice of motion moved this morning dealt in particular with FM radio questions. It might be that that matter is more appropriate for a specific committee other than his, but I am not giving a commitment now because it has to go through the full party procedures.

The only other point I make in addressing Senator Coates's speech this morning is that whilst I do not know that I need a lecture on courtesy from him, I do appreciate that I should have informed him last night. I regret that I did not. I plead simply the pressure of business. Therefore, we will not support the amendment.

I will deal briefly with the matters that were raised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, that go to the substance of the issue. The Minister should not be afraid of parliamentary scrutiny as he seemed to be this morning. I also say that the capacity to inquire within the structure of Estimates committees is somewhat limited. The issues that we are seeking to pursue within this inquiry are really inappropriate to the Estimates committee mechanism.

In fact, the decision to seek the reference has in part come from our experience of being unable to get to the bottom of the issues that concern the management systems within the Department. There is the inability of the Department to formulate proper program evaluation procedures that deal with the Estimates Committee being unable to get to the bottom of why these leaks of sensitive information are continuing, despite the Minister's assurances that everything possible is being done. It is these failures of the Estimates Committee to produce the answers that we require that, in part, has led us to believe that the only way to get to the bottom of these issues is by a more in-depth inquiry, and that the appropriate mechanism for that is a standing committee.

We know that extensive financial irregularities have been disclosed within the Department for some time. I am pleased to say that it seems that those that have been disclosed have now been largely answered. What we do not know is whether the Department's systems have now been changed in a way that will avoid a repetition of that embarrassment. That is the sort of inquiry that could be undertaken by this Committee. Similarly, in the wider area of management systems and evaluation procedures, it will be able to be examine in depth whether they are inadequate.

The Minister has been constantly defensive on this aspect. I remind the Senate that, when questioned in the Estimates Committee hearings in September 1990 as to whether there have been any independent or objective assessments of management and support, the head of the corporate management division claimed that the Department had just developed an external evaluation plan in which DFAT had invited the Department of Finance to participate.

To balance that-and from a more objective point of view-we had the advice of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO), which subsequently reported that DFAT had shown resistance to the implementation of stage 1 of program evaluation `and lack of understanding of and commitment to evaluation'. That was in the ANAO audit report No. 23, with which Senator Watson is probably very familiar. It was said that DFAT had found it difficult to get corporate commitment to the evaluation strategy and, consequently, general staff commitment. The ANAO concluded that DFAT has so far made very little progress with the evaluation strategy. The Minister's answer to that was that his Department was a policy department and policy departments should be treated differently.

It is Senator Coates's Committee which can best make the assessment on behalf of this parliamentary process as to whether the Minister's case has been made out or whether the case of ANAO is made out, and the Department should be treated in the same way as any other department.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is in fact long overdue for a substantial review of its structure and administrative efficiency. The last comprehensive review of the Department was in its former state, pre-amalgamation, which was back in 1978. It was conducted, I have to concede, by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. There has not been an external evaluation since. There have been some internal evaluations of particular aspects, but there has not been any evaluation in the post-amalgamation period, that is, since the Department of Trade and the Department of Foreign Affairs were brought together.

The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, which I am excluding really from this reference, has been examined in depth both by the Jackson Committee of Review on the Australian Overseas Aid Program in 1983 and by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in 1989. Austrade, of course, was subject to a major external review recently by management consultants McKinsey and Co. Inc., and that has now been brought within the Department also. The core administration of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not been subject to any such review, and I think it is time now for such outside scrutiny. A McKinsey type inquiry, I say in passing, might in fact be a better course of action. We did float that in the Estimates Committee but certainly the senior officers of the Department did not respond positively to the suggestion that it might be in their best interests to be subjected to a comprehensive outside professional evaluation. So we return to the mechanisms within our control, the committees of this Parliament.

For the Department 1990 was clearly a bad year. There were numerous allegations of maladministration, leaks of sensitive documents and claims of indifference to overseas conditions of service leading, regrettably, to industrial action. There were clear signs of morale and discipline falling. I see that personally from the number of representations I receive from officers within the Department-very genuine and well meaning people who are concerned by these various issues. In the supporting information to the motion I put in December last year I gave a sketch of details of a whole series of security leaks before that date.

In the Estimates Committee I have given details of some 12 very serious leaks between that Estimates Committee and this one on the Supplementary Estimates, and there have been at least five very serious and damaging leaks since then, despite the Minister's assurances that this was now going to change. I raised one in the Senate concerning the Australian Government's assessment of Singapore's involvement in Burma, which was so embarrassing to have leaked, and another concerning the Khmer Rouge and the fact that it was gaining benefit under the various plans. I will not detail them now because now is not the place. The place to put them is before the Standing Committee so it can examine them.

What is evident on the face of that is that there is not in existence at the moment a system which can adequately safeguard the highly sensitive information of the Department. Hopefully the Senate Standing Committee will be able to constructively help with that. As I indicated a moment ago, I have been told that morale has been affected by the ongoing problems, and one of those problems relates to conditions of service overseas. The overseas living allowance (OLA) system has been criticised for being non-transparent in the sense that no-one can give a proper explanation as to how various allowances for service overseas have been arrived at.

Senator Evans expressed the hope to the Estimates Committee in September 1990 that there could be a just and final outcome and proper processes in place for the future which are a bit more transparent and a bit more systematic than has been the case in the past, but as it has turned out the result is not to the satisfaction of staff. Subsequently Senator Evans said that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) had negotiated a package which was fair and balanced, though not as generous as ideally. He noted that staff at some posts accepted the packages while others did not.

What he failed to address, however, was the issue of transparency, which he had earlier stated to be the central issue. Staff feel that their salary and allowance packages are constantly rising and falling without any predictability or identifiable relationship to conditions at the post. The net result is that there is considerable dissatisfaction. Much of this dissatisfaction can be linked to the fact that the issue has dragged on for years with the Department apparently helpless to deal with such a major issue affecting its management and administrative performances.

The Department's annual report in 1986-87 recorded that OLA `failed to meet all the objectives set for it by the Public Service Board and operating departments'. The following year, the annual report was able to say that the Department of Industrial Relations agreed to address anomalies identified by internal review of OLA. And so the issue dragged on for four years before reaching its present position. It seems that, in that unsatisfactory situation, some outside body should look at OLA and, hopefully after the passage of this motion, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration will be able to do so.

Another aspect of the morale problems has arisen from the issues that have not been adequately addressed in and following the amalgamation of the departments. I am advised that the Foreign Affairs officers' (FAO) stream, which was a fundamental principle of departmental organisation from its establishment and the route to the top for most present senior departmental managers, was abolished to accommodate the amalgamation with the Department of Trade but it continues to influence the working of the Department. So there is a situation of confusion.

Positions were designated policy or administrative, partially reflecting the former distinction between the Foreign Affairs officer and consular-administrative streams. Former trade officers have fitted uneasily into this new structure. Officers not recruited via the FAO stream, whether from Trade or the former consular-administrative stream, often feel disadvantaged and threatened. The statement put to the Estimates Committee by the Department that there are people in the Department without the skills required now and required increasingly in the future alludes to this problem.

Officers spoke of the need for training or the possibility of early retirement packages. Attempts such as this to get rid of perceived troublemakers will not solve the fundamental problems that have given rise to them, and such issues arising out of the amalgamation that have not adequately met the concerns of officers of the Department can be looked at by this Senate Committee.

In summary, the notice of motion of 21 December, as subsequently amended, seeks to bring independent analysis and public scrutiny to the operations of DFAT in a way that will assist the Department to fulfil its charter in relation to the conduct of Australia's international relations. It seeks to look at the serious allegations and symptoms of poor morale within the general context of the management systems and program evaluation procedures of the Department. If the Department has already taken action to solve all of the problems that have been aired, which does not seem to be the case from what has been put before the Estimates Committee in any event, the Senate Standing Committee report can only help to restore confidence in the Department. If action has not been taken, the Committee can make recommendations to assist the solution of the problems facing the Department.

As I said at the outset, it is now 13 years since such a public inquiry has been made into DFAT and, bearing in mind both the major changes that the Department has undergone in recent years and the continuing signs of management and morale problems, an independent examination of the management and operation of the Department is long overdue.

I regret to say that the Minister has shown little interest in questions relating to the administration of the Department. Perhaps if he had been more interested and concerned with the terms and conditions of service of his officers, this inquiry may not have been necessary.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The report of the Administrative Review Council, entitled Review of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act: Statements of Reasons for Decisions, addresses the issue of what power the judicature should have in dealing with the Executive. The Executive and the judicature are two separate arms of government, the third being the Parliament.

The phrase `separation of powers' has an esoteric ring to it but describes a mechanism that is central to the well-being of the community. Chapters 1, 2 and 3 of the Constitution establish that mechanism by distributing the powers of government amongst the Parliament, the Executive and the judicature. When each of the three entities exercise distinct powers of government, there is a reasonable expectation that a happy balance will evolve: where none can harm any member of the community, all should serve. Unfortunately, imbalances keep arising which allow people to be damaged by the actions of one or more of the entities.

In recent times there has been much proper concern expressed about the way the dynamics at work among the arms of government have been markedly disturbed. Senator Peter Walsh turned his considerable mind to the issue in his article in the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, 18 June 1991, in which he points out that bodies such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Resource Assessment Commission, the Law Reform Commission, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and other such bodies have taken on work which was formerly done by parliamentarians. Senator Walsh, in doing that, has raised a central issue which we as a parliament should address. The fact is that for many years now Parliament has not exercised the restraint over the Executive that it formerly exercised. There have had to be other bodies set up to deal with that.
On the other hand, we have statements by Mr Justice Brennan of the High Court of Australia, a very eminent jurist, who says that in fact the Executive has now taken on too much power. He says:

As the wind of political expediency now chills Parliament's willingness to impose checks on the Executive and the Executive now has a large measure of control over legislation, the courts alone retain their original function of standing between government and the governed.
