He puts in a plea-if that is the way to put it-for the courts to have an ability to exercise a proper power over the Executive. Senator Walsh and Mr Justice Brennan are two of the many people now raising the issue of the proper relationship between the arms of government. It is an important issue, one that we ought to deal with more fully than we do and one which is addressed in this excellent report.

I note the list of people who are on the Administrative Review Council. Professor Cheryl Saunders is the President. I think they are to be congratulated not only on this work but also on the other work that they have produced. In saying that, it is not to be taken that I necessarily agree with all of the views that have been expressed by the Administrative Review Council in this report. It is proper that those views be discussed further with them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: â€”In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 32 of 1990-91-Department of Community Services and Health-Administration of the Medicare Benefits Schedule.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

We have had access to this report for two hours or so-maybe slightly more. This is an extensive and long report by the Auditor-General entitled Department of Community Services and Health- Administration of the Medicare Benefits Schedule. It should be noted on every occasion in this chamber when mention is made of the Medicare benefits schedule (MBS) that it is a myth perpetrated by those on the other side that the Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent of our incomes covers the cost of medical and hospital services. The message that needs to be put across over and over again is that the levy contributes only about one-third of the funding that is outlaid on Medicare programs. Anybody in the Australian community who thinks that their Medicare levy is paying for the medical expenses of this country is living in the land of--

talk.start.para: â€”Dreams.
â€”Thank you, Senator Knowles. I think I am hampered by the fact that I had only about three hours sleep last night.
â€”Not enough dreams.

â€”Yes, we have not had enough dreams! This report is in some ways a condemnation and it also indicates the head-in-the-sand attitude of the Department of Community Services and Health. It is a condemnation of both the administration of the Medicare benefits program and the lack of responsiveness by the Department to the recommendations made by the Auditor-General.

speech.para: It seems to me that this sort of thing is frequently experienced. When the Privacy Commissioner expressed concerns, the Government did not respond. Here is the Auditor-General expressing concerns, as he did with issues such as Telecom Australia, the system for social security and the matters that we raised yesterday. The Auditor-General has outlined a lack of care and attention to detail, which means that the taxpayer is paying the bill.

One of the things that this report has highlighted is that there has been a deterioration in the basis of how the fees are set. These fees have grown up across time a bit like Topsy and the Auditor-General is recommending that a standard methodology for establishing the value of schedule fees should be developed and that there should be a greater consistency and equity of fees between items in the MBS.

This report also points out that there has been quite a significant growth in Medicare benefit outlays. We all know that much of this growth can be attributed to a number of issues, such as the ageing of our population, greater dependence of our population on medication, the ease of access to medical advice and also the increased size of the population. The Auditor-General also points out that one of the contributing factors in the increased cost of medical services has been direct billing. In fact, he says that a significant proportion of this cost has been as a result of direct billing. The Auditor-General says on page 15 of this report:
It was noted by the ANAO that the areas with the highest growth in outlays are frequently those areas with a high proportion of direct billing.

We have a number of problems here. The Department has said that this is not necessarily the case. It has buried its head in the sand over this issue and says that the Auditor-General should have come up with much better figures and a much better method of examining the matter. It has been quite derogatory in some ways about the recommendation that this issue ought to be addressed. But there are a number of areas in regard to direct billing that ought to be addressed. A number of people are responsible. Firstly, the Government and the Department of Community Services and Health ought to be addressing it. Secondly, our medical profession has a responsibility to the Australian community not to abuse the system of direct billing. Also, we as citizens have a responsibility to realise that every time we go to the doctor and are direct billed our fellow taxpayer is contributing, since our Medicare levy does not cover the cost of our medical expenses.

The report signifies that there is a real need for a total review, a total analysis, and some very clear-headed thinking with regard to the cost of medical benefits to our population. We have seen an enormous growth in Medicare benefit outlays. The Auditor-General says that the cost of medical services to the patient has grown and the cost to the community has grown. If that cost has grown, we ought to have seen an improvement in public health; otherwise the cost increase is not justified. The Auditor-General says:

. . . the cost of medical services to the patient, as represented by the difference between provider charges and benefits received, increased from $295 million in 1985-86 to $668 million in 1988-89. In this period the patient contribution to the cost of medical services increased from 10% to 16%. A proportion of this higher cost can be recovered if patients have private health insurance but this is ultimately reflected in higher insurance premiums.

Given the current Government's policy, because of these increased costs and increased premiums and because of the myth that the Medicare levy covers the cost of our health care, in 1990, the Auditor-General says, only 43 per cent of the population has private insurance. Many of those are pensioners, people least able to afford it but who realise that they are the ones who are going to join the hospital waiting queues in every State. Many of them are taking out or keeping their health insurance and paying the higher premium.

The Auditor-General's report-as I said, we have not had time to go through it in absolute detail-has put the Department on notice that there are many areas that it can address and savings that can be made. Our Medicare benefit payments have increased from $2.6 billion in 1985-86 to $3.8 billion in 1989-90. We cannot afford that sort of escalation without a very serious review of how we can curb those costs and maintain an adequate and proper standard of public health.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer to the Auditor-General's report regarding the administration of the Medicare benefits schedule. The report highlights the need for a more systematic process for the review of items and fees in the Medicare benefits schedule. It recommends that improved information gathering systems and analytical techniques should be developed to provide early detection and timely implementation of required amendments to the schedule. It also points to the need to develop a strategic plan for a comprehensive and systematic review of sections of the schedule. The audit found that a variety of methods have been used to determine Medicare schedule fees and, in the absence of a standard methodology, there is no readily available measure to assess the consistency and equity of fees.

speech.para: Analysis of change to Medicare fees in recent years revealed that actions by medical practitioners had limited the effectiveness of measures to reduce Medicare outlays. It was also noted that reductions in scheduled fees have generally resulted in reduced observance of scheduled fees by medical practitioners and an increased contribution by patients towards the cost of medical services. Bulk-billing has been actively encouraged by the Government and has obviously been increasingly taken up by general practitioners.

It is fairly obvious that the 50 per cent increase in the number of doctors between 1980 and 1990-now 38,000 in Australia and increasing by 800 each year-has meant an oversupply of medical practitioners. This has been accentuated by the number of immigrant doctors now being registered. It is estimated that 350 medical graduates enter the country every year-the equivalent of the output of two Australian medical schools. This is to the detriment of the students wishing to go through our medical schools-Australian children, 30 per cent of whom are the children of immigrants. Australia now has the second lowest doctor-patient ratio in the world-second only to Belgium.

There is little doubt that this combination of oversupply and increased competition has led to an increase in the number of medical services being bulk-billed. Last week I received a letter from a friend of mine who is the Professor of Surgery at the University of California, Los Angeles, and a former President of the American Association of Surgeons. The letter states:

I intend to spend my spare time within the coming year demonstrating that we have about 20 per cent more physicians in the United States than we currently need. We made the mistake of opening our doors to tens of thousands of immigrant physicians. They haven't done any harm, have done no measurable good, and have cost us a bundle! Finally, about two years ago the government woke up and stopped the immigration entirely. It was contrary to our constitutional philosophy, but the cost became unbearable. I have some fascinating data which show that the cost per unit service (office visits/operations) is a straight line function of the number of doctors per 100,000 population. It is directly contrary to the law of supply and demand--

The average use of medical services per person in Australia has increased from 7.1 per cent to 8.8 per cent in the last five years-a 23 per cent increase. Senator Robert Ray may need some of that increase-if not my services-soon.

talk.start.para: â€”I am being inspired here. Keep it up.

â€”Thank you. The use of pathology and radiology has increased by 42 per cent per patient in the last five years. The Government has attempted to control the burgeoning cost by decreasing the refund on medical fees, particularly in pathology, and also by reducing the refund for in-patient procedures from 85 per cent to 75 per cent of the scheduled fee. This has resulted in an increasing gap between Medicare fees and Medicare refund. In fact, that gap has increased by 120 per cent in the last five years. Is it any wonder that people are complaining about this gap when they are forbidden by the law of this Government to insure themselves for it unless they are in-patients in a hospital?

speech.para: Paradoxically, the increasing cost of private hospital insurance has led to an increase of 100 per cent in insurance rates in the last five years which, in turn, has led to a fall in the number of people covered by private insurance from 70 per cent in 1983 to 43 per cent in 1991. My own State of Queensland has an insurance rate as low as 32 per cent. The Government does not seem to understand that for every one per cent of the population which opts out of private cover, $80m is added to the public sector cost per annum.

Finally, the direction in which Medicare is heading will mean that not only will Australia be a banana republic in economic terms, but also, with the rationing of health care, we will have good quality health care available only to those who can afford it, and lengthening queues for those who cannot. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.title:
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991
SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: â€”Neither the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 nor the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991, which are allied Bills, are earth shattering. With the exception of one matter, which we will be opposing at the committee stage, we support the two Bills. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 contains some relatively minor policy changes and allows for the amendments made to the 1947 Social Security Act during the current autumn sittings to be incorporated into the `plain English' Social Security Act.

speech.para: The proposal that we regard as most controversial and the one to which we are opposed, relates to those clauses which seek to change the eligibility criteria for special benefits, allowing them to be payable at the discretion of the Secretary of the Department to a person who is the holder of a conditional two-year residence permit, granted on the basis of a relationship with an Australian resident, where the application for that payment was made on or after 15 April 1991.

Under the recently introduced migration rules, as from 15 April this year a two-year conditional residence permit can be granted to a person who has entered into a formal marriage or a de facto relationship with an Australian citizen or resident. The proposed change would allow special benefits to be paid to such persons and, if necessary, backdated to the commencement date of the new rule. It must be presumed that applicants for such conditional entry permits and, indeed, the overwhelming proportion of migrants to this country, are able-bodied citizens who are entering Australia with adequate means of support. To allow newly arrived migrants immediately to receive social security income support sends precisely the wrong signal to prospective entrants.

Indeed, the way in which this clause is framed would enable people to come here under the guise of entering-or having entered-into a permanent relationship, be granted a conditional entry permit for the next two years, immediately receive special benefits, then dissolve the relationship, have the entry permit terminated and leave the premises, so to speak, having received welfare payments for the duration of that term of entry. That seems to us to be inherently unsound.

There is no justification for, in effect, inviting people to come to this country on, in a sense, a probationary basis. That is the whole purpose of denying them permanent entry status. They come here seeking to prove their bona fides-otherwise they are queue jumpers. It is proposed that we then should turn around and offer them welfare payments. We do not think that is adequate and, therefore, we propose that these clauses be removed.

There is even less justification for any retrospective operation. Whilst the Department may have promised such payments as from 1 April, it had no authority to do so. Presuming the new arrivals have survived financially to date, there is no justification for now providing them with a backdated lump sum payment.

The other changes involve the indexation of the maintenance income free area. That is an uncontroversial proposition. The measure will ensure that the allowable level of child support is not eroded over time by inflation. The indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance, which is to be indexed from the first pension or benefit payday after 20 September each year, does have very significant financial consequences because it involves an estimated annual cost in excess of $200m. Nonetheless, given the commitments that were made to pensioners in the context of the changes in the last Budget which replaced the pharmaceutical beneficiary charge, I think we would take the view it is proper that the amount of the allowance be indexed.

We support the changes to the pension portability provisions. The Bill adds further refinements to the restrictions on the portability of wives and class B widows' pensions which were put in place last year. Otherwise, we can have a situation-it exists presently-where people who have never resided in this country have married an Australian resident, who then dies, and then remain perhaps at their place of birth and continue to receive a widow's pension. We share the Government's view that in those circumstances those people should not be entitled to continuing welfare support. We therefore support that proposition.

The pharmaceutical benefits card eligibility is another measure that the Opposition supports. In the last Budget, pensioners were promised that they would not lose their entitlements to the pharmaceutical benefits card if, as a result of complying with the deeming arrangements, the rate of return on their savings took them above the designated savings threshold, which in respect of fringe benefits is currently $95 a week. As a result of the rearrangement of assets, the whole purpose of the exercise is that people will be pushed to a point where they are entitled to less pension moneys than they would otherwise have received, thus ensuring that they maximise their returns on their investments.

I pay tribute to my colleague, Senator Patterson, who has identified a transitional difficulty which I see the Government is now proposing to correct. That will honour the promise; so we will simply find that, as from March when the deeming legislation came into force, not only those people but also anyone who has rearranged their affairs as a result of the Budget announcement will be protected.

The Opposition accepts that the reciprocal social security arrangement with the Netherlands ought to be written into the Bill. That will, as it does in most other instances, bind other countries into paying pensions and benefits for their nationals residing in Australia. The agreement will result in an estimated net saving of almost $8m in the 1991-92 financial year.

There is one other matter to which I should advert at this stage and that is the provision which would exempt the Secretary's power to waive a debt from review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. This matter has had a somewhat chequered history. I think it is largely the responsibility of the Government that we have reached the situation where it has been necessary to spend a lot of time agonising over the meaning of the current provisions.

The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills took the view in 1988 that there was indeed not an ability in the Tribunal to override the power of the Minister to override the power of the Secretary, in effect, to vary or amend waiver arrangements. I think that has been the conventional wisdom and we certainly proceeded on that basis when considering earlier legislation only a couple of weeks ago.

In recent days I have been provided with some material, including a legal advice, which for the first time spells out that the Government believes it is still possible to interpret the provisions in such a way that the Tribunal would be able to override in respect of general waivers. We take the view that, whilst it is important for the Tribunal to retain the right to pass ultimate judgment on the circumstances of individual cases, it is not appropriate for the Tribunal, in effect, to second guess policy matters where the Minister has determined on a policy basis that certain categories or classes of people ought not to be entitled to the waiver. In those circumstances we believe that the decision of the Minister ought to be final and that the matter should not be able to be reviewed by the Tribunal. Therefore, we will not be opposing that provision. The rewrite Bill contains a number of propositions with which we do not agree, but I will not trouble the Senate further with any analysis.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talk.start.para: â€”These Bills originally entered the Senate as part of a package of three. The Australian Democrats are very pleased to note that, with the support of the Liberal Party, we have managed to move the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill off to a committee for further consideration; and, in particular, to give those people most affected by this Bill-that is, people with disabilities, their families and the groups representing them-time to look at all the implications of what is a very major change.

speech.para: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 implements minor policy changes and incorporates into the 1991 Social Security Act amendments made to the previous 1947 Act during the autumn session. I want to cover only a few of these changes this evening. Firstly, let us look at the provision of special benefits and the eligibility criteria: the Bill provides for special benefits to be payable to a person who is a holder of an extended eligibility or spouse entry permit under the Migration Act. Unfortunately, again there have been a lot of very strange ideas spread around about what these provisions actually mean. Firstly, I stress that it does not mean that people entering the country can stroll in at any time and, regardless of need or their financial or other circumstances, tap into our social security system.

Special benefit is a discretionary benefit. Essentially, it is a hardship provision. There are very stringent eligibility criteria that have to be met. It is a last resort for those people who have absolutely no other support service available-no other means of income support. People who have been granted conditional entry into this country should not be forced to starve on the streets. We have accepted these people into the country-the first step, hopefully, towards their becoming Australian citizens-and I do not think they should be excluded from this form of assistance, which is, as I said, their last hope.

Unfortunately, these provisions seem to have provided some people with the chance to severely criticise migrants, in particular. They have suggested, for example, that suddenly we will be flooded by hordes of people, realising what a wonderful social security system we have, rushing to Australia's shores. That is simply not accurate. Further information that I was able to obtain today shows that lawyers who work in this field stress that it is not easy to access special benefit; that the permit is in force for two years and this is a trial period; that the people must prove that they are genuinely seeking permanent residence; and that they must be in a permanent relationship and simply cannot get one of the entry permits if they are not.

Experienced legal practitioners in the immigration area will tell us of many cases where the partner of one of these permit holders or, indeed, the permit holder himself or herself fell ill, had a serious accident and-prior to the amendment we are looking at today-had no means of support, no income at all. A Sydney-based barrister told me that she had seen people in these circumstances who were so desperate they had spoken of suicide or of returning to their home country where they would be faced by persecution, simply because they could not get any income at all in Australia through circumstances that, I must stress, are no fault of theirs whatsoever. The amendments before us, which we commend to the Senate, are designed to pick up these sorts of very deserving cases-and I stress again that there are not many of them. There are not thousands of people; there are a small number of people to whom, if this amendment is defeated tonight, we will be denying access to any support at all, whether there are special circumstances or not.

A retrospective element identified in this Bill is a provision regarding a commencement date of 15 April. I understand, and I will ask the Minister later as we move into committee, that this is presumably because of the linkage with the changes in the migration regulations which were done on this date. Again, the Democrats do not generally consider retrospective elements to be desirable, but we see this example as not being of great concern. It was not of great concern to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It could perhaps be best described as a benign example and it will certainly not disadvantage anyone. So in these circumstances we will not be opposing this clause.

The Bill provides for the maintenance income areas for pensioners and beneficiaries to be indexed on 1 July each year. This refers to the amount of maintenance or child support people can receive before their pension or benefit is affected. I note with interest the Minister's answer to a question of mine today in Question Time where he assured us that the very unjust practice of limiting maintenance income to only $15 before the pension is affected, or $5 for each additional child, will be looked at. Hopefully, it will at least rise to the $40 income that is permissible from any other source. We would hope that the income levels would rise substantially to help to reduce the poverty traps that single parents are currently facing.

Similarly, the Bill contains provisions for the indexation of the pharmaceutical allowance. We also support this move, but feel obliged to point out yet again that the way the allowance is structured discriminates against married couples by providing them with the same amount of allowance as would be received by a single person. At the time this allowance was introduced last year, I made the point that this discrimination makes very little sense. It makes things extremely difficult, particularly for older married couples. We have had many letters from pensioner couples whose situation confirms this. Without much hope, I ask the Government to take another look at this problem-hopefully, it will be done in the Budget this year-and in particular to look at the problems of the really elderly people who are suffering, both of them in many cases, chronic illness or disability. The remainder of this Bill incorporates changes in the autumn session to the new Social Security Act, and the only problem we have here is with clause 20. We will be moving the same amendment as we moved a week or so previously to ensure that guidelines relating to the waiving of debts to the Department of Social Security are subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill contains no policy changes. It is basically a transitional piece of legislation to ensure that the new Act incorporates changes made in the 1990 Budget session. We have no problems with this Bill and will not be moving any amendments. I take this opportunity to comment briefly on two particular social security issues that are of concern. Firstly, referring to waiting periods, I would recommend as reading for those honourable senators who are concerned at the great difficulties being faced by the people suffering hardest from this recession that we had to have the recent Victorian Council of Social Service (VCOSS) report, No Reason to Wait for Social Security. This report urges the Government to abolish a variety of waiting periods: the one-week ordinary waiting period which, I might add, usually spreads out to at least three weeks before any support is given; the four-week liquid assets test waiting period; the 26-week wait for rent assistance; and, I note in particular, a reduction in the 13-week waiting period or the three months that education leavers under 21 must currently endure. I stress here that these are education leavers. They are not people dropping out for the sake of dropping out; they are those who have graduated and those who have, unfortunately, failed their course from colleges of technical and further education, universities or whatever.

The report identified waiting periods for social security benefits as a key factor in the increased demand for emergency relief and food vouchers. In response to this report, the Australian reported a spokesperson for the Minister as saying:
The Minister is aware of the concerns of . . . welfare groups and they will be considered seriously as part of the Budget.

But on 5 June when we were debating the Job Search and Newstart legislation in this chamber, the Minister expressly stated that he had decided not to raise the matter of education leaver waiting periods. Unfortunately, the Minister is not with us now, but I will certainly be asking him during the committee stage whether he will raise any of the waiting periods for Job Search and Newstart allowances discussed in the VCOSS report as part of the Budget discussions. I again note that the VCOSS report confirms that these waiting periods are causing hardship and increasing the demands on welfare agencies. Not only that, they are patently unfair and they further penalise people who are out of the work force because of this Government's economic policies.

The second area I wish to look at briefly tonight is income security for farming families. All those present in this chamber are well aware of the rural crisis. It was debated again last night as we looked at the wool legislation. I stress that sheep farmers are probably amongst the hardest hit of rural people. The enormous amount of hardship is both financial and social. The problem of providing appropriate and adequate income support to farming families this year is critical.

The United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia Inc. estimates that 80 per cent of farmers in South Australia will not make enough money this year to meet costs. In April, a senior official from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was reported in the Age as predicting:
There would be a serious social crisis in rural Australia by the middle of 1992, despite an expected pick-up in rural exports next year.

It is important to note that in the vast majority of cases the income crisis faced by farming families arises through no fault of their own. It is being caused by the unique coincidence of international and national conditions, many of which can be directly traced to the European Community and United States Government subsidies and other supports for their farmers.

An Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) study has found that farmers in Western countries received $383 billion in subsidies last year. That is as much as Australia's total gross domestic product. In fact, the OECD's monitoring of agricultural protection showed that the cost of subsidies soared by 12 per cent in 1990. This is at precisely the same time as the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks were supposed to be achieving a decrease but were achieving exactly the opposite. In Europe, government subsidies and other support to farmers jumped $105 billion, providing 48 per cent of farmers' incomes. In the United States, government subsidies and support for farmers provides 30 per cent of farm incomes; in Japan, it is 68 per cent.

The only two countries the OECD could find worthy of praise were Australia and New Zealand-the agricultural odd couple. Australia's support for farmers is now at 11 per cent and New Zealand's is down to 5 per cent. It seems that in every country other than Australia and New Zealand governments are persuaded by arguments that farming actually has a purpose greater than its substantial economic value; it has social and other benefits which deserve acknowledgment and protection.

Other governments around the world recognise the value of farmers, farming families and rural communities and support them. This is something that this Government and, unfortunately at times, this Opposition either cannot or will not recognise. The question of the appropriate way to support Australian farming families should be exercising all of our minds in the chamber at this very serious time. The question is: what is the appropriate way to assist farming families? Is it to provide income security for farmers through direct price support, through the rural adjustment scheme or through the means provided to all other Australians-that is, the social security system? This is the matter for debate and that debate must take place urgently.

Above all, it is our responsibility to provide certainty for rural families about their rights and their futures. Quite clearly it is not being done at the moment. In fact, the opposite is occurring. A letter from Mr Con Sciacca, the honourable member for Bowman and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, written to the State Association of Rural Counselling Services in South Australia, dated 6 May 1991, reads:

Social security was never intended to be a subsidy for uneconomic enterprises but a payment to those who are unable to earn a living because of unemployment, age, infirmity or family responsibilities. It is not an appropriate means of assisting farmers who still own considerable business assets but who are without an income or whose income is committed because of debt.

This quotation clearly lays the ground rules as far as the Department of Social Security (DSS) is concerned: farming families are not appropriate candidates for social security payments. That was on 6 May. Yet on 13 May the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and now Treasurer (Mr Kerin) encouraged farmers to apply for social security payments.I quote from in an article in the Australian on 13 May 1991:

Mr Kerin said yesterday that Cabinet confirmed on April 17, when funding to the Rural Adjustment Scheme was increased by $100 million to $164 million, that farmers were eligible for hardship provisions under the Social Security Act.
In particular, Mr Kerin referred to section 7 of the Act. The article stated:
Farmers who meet the other normal eligibility conditions may qualify for support under hardship provisions and may receive unemployment, sickness, or special benefits and pensions.
It went on:
To receive a social security payment, farmers must prove severe financial hardship by:
HAVING a total income less than the maximum fortnightly benefit applicable.
as that is about $243 currently, that is very easy for farmers to do-
SHOWING that readily available funds do not exceed $6,000 for a single person or $10,000 for a married couple.
again that is very easy to do-
EXHAUSTING all other possible avenues to improve their financial position.
There is a possible question mark there. Does that mean that they have to put the farm on the market? The article continued:
NOT receiving any other forms of Commonwealth assistance, including Department of Veterans Affairs pensions or the household support section of the Rural Adjustment Scheme.

This is a contentious issue. My office conducted a survey of all the DSS offices in rural South Australia and we were told there had been virtually no-one successful at getting onto social security benefits through the existing hardship provisions.

According to Maggie Martinelli of the South Australian Welfare Rights Centre, this is not surprising because there is virtually no-one being told they can apply. Contrary to the advice given by Mr Kerin, people are being told at the DSS counter that they must apply for household support. According to Maggie, the DSS has been positively obstructionist in providing adequate information and advice to farming families. DSS does not tell farmers that perhaps their wives are eligible for unemployment benefits. It does not tell farmers that if they are not happy with what they are being told, there is a right to appeal. Or perhaps they are simply told there are no appeal forms available anyway.

The advice that they must apply for household support first is simply not correct. Household support is paid through the rural adjustment scheme to meet living expenses while the farmer considers whether to adjust out of farming. The farmer must be unable to obtain financial assistance elsewhere. It is not necessary for the farm to be put on the market to receive the support. However, it is normally only granted for more than three months if the Department considers the farmer is making a genuine attempt to leave farming but cannot undertake full time work off the farm because of his farming responsibilities-for example, maintaining fences and looking after stock.

It seems quite clear to us that the Department of Social Security is deliberately leading farmers up the garden path. It is making it virtually impossible for them to access benefits. There is also the paperwork if indeed they do make it past the front counter. Rural counsellors in South Australia, and it is certainly more than just a couple, assure us it runs to something like 35 pages of paperwork. It can take somewhere around three and a half hours to complete, and that is with an advocate, whether that advocate be a rural counsellor or, in some cases, an accountant. It seems to me that however we look at this problem it comes down to its being a matter of government and departmental will.

The infrastructure is there to assist farming families, but the jumbled, confused maze of advice and competing interests, or perhaps disinterests, is severely hampering the possibilities of farmers accessing support. There is a swirl of assets test, asset valuation practices, hardship provisions, work tests, income tests and competing advice that farming families must wade their way through to obtain any support. Simplification, clarification, reprioritisation are all needed.

I am taking this opportunity now to indicate that this is an area which the Democrats believe urgently requires Government attention. We hope that this will occur during the Budget session, if not before, and I can assure the chamber that the Democrats will be watching this area carefully and will be taking action in the Budget session if none is forthcoming from the Government.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Tonight we are debating two social security Bills, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 and the Social Security (Rewrite) Amendment Bill 1991. Both of these Bills incorporate into the new clear-English Act a range of changes to the social security system that have occurred since the last Budget. The rewrite Bill also makes a number of minor changes which help clarify the intent of the new Act.

speech.para: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) also seeks to introduce a number of relatively minor policy changes into the Social Security Act, including allowing the payment of special benefit to holders of a conditional two-year residence permit, the indexation of the income-free area for the maintenance income test, the indexation of the $2.50 pharmaceutical allowance and the continued provision of fringe benefits cards to those pensioners who have exceeded the fringe benefit threshold.

The Opposition will oppose the Government's attempt to allow non-permanent residents access to special benefits. It seems bizarre to tell supposedly able-bodied people that our Government will look after them. This clause is sending precisely the wrong signals to migrants. Rather than encouraging a welfare mentality, governments should be creating opportunities and rewarding individual excellence.

I wish to concentrate on just one of these issues, namely the decision to allow pensioners to retain concession cards if they exceed the fringe benefits threshold due to deeming. This promise is indicative of the Government's bandaid approach to decision making but, as with most bandaids, this one seems to have come unstuck.

In the Budget, it was announced that all pensioner investments above a certain amount would be deemed to be earning 10 per cent per annum. This decision caused an outcry from pensioners. One of their biggest concerns was that they would lose fringe benefits because extra income earned, or deemed to be earned, would take them over the fringe benefits threshold.

Pensioners value their fringe benefits highly and are very protective of them-sometimes not in a justified way. In fact, they would be better to have earned their income. But they do feel very protective of these fringe benefits. It is difficult to put a monetary value on the fringe benefits card, but it can be used to obtain a range of concessions from Federal, State and local agencies on rates, electricity, public transport, pharmaceuticals and other items.

In an attempt to curb the angry masses, the magnanimous Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) made an off the-cuff decision that no pensioner entitled to fringe benefits at the time of the Budget would lose these benefits as a result of the deeming initiative. There was no Cabinet decision, no mention in the Budget, no costings, no legislation-just a kind and compassionate Minister with a very keen eye on the pensioner vote at the next election.

Everything seemed rosy. The Minister had stemmed the pensioner outcry. There was little cost for the Federal Government as the majority of fringe benefits are paid by State and local governments. However, there were unforseen circumstances that cast doubt on the fairness and equity of the Minister's promise.

I began receiving phone calls from pensioners who had been maintaining their income in higher interest bearing accounts prior to the Budget and who were concerned that they would continue to be ineligible for fringe benefits, although their incomes were identical to or even less than the incomes of those people who stood to benefit from the Minister's promise. What crime had these pensioners committed? None. What they were doing was honestly investing their income, their capital, earning interest and declaring it to the Government. Ironically, they were paying the price for having conducted their financial affairs in a way that is now being openly endorsed and encouraged by the Federal Government.

The Minister's promise also discriminates against pensioners whose extra income is derived from sources other than interest bearing accounts. They remain ineligible for fringe benefits, even though their total income may be no greater, or quite possibly less, than someone who remains entitled to fringe benefits. The Minister is responsible for engineering an inequitable welfare system in which pensioners with identical incomes and assets are entitled to different government benefits.

What was the Minister's response when I asked him what would be done to rectify this inequitable situation? He claimed that he would be using the `new-federalism' process over the next two years to introduce uniformity in fringe benefits between States. What hypocrisy! The Minister's own doorstop promise caused the inequitable situation whereby pensioners with identical income and assets have different fringe benefits entitlements. Then he stands up in the Senate claiming that he is working on achieving a uniform system of fringe benefits. I remind the Minister that the charter of the Department of Social Security states:
To deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency.

My emphasis is on fairness. The Minister's promise pays scant regard to the fairness principle. There is nothing fair about two people with identical incomes and assets having different fringe benefits entitlements. It would also be overgenerous to classify the Department's implementation of the Minister's promise as being within the realms of `efficient delivery of social security entitlements', as specified in the Department's charter.

To be fair to the Department, some of these administrative problems stem from the impromptu nature of the Minister's promise. First, there was the inexcusable situation whereby people who were granted the pension after the Minister's promise were told that they were eligible for fringe benefits. They were later told, `Sorry, actually you are not eligible'. When one such person complained to the Minister, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) wrote back saying:
Unfortunately, due to a computer programming error-
I remember reading just recently a quite interesting quote in a book, `Who did people blame before there were computers?'-

when implementing the Government's deeming measures, some pensioners were incorrectly advised that they were entitled to fringe benefits. It was necessary to advise pensioners of their non-entitlement to fringe benefits when the mistake was discovered.
This was a good try by Mr Sciacca, but it was not quite right, as the Secretary to the Department admitted in the Senate Estimates in April. He said:

. . . some people were issued with fringe benefits cards following the Budget in the understanding that they were not eligible for them but to be sure that we met the Government's commitment in respect of people retaining PHB Cards, regardless of what happened with deeming. As soon as the systems changes were made, we wrote to those people to inform them that they were not eligible for those cards. The problem we had was that the database did not identify certain categories of people and it was very much a short term arrangement we pursued.
Before I go on to the second example, I refer again to the charter:
To deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency.

Problem No. 2 is that the Minister promised that no-one would lose their fringe benefits entitlement as a result of the deeming even if their pension were cancelled. Unfortunately, Social Security's administration of the promise did not quite reflect the promise, as this excerpt from a letter kindly provided by the shadow Minister for social security, child-care and retirement incomes, Senator Alston, shows:

The government did guarantee that holders of these cards would not be disadvantaged by doing the right thing and rearranging their affairs to maximise their income. This means that although your pension has been cancelled due to an increase in your income you are entitled to retain your card. The problem has been that automatic devices have not been updated to reflect this policy change. If you have not destroyed your card as instructed you may continue to use it. If however you have destroyed the card could you please contact me as soon as possible so that I can arrange to reissue your card immediately.

These are both examples of the administrative problems faced by an inflexible department which is faced with implementing an impromptu promise that has been made by its Minister. Without downplaying the significance of those examples, my third example is a potentially far more drastic administrative blunder which the Senate must address today during this cognate debate. As I said earlier, this legislation attempts to give legal status to the Minister's fringe benefits promise.

Let me say that while the Minister has an army of legal eagles, an army of people with experience in social security legislation and an army of draftspeople to prepare the legislation, my office conducted a close scrutiny of this legislation and found that they had got it wrong. We spend half our lives-that may be a slight exaggeration-in this chamber correcting legislation, often when it has gone through the Senate, because it is brought in at the eleventh hour and we do not have time to scrutinise it to the degree to which it ought be scrutinised. However, with the scrutiny of this legislation demonstrated by myself and my staff, we found this error.

We found that the relevant clause in the Bill was drafted in a way that would not do what the Minister had promised; to the contrary, it would do the exact opposite. It would disqualify anyone who went over the threshold due to the rearrangement of their income from being eligible for a fringe benefits card. I do not know whether we were supposed to rely on the Minister's promise, but given the way promises are broken by this Government, I would not like to have been a pensioner hoping that I would retain my entitlement card.

I can just picture the Minister's face when he found out that the legal section of his own Department had drafted the Bill in a way that overturned his own promise, but thankfully we picked up the error. We informed the Minister who demanded that the problem be fixed immediately. When the Government moves amendments to rectify this problem during the committee stage, I will comment further about the drafting problems with current social security legislation. At this stage, I just wish to reiterate the Opposition's concerns about this hastily conceived promise, the way in which it was implemented and the fact that it has now created different classes of people with the same income receiving different benefits.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”So far as Senator Patterson's comments are concerned, I should say first off that the `army' of people in the legal section of my Department numbers nine, which is a pretty small army. In any event, responsibility for the drafting of legislation lies with the Office of Parliamentary Counsel which is attempting to deliver a very large program of legislation. The army in my Department has delivered the biggest chunk of that legislative program in the Commonwealth but the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has to deliver the lot.

speech.para: I am not going to be ungracious about it. I am grateful to Senator Patterson for having alerted us to what could have been a technical error and, as she is well aware, action is being taken to remedy that error. In terms of the fairness of a decision to allow those who were being affected by deeming to keep fringe benefits as against those who have come into the system later and who will not be eligible for them on the same income--

talk.start.para: â€”I didn't say that.
â€”Senator Patterson did speak about it.
â€”The people before the Budget.

â€”That is precisely what I am talking about. I have said in here before and repeat for the record that it would be wrong to implement a major reform such as this, which by its very nature must create a fair degree of fear and trepidation in the elderly community, and then attempt to have that community even worse off and even more worried and confused by ripping fringe benefits off it. However, we are working very hard to ensure that we can get a nationally agreed system of fringe benefits and that the Commonwealth can come to an arrangement with the States to see it implemented. Only one State is giving us any real difficulty on that score. I am referring, of course, to New South Wales. Perhaps Senator Patterson can use some of her influence on her Liberal Party colleagues in that State to get them to do the right thing. I believe that if we do not get a proper national system we will have a disaster.

speech.para: In terms of Senator Patterson's other remark about who we blamed before computers came in, for a department that is making in excess of 100 million payments a year to four million people, the idea that the massive amount of computer programming that entails can never make an error is a nonsense. There must occasionally be errors. We seek to minimise them. We are seeking to upgrade the equipment all the time and to upgrade the programming to try to make sure that errors do not occur. To pretend that errors would never occur in a system of that size, irrespective of who administered it, is a nonsense. I believe that the record is excellent. When compared with the program delivery, the number of those errors has been very small indeed.

Most of what Senator Lees referred to is not actually in the Bill. I am not quite sure what I should say about those comments. For all those like Senator Lees who think that in some way getting the disability Bill referred to a committee will give those affected time to consider it, I should say that I have been with officers of the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled this afternoon. They are keen to see this legislation passed and implemented. The disabled community itself has given a great deal of support to this Bill and takes a different view from that of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). I would have thought that if we are going to look at who among community groups is actually representing the disabled, we cannot go past their own organisations. They are, by and large, in support of this package. I know that there are those in the Australian Democrats and those in ACOSS who have an absolute view that giving some of these people the opportunity to work is not a good thing. I am not in accord with Senator Lees's views on this and, I hasten to point out, neither are the organisations which represent the disabled. They welcome this package and they reiterated that to me today.

I now turn to Senator Alston's comments. I do not want to address everything Senator Alston was saying, but he did speak about the Opposition's concerns about special benefits being extended to those persons granted two-year conditional entry permits. There are a few points to make on this issue. Persons with these new permits will not be automatically eligible for special benefit, because the payment of special benefit is subject to pretty stringent hardship and income tests. I will not go through what those tests are; we are all aware of them. As the new permits include permission to work, most of the time the special benefit will be paid subject to claim and satisfying Job Search allowance conditions. So I think Senator Alston's fundamental concern has already been addressed.

The legislation prohibits the backdating of the payment of special benefit. It literally prohibits it, so I do not think we will see too much in the way of any new loopholes opened here. The earliest the payment can commence is when an application is lodged. Most importantly when we are looking at this new category and extension of special benefit, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will be undertaking a very intensive screening of the process in assessing eligibility for these new permits.

The process is exactly the same as that for assessing eligibility for permanent residence, but the grant for permanent residence is conditional upon the relationship being genuine and continuing over two years. In the opinion of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and that is what one must refer to in looking at this, 95 per cent-the great majority-of those issued with permits will be eligible for permanent residence at the end of the two-year conditional period. I am not convinced that there is any problem to be addressed.

talk.start.para: â€”You are allowing for 200 or 300 people a year to be granted special benefits.

â€”The special benefits can only be granted under the conditions that I have just outlined. I am not worried about people getting the special benefits. If they have to satisfy those conditions, I am not against them getting special benefits-they are entitled to them. I do not think I need to address anything else in Senator Alston's contribution.

speech.para: That is the Government's view. Obviously, we will be happy to amend the legislation to take account of the matter to which Senator Lees referred. I know there is another amendment on the question of making my decisions disallowable. The Government will not divide on this issue. I simply repeat to the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that I do not believe this will be in the interests of good government, but it is not the end of the world and we will live with it if we have to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”I table supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to the Government amendments to be moved to these Bills.

The Bill.

(2) Clause 41, page 15, line 3, omit ``paragraph'' (first occurring), substitute ``paragraphs''.
(3) Clause 41, page 15, proposed paragraph (aaa), at end of paragraph, add the following paragraph:

Income from certain money

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to take this opportunity, on looking through these amendments, to congratulate Senator Patterson and her office for discovering the difficulties that apparently exist in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. The Australian Democrats will support the amendments.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I appreciate Senator Richardson's acknowledgment of our finding of the technical error. As I said in my contribution to the second reading debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) Bill 1991, if the original, flawed clause 41 been allowed to pass through the Senate, it would have meant that anyone who rearranged their income between the Budget and 1 March 1991 to comply with the deeming arrangements and went over the fringe benefits threshold could have lost the fringe benefits entitlement, had the Government so chosen. The result of the original clause would have been exactly that which would have occurred if the Minister had not promised to protect pensioners' fringe benefits entitlements from the effects of deeming.

speech.para: All pensioners in Australia were informed in March 1991 that their fringe benefits would not be affected by the deeming provisions, yet the Department of Social Security has drafted legislation in such a way that would have exactly the opposite effect. This is either an extremely incompetent piece of drafting-so incompetent that it could be picked up at the drop of a hat by virtually any bush lawyer-or it was a deliberate attempt to overturn the Minister's promise that pensioners' fringe benefits would not be affected by deeming. I am generous enough to presume that it was an oversight.

This is a prime example of where sloppy or incompetent drafting can have a marked effect on the implementation of policy. If this error had not been identified, a significant number of pensioners could have lost their fringe benefit entitlement. With all due respect to the Minister who said that he does not actually have an army, it looks like an army from this side of the chamber when he has three staff members. It is an army that has a lot more experience than my small battalion.

This is not the first time that the Government's social security initiatives from the last Budget have been besieged by drafting problems. Last year, the Government inadvertently set the deeming threshold at $2,000 for singles and $4,000 for couples. Earlier this year, it was discovered that a drafting error in the same Bill prevented the Department from collecting tax file numbers from a wide range of beneficiaries. Then, in the first Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill earlier this year, the funeral bond provisions were drafted in a way that would have allowed withdrawal of moneys by a spouse contrary to the intentions of the Bill. We discussed this in my office and, unfortunately, did not do what we did this time and notify the Minister. We thought we were aware of a bungle. This time when we saw the bungle, we notified the Minister.

It is inappropriate to make scapegoats of the drafters in the Department of Social Security or the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. We know and we accept, given this Government's ridiculous program, that they are working to very difficult deadlines which are forced upon them by the Government's legislative schedule. Ultimately, the blame rests with the Government because it is not providing its own drafters or the Senate committees with sufficient time to scrutinise its legislation effectively.

These are the drafting errors that we have picked up. It would be a courageous person who would claim with any degree of confidence that there are not other errors which have escaped the scrutiny of the drafters and the Senate. It again confirms my belief of the importance of the role of this place, that we have the time to scrutinise legislation to ensure that it is less likely to be subjected to unintended consequences. We must remember that at the end of the day, the people who are affected are the ordinary people, in this case, pensioners.

I appreciate that the Minister has responded. I appreciate the Minister's letter to me and his comments in the chamber. I hope that more attention will be paid to this matter so that we do not have these sorts of legislative errors.
Amendments agreed to.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: After clause 19, page 6, line 12, insert the following clause:
``19a. Section 1237 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (4) and substituting the following subsection:
`(4) A determination made under subsection (3) giving, revoking or varying directions is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.'.''.

This amendment fits in after clause 19, as the Minister has previously mentioned. I moved this amendment, which was supported by the Opposition, only a week or so ago and it is disappointing that this was not then taken into consideration when this Bill was drafted.
Proposed new clause agreed to.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I did indicate that the Opposition will be opposing clauses 4 and 10 and it may be appropriate for them to be voted on together. Otherwise, we will not be opposing the remainder of the Bill. I take the opportunity to explore with the Minister some of the comments made by Senator Lees in relation to waiting periods. Senator Lees was trying to suggest that the Australian Democrats were sympathetic to farmers and those in rural areas. I think we are all acutely aware of the fact that the Democrats are the party that would punish those in rural areas more than anyone else in this Parliament.

speech.para: It is very hypocritical for Senator Lees, on the one hand, to wander around rural areas pretending that somehow farmers are suffering from various elements in the social security legislation when, on the other hand, her colleague Senator Spindler is running around with a hit list which amounts to additional taxes of the order of $7 billion. These would involve increased excises on petrol and diesel fuel; a levy on all domestic road freight movements; changes in pay as you earn deduction procedures to impose further burdens on employers, particularly farmers; increases in company taxes for companies grossing in excess of $100,000, which is virtually every company that is able to keep its head above water; and taxing trusts as companies but, of course, making special arrangements for trade unions.

I would have thought that by now farmers ought to understand that this is a wolf in sheep's clothing, if ever there was one. The Australian Democrats are the party in the Parliament which is proposing to extend the capital gains tax to family homes worth more than $500,000. The Democrats are trying in all sorts of ways to make sure that any farmer who is still alive would not survive for much longer if this sort of silly agenda were ever implemented. We all know that it will not be implemented and we all know that the Democrats will never get their hands on the levers. But I think Senator Lees at least owes it to the rural community to explain how she can, on the one hand, simply go around wringing her hands and saying that she feels sorry for farmers and yet, on the other hand, have an agenda which is viciously anti-farmer.

We have only to look at Senator Lees's own State where the Democrats would propose a 40 per cent increase in the alcohol excise and speculate what effect that might have on the wine industry in South Australia. There is a whole raft of proposals which are designed not only to ensure that farmers' incomes are significantly reduced but also to tax out of existence any of those who are still surviving. Proposals that involve wealth and inheritance taxes, closing down the live sheep export industry and almost any other productive rural activity give the lie to the concern that is being expressed.

I do not mind Senator Lees being critical in a whole range of areas but I think the honest thing to do is point out the pluses and minuses of the Democrats' approach. It is simply hypocritical double standards to, on the one hand, allow Senator Lees to get away with that sort of nonsense but, on the other hand, not come clean about what her colleague has in mind.

Having got that off my chest, I ask the Minister a question. Does the Government think the Democrats' suggestion-which echoes the views of bodies such as the Australian Council of Social Service and the Victorian Council of Social Service-that waiting periods ought to be reduced, I think, pretty much across the board, contains some inherent logic? Should we have a shorter waiting period in times of economic difficulty? In a sense, the corollary of that would be that we would be entitled to have a longer waiting period in times of economic progress.

I would be interested in the Minister's response. It seems to me that there would be the insuperable political difficulty of reinstating a longer waiting period when someone had made the hard judgment that the economy had recovered. Apart from that, I have a difficulty in terms of the logic behind that position. If one can justify having waiting periods, what difference does it make whether there is a recession? I would be interested to hear the Minister's response.

speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not accept the view that waiting periods should be shortened because there is a recession. If one accepts that a recession is a time of economic hardship-and I do not think we will go into whether we have two consecutive quarters of negative growth-that is why we have hardship provisions. I can recall outlining in the Senate a couple of weeks ago not only what the hardship provisions were but also how they were applied. I pointed out that the Department of Social Security has taken a fairly liberal view of applications for hardship provisions. We have taken a compassionate view and where evidence exists, waiting periods are waived. So I do not think we should change the waiting period; it is just a matter of how we react to a time of hardship with the use of the hardship provisions. I defend the way in which the Department has implemented those provisions over the course of, say, the last six to nine months when economic times were obviously turning towards hardship.

speech.para: I am faced, however, with the same problem I had in answering a question from Senator Lees at Question Time today. I still do not exclude the possibility that there might be certainly one anomaly in waiting periods that we did not intend at the time. Therefore, I cannot say that I will not be doing anything about changes in waiting periods in the Budget. But as a principle I do not accept that, because times are tougher, we change waiting periods.

talk.start.para: â€”I am indebted to the Minister for that explanation. What view does the Minister take of the proposition that there are very many people who are finding that the nominal one week waiting period is in practice often extended to three weeks? I presume that means that at the end of three weeks those people are getting backdated payments, so in effect they are getting two weeks. I would be interested in whatever the Government can provide on the magnitude of this problem. It has been brought to my attention on a number of occasions and complaints have been made that many people are, in practice, being required to wait not one but three weeks. I presume that is simply a function of administration. It may be caused by an increased demand during the period of the recession, but if it is the fact we ought to know the extent of the difficulty. I invite the Minister to make some inquiries and perhaps report back on the magnitude of the problem.

â€”I have had specific cases drawn to my attention on a number of occasions. I cannot say that I am aware of its being a problem of magnitude. I will make further inquiries in an attempt to give Senator Alston before the end of the week the numbers that would be in the position of having to wait three weeks. I have been of the view that they have been relatively small. I have not had an avalanche of cases drawn to my attention. I will recheck it and get back to Senator Alston in the next couple of days.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to respond, as I was invited to by Senator Alston, to the nonsense he has just put. First and foremost, I stand by the need to totally review the Australian taxation system. We need an equitable and just tax system. The problem in this country is definitely in the area of who pays. Who is now paying the burden of taxation? It is the middle to low income earners, particularly the pay as you earn taxpayers.

speech.para: The plan of the Australian Democrats is for a tax system that taxes those people who can afford to pay. We certainly are not proposing a broad based consumption tax-as Senator Alston is-that will tax everyone right across the board and will tax such things as medical and dental services, which at the moment do not attract any tax at all, regardless of a person's income. The Democrats stand by the tax package we are in the process of developing. A couple of the taxes mentioned by Senator Alston probably will be on the agenda, but I stress that the tax policies of the Democrats will tax those who can afford to pay. At the moment, farmers in this country not only cannot afford to pay taxes but also are having great difficulty in surviving.

Returning to what we are supposed to be discussing, we will not be supporting the two amendments moved by the Opposition. As I highlighted in my speech, we do not believe that these amendments will do anything other than close what was hopefully an unforeseen hole that people would simply fall into if they happened to fit into a particular category-in other words, close off the possibility where people in this country, as the Minister has said, the vast majority of them preparing to become Australian citizens, find themselves through no fault of their own with absolutely no income. Therefore, we will be supporting the Bill.

I take the opportunity to ask the Minister whether he could give us the number of people per year who would fall into the category of coming into this country, finding themselves in a situation where they urgently needed assistance and needing special benefits.

talk.start.para: â€”I will have to take that on notice. I do not have that information available here.
â€”It is about 300.
â€”There are the 300 we have given on this. I thought Senator Lees's question was broader than that; I will have to take it on notice.

â€”Could I check that it is not the hordes that some people have suggested? An earlier issue that I meant to raise relates to the commencement date on 15 April. Are we looking at this retrospective element because that is tying it back to migration regulations?

â€”To answer the first part of the question, there are not hordes, but I will get the exact numbers. I should be able to do that tomorrow. We are talking about the date that these regulations came into effect, are we not? That is where it harks back to.

â€”As I understand it, this allows applications to be made on or after 15 April. Is the Minister saying that people cannot receive backdated payments? No-one is going to be able to make an application earlier than today's date, so why does the legislation not simply provide prospectively? Why is there any need to refer to the date when the migration regulations came into effect?

â€”I can only repeat what I said earlier. The only reason we have referred to April is that that is the date when those regulations came into being. I can only repeat what I said: the legislation prohibits backdating. It can be done only from the date that a claim for special benefits is lodged.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: â€”We do not necessarily have to backdate the date of the application; we can date it at today's date. But is Senator Richardson saying that we then could not claim in respect of the period since 15 April? For example, if someone arrived here on 16 April and demonstrated that he or she was deserving of special benefits, that person could not receive payments from that date?
â€”No.
â€”I acknowledge the Minister saying that that cannot be done.

proctext.para: Bills (on motion by Senator Richardson) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a first time.
