speech.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, which is now before the chamber contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987.

This Bill gives effect to the tariff changes announced as part of the Ministerial Statement-Building a Competitive Australia. The Bill also contains some amendments which have previously been introduced as customs tariff proposals.
The major tariff changes announced on the twelfth day of March 1991 fulfil the Government's commitment to continue, beyond 1992, the tariff reforms initiated in 1988.
The importance of these changes is the certainty that this announcement will provide to the importing community in setting the tariff regime for the foreseeable future.
The Bill contains measures relating to general tariff rates, measures for the specific industry sectors of agriculture, passenger motor vehicles and textile, clothing and footwear.
The amendments to the general manufacturing ad valorem rates implement phased reductions to 5 per cent by 1 July 1996 for tariffs greater than 5 per cent at 1 July 1992.

This will continue to reduce the disparities in the effective rates of assistance between Australian industries, further flatten the tariff, encourage rationalisation of less efficient activities and reduce input costs to other trade-exposed sectors of the economy. Changes are also proposed for the preferential tariff arrangements for Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan Province and the Republic of Korea. From 1 July 1992 the tariff rates for these countries will be frozen.

When the general tariff rate reaches or passes the frozen rate the general rate will apply. This action recognises the rapid improvement in their economic situation, and the widening disparity among countries traditionally considered to be ``developing''. This disparity creates differing needs for international trade assistance by way of preferential treatment. The United States recently recognised this in their ``graduation'' of these four countries from preference arrangements. The amendments in this Bill will be consistent with these moves, and with the original purpose of preferential arrangements.

In any case, the freezing of tariffs applying to these countries will ensure that no tariff rates will increase for them. Some preference will continue to be available until the general tariff rate phases down to the rate applying to developing countries at the start of the freeze. Where the general tariff rate remains unchanged, these countries will continue to enjoy the 5 per cent preference margin.
The Government has also decided to convert fixed and composite tariff rates to ad valorem equivalents wherever possible and consistent with Australia's international obligations.
These tariffs will be reduced in line with the general reductions in tariffs.
Tariff assistance for agricultural industries will phase down after 1992 at the same rate as the general manufacturing sector, to 5 per cent by 1 July 1996, with the following exceptions:

* Vegetable products (which are phasing down to a tariff of 10 per cent by 1 July 1994) will continue to phase down at the same rate as the general manufacturing sector, to 5 per cent by 1 January 1998.

* Post 1992 assistance arrangements for the dairy, sugar and tobacco growing industries will be determined in the context of industry commission inquiries. An inquiry into the dairy industry is currently under way, an inquiry into sugar will commence in the near future and tobacco growing will be reviewed in 1993.

In the interim assistance for the Sugar Industry should be brought back within the spirit of the 1988 decision to reduce general tariffs to a maximum of 15 per cent ad valorem equivalent by 1 July 1992.

Accordingly, it is proposed to adjust the specific tariff rate for raw and refined sugar to $76 per tonne at 1 July 1991 and to $55 per tonne at 1 July 1992. By maintaining a specific tariff rate, the Sugar Industry will remain protected in the event of low world prices over this period.

The new arrangements for passenger motor vehicles maintain the successful policy direction already established by continuing the existing rate of tariff reduction, while making the export facilitation scheme more flexible and rewarding to those firms prepared to make investments to considerably expand exports.

They are designed to focus the Australian industry on increasing its viability and international competitiveness at reduced levels of tariff assistance, achieving a higher level of global integration, and improving product quality at reduced real prices.
The new arrangements also reflect the Government's desire to reduce the cost to the community of supporting industry.
The new arrangements retain the current schedule for tariff reduction until December, 1992. From January, 1993:
* tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and original equipment components will continue to be reduced at the current rate of 2.5 per cent per year, reaching 15 per cent by the year 2000;
* tariffs on light commercial and four-wheel drive vehicles (as well as on components for these vehicles) will be reduced from 15 per cent in line with the general tariff reductions; while
* tariffs on replacement components for passenger motor vehicles will be maintained at 15 per cent until 31 December 2000.
The Government has also moved to provide for a definition of forward-control vehicles in the Customs Tariff Act.
Assistance changes for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries will extend to the year 2000.

Tariffs will commence phasing on 1 March 1992 and will reach a maximum of 25 per cent in the year 2000 compared to the current planned level of 55 per cent by 1995. Quotas will be abolished by 1 March 1993, two years ahead of schedule.

The Government's decision to accelerate TCF tariff reductions is aimed at bringing TCF assistance more into line with the rest of manufacturing while recognising the special adjustment problems within the sector.

The pace of restructuring since the current plan was announced in 1986 has not been sufficient. Protection levels have remained very high. This has tended to attract resources into the least efficient areas of production and has negated any incentive for the industries to restructure and become internationally competitive.

Although the current plan would have made significant reductions in protection by 1995, TCF assistance would still be much higher than that currently programmed to apply industry-wide. The tariff quota system in particular has tended to counteract reductions in protection.

The changes incorporated in this Bill are designed to encourage the development of a more internationally competitive TCF sector which will be viable with lower levels of community support. Australian consumers stand to benefit from better products at cheaper prices. Economy wide effects will accrue from the more efficient allocation of resources.
In line with these objectives
* All quotas will be terminated on 1 March 1993 and out-of-quota duty rates currently programmed for 1 March 1992 will be halved.
* Tariff rates will be reduced as follows:
- apparel and certain finished textiles to phase down to 25 per cent by 1 July 2000
- footwear, cotton sheeting and fabrics to phase down to 15 per cent by 1 July 2000
- footwear parts and existing non-quota TCF goods to phase down to 10 per cent by 1 July 2000
- TCF goods already having rates of 15 per cent or less to phase down in line with general reductions for general manufacturing tariffs
* The textile yarn bounty will be phased from 30 per cent value-added on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995 when it will then be replaced with a 5 per cent tariff.

* An import credit scheme will operate from 1 July 1991 to 30 June 2000 to assist those firms who have the best chance of becoming internationally competitive to prosper in an environment of lower protection.

- import credits will initially accrue at the rate of 30 per cent of the domestic value added of TCF exports and will phase to 15 per cent of the domestic value added over the period of the scheme. The scheme will exclude exports of wool, wool tops and raw cotton as well as all exports to New Zealand
- the credits can only be used to reduce tariffs on TCF imports and will be freely transferable.

The Government has also decided to extend the existing duty free entry provisions for capital equipment. The savings in import duty will encourage the undertaking of industrial projects in Australia, greater participation of Australian manufacturers, the boosting of Australia's international competitiveness and increased exports.
The specific assistance measures are:

* Extending the split consignments provisions available under item 43 in schedule 4 to certain capital equipment falling within chapters 86, 87 and 89 of schedule 3. This will allow the importation of complete capital equipment or parts of this equipment in separate consignments at the rate of duty applying to the complete plant.

* Extending duty free entry for minerals processing equipment not made in Australia in the ordinary course of business. This is achieved by amending item 45 in schedule 4 and will encourage the downstream processing of our resource based industries and further enhance our international competitiveness.

* Extending item 42a in schedule 4 to allow shipbuilders to enter duty free, all components for the repair, modification and construction of vessels greater than 150 gross construction tons. This will enhance their international competitiveness.
Other industry specific measures are:

* The provision for duty free entry of bountiable machinery for working advanced materials such as engineering ceramics, composites and polymers. This action is in conjunction with the extension of the machine tools and robots bounty which will give uniform treatment for all machine tools covered by the bounty, and will allow end users access to the latest equipment at world prices while continuing to give assistance to local industry. A new item in schedule 4 will give effect to this measure.

* The removal of the duty on printed circuit boards classified to heading 8534 in schedule 3 from 1 July 1991. This reflects the decision to assist local value added production of printed circuit boards by means of the computer bounty scheme.
* Binding tariff rates on certain vegetable products at 10 per cent as a result of GATT negotiations.
Now, to guide members through the sections and schedules of the Bill.

Clause 3 of the Bill inserts new subsections 19(1a), 19(1b) and 19(1c) into the principal Act to maintain the preference advantage for Canada and forum island countries over general rate countries and to cater for the selective phasing out of developing country preferential rates for goods of Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan province and Republic of Korea origin.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends subsection 26 (1) of the principal Act by inserting two tariff subheadings in the table in this subsection. This amendment will allow the consumer price index adjustment factor to be applied to the rate of duty for certain mixed spirituous beverages of these subheadings. The changes are operative on and from the thirteenth day of February 1991.

Schedule one is effective on and from the seventeenth day of August 1990 and provides a free rate of duty for aluminised steel for use in the manufacture of automotive muffler exhaust systems and components.

The amendments contained in schedule 2 reduce the rate of duty on certain coated fabrics covered by item 40e of schedule 4 from 16 per cent to 8 per cent and delete the upward phasing rates which would have been fully implemented in 1993. These amendments are operative on and from the seventeenth day of October 1990.

The amendments contained in schedule 3, operative on and from the twenty-fourth day of December 1990, address administrative problems associated with the importation of industrial crafts covered by schedule 5 of the customs tariff. The amendments remove the necessity for industrial crafts to be made of woven material and clarifies the batik process.

Schedule 4, which operates on and from the first day of January 1991, introduces a free rate of duty for defibrillators, heart pacemakers and wheelchairs. These changes are a result of the Government's decision on the Industry Commission's report on ``aids and appliances for people with disabilities''.
Schedule 5 puts in place the tender quota and tender extension rates of duty for textiles, clothing and footwear goods for the period 1 March 1991 to 29 February 1992.
Schedules 6, 7 and 8 implement the major tariff initiatives announced as part of the ministerial statement-Building a Competitive Australia.
Financial impact statement

The initiatives to allow duty free entry of aluminised steel for use in the manufacture of automotive muffler exhaust systems and components will involve a revenue loss of $1.83m in the current financial year and $2m in 1991-1992.
Tariff changes to wheelchairs, defibrillators and heart pacemakers will involve a loss of duty in this financial year of $400,000 and $890,000 in 1991-1992.

The value of the tender quota allocation for 1991-1992 has been raised by 17 per cent above 1990-1991 levels as a result of the expansion of quota ceilings. However, due to a general reduction in premium rates, the level of duty is expected to drop by $101.3m.

Assistance measures announced in the economic development statement of 12 March 1991 and contained in this Bill will reduce revenue receipts by a total of $79.1m in 1991-92, $115.65m in 1992-93 and $491.65m in 1993-94.
Other changes contained in this Bill have only minor revenue implications.
Summaries of the amendments contained in this Bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.
Motion
Motion (by Senator Richardson)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Amendment Bill 1991 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

debate.title:
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1991

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 18 April and 29 May, on motions by Senator Collins and Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Olsen Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: â€”The principal amendments proposed by the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991 and the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, which we have agreed are allied Bills, serve to dismantle some fundamental structures of Australian protectionism. In principle, the coalition supports their thrust and direction. However, while we agree with the general thrust of the Government's proposals in these two Bills-indeed, the coalition set the agenda last year when it called for phased reductions of all industry protection to, at most, negligible levels by the year 2000-the Government has failed to deliver the other side of the reform ledger which we say is an absolutely vital and important component; they have to go together.

speech.para: The failure to deliver micro-economic reform will mean that thousands of enterprises, faced with lower assistance, will not be able to meet the challenge of increased international competition. It must be made clear that the Government, by not balancing this ledger-and I am talking about the waterfront, industrial relations, telecommunications and transport; the list goes on-has broken its commitment to industry to tackle other reform areas which would ensure cost reductions and give it a better opportunity to compete on world markets.

I want to address my remarks to the Bills under debate. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill legislates protection cuts announced in the 12 March statement as well as several other tariff changes announced recently. In broad terms, the effect of the major amendments will be to phase down certain general ad valorem tariff rates by 1996; phase down tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and original equipment components; phase down textile, clothing and footwear tariffs; allow duty free importation of goods designed for minerals processing which are not made in Australia; allow duty free importation of goods used in the construction, modification and repair of ships greater than 150 gross construction tons; lower the tariff rate for raw and refined sugar; freeze tariff rates applying to certain imported goods from Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea until the general tariff rate is down to the tariff rate of those goods; allow the duty free importation of invalid carriages, defibrillators and pacemakers; and raise the tender quota allocations of most textile, clothing and footwear goods.

The coalition supports the proposed general tariff reductions to bring virtually all manufacturing tariffs to 5 per cent by July 1996. This is in line with our announcement last year to reduce all industry protection to, at most, negligible levels by the end of the century. However, we again stress-and it is vital to make this point-that our commitment included an equally absolute commitment to tackle micro-economic reforms so that industry would be given the opportunity to meet the challenge of lower industry assistance. We will be moving an amendment to urge the Government to reconsider this unbalanced approach. It is much in line with the imbalance that we now have with the financial markets deregulated but the labour markets not deregulated. One arm of supply and demand cannot be deregulated without the other.

talk.start.para: â€”You certainly cannot push mark VI accord and cut tariffs.

â€”No, you cannot. The whole thrust of the coalition's policy to reduce tariffs is to do it consistently with, and at the same time as, micro-economic reform to address the cost factors, as Senator Boswell referred to them, of goods and production.

speech.para: The Bill also implements announced tariff reductions for the automotive and textile, clothing and footwear sectors. Broadly speaking, the automotive sector tariff will be phased down from 35 per cent to 15 per cent by the year 2000. In the textile, clothing and footwear sector, quotas will be abolished two years ahead of schedule, and the tariff level applying by the year 2000 will be 25 per cent for most clothing, 15 per cent for footwear and fabrics and 10 per cent for footwear parts and certain non-quota goods.

While the coalition will not oppose these reductions, our preference is to remove all special industry arrangements by the end of the century. In other words, these two sectors should receive the same level of assistance as the rest of the manufacturing industry by the year 2000, given that a coalition government will implement much needed micro-economic reforms.

On a more positive note, the Government has adopted the coalition's proposal to freeze the developing country preference rate for the so-called newly industrialised countries of Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and Korea. Their preference will be frozen, and as the general tariff rate falls the preference margin will also fall until it reaches zero. The general tariff rate will then apply to these countries.

Other changes included in this Bill are the expanded duty free provisions for the importation of capital equipment which the coalition supports. It also supports a range of other proposed changes for the duty free importation of aluminised steel used in the manufacture of automotive muffler exhaust systems, duty free entry of wheelchairs, defibrillators, heart pacemakers, printed circuit boards, machine tools and parts for working advanced materials.

In relation to the steel used for the manufacture of automotive exhaust systems, I am pleased to see that this Bill provides for that change of policy. In May last year, in one of my first acts as a senator, I represented a small South Australian manufacturing company which was severely disadvantaged by the fact it could not obtain its raw material and as a result was disadvantaged in the marketplace. As the Minister's press statement says, Australian car manufacturers have made it clear that a local product did not meet the needs of muffler exhaust systems manufacturers. He said that the Government believed its action would reduce the manufacturers' raw material costs and would improve the market competitiveness of their mufflers. Of course, that will have a flow-on effect for the Australian vehicle building industry.

I first made representations on 30 May, and we now see in this Bill that measure implemented. In this instance it will give a South Australian motor vehicle manufacturer, Walker Australia Pty Ltd, the opportunity to be competitive within the Australian market and, hopefully, more competitive on international markets. I certainly welcome that change. It is a move in the right direction.

The Customs Bill also implements the proposed textile, clothing and footwear import credit scheme which is a somewhat less generous version of the automotive industry's export facilitation scheme. This Bill establishes the by-law to allow duty free entry of goods under the scheme. An amendment will be moved to delete this new by-law because the coalition, as a matter of principle, opposes the extension of the export credit schemes beyond the car industry. The only reason we accept continuation of export facilitation in that industry is that it is there and it would be too disruptive to withdraw it now. Moreover, as the tariff falls, so too will the amount of export subsidy involved.

The coalition is moving the amendment because it considers such export facilitation arrangements are generally undesirable because they can add yet another layer of distortion. The whole thrust of this legislation is to start withdrawing or removing some of these distortions in the marketplace and in the manufacturing arena. Distortions may be reduced within the industry between importers and exporters, but the overwhelming problem is that distortions are exacerbated between exporters in the target industries and exporters in other industries. This is the reason the Industry Commission opposes such schemes in principle.

Everyone agrees now that the major cost of import protection is the effective tax imposed on exports. Exporters are not only forced to pay higher prices for protected inputs but, of more concern, they are compelled to pay higher prices for factors of production such as labour and capital, the prices of which are bid up by the protected sectors. Of course, not only exporters bear these higher costs but exporters cannot pass them on into higher consumer prices-they must compete with world prices on world markets. The only real solution to the problem is to get rid of the import protection, and this process is now under way with bipartisan support and the general thrust of this Bill.

But others suggest some form of tariff compensation which broadly compensates exporters for the costs of import protection. In theory this could be achieved but in practice these schemes rarely compensate on a non-distorting basis and, of course, the administrative costs of such schemes become prohibitive.

In this light, the proposed textile, clothing and footwear imports credit scheme is a sort of halfway house. Import protection is coming down in the industry but obviously the Government feels this is not enough to encourage exporters. Therefore, it is proposing a scheme which will allow exporters initially to earn import credits to the value of 30c for every dollar of exports, which will phase down to 15c. Whilst this is more modest than the export facilitation program in the car industry, the principle, however, is the same.

Much has already been made of the Industry Commission's recommendation to continue export facilitation in the car industry. It has been written up as a major change in direction of that body away from economic purity and an endorsement of pragmatic and selective export encouragement. Clearly, these commentators have not read the Commission's report. The Commission's decision was delicately poised. It concluded that `export facilitation is resulting in a less efficient allocation of resources between industries than would otherwise occur' and that this must be balanced against any gain in efficiency of resource use within the industry.

Ultimately, its decision to recommend continuation of the scheme rested on its assessment that the scheme had been in place for some 10 years and its removal would impose adjustment costs on top of those which would flow from further reduction in tariffs. Moreover, as the tariff fell, the amount of export subsidy would dwindle. The Commission was at pains to stress that this recommendation did not signal general endorsement of such schemes. It summed up:

The Commission does not view export facilitations a desirable policy instrument in its own right . . . the costs of tariff protection to exporters and others are best addressed by focussing on reducing that protection as part of the broader program of microeconomic reform.

For these reasons, the coalition will move to oppose the establishment of the textile, clothing and footwear imports credits scheme. In due course, I will certainly commend that amendment to this chamber.

I wish to raise a matter which I hope the duty Minister, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), will take up with the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) in due course. Hopefully, we might get some answers from the Government at the committee stage. It has come to our attention that draft guidelines for various TCF programs, including the import credits scheme, have been circulated on a selective basis to certain companies. I would think that this would be in normal contravention of government practice. Clearly, selected companies would have a head start if they knew what the ground rules were. In addition to that, to the extent that their comments are taken into account, presumably the final guidelines will cater for their needs to the exclusion of firms which are not on this selective list and which have not looked at the guidelines before they are drawn up and put into place.

Overall, the Opposition is of the view that such practice is an almost inevitable by-product of such bureaucratic and administratively complex schemes as the import credits scheme. Such schemes are prone to the arbitrary selection of winners because they reward those who can or have the time to work the system. We will take this matter up with the Minister at the committee stage to ascertain whether the selective circulation of proposed guidelines was a mistake or whether it is the normal course that is followed. A number of questions will flow from that. We will seek that clarification from the Minister and his officers.

The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill essentially complements the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill amending six bounty Acts, giving effect to the announcements made in the 12 March statement. It proposes to phase down the bounty rates applying to various industries; widen the scope of certain bounty schemes; and require certain minimum annual production levels to be met to be eligible for certain bounties.

A major provision of the Bill which the coalition supports includes the phasing out of textile bounties. The post-1988 textile and clothing footwear plan proposed to reduce textile yarn bounties to 30 per cent by 1992 and to maintain them at that rate until 1995. It is now proposed that they be phased out completely by June 1995, with a 5 per cent tariff to apply thereafter. The bounty on textile printing will also phase out by June 1995 but will not be replaced by a tariff. The bed sheeting bounty, which was to wind up next year, is to be extended three years, but it will also phase to zero by 30 June 1995.

A number of other changes will be made to the textile yarns bounty following a review of the Textile Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, including the removal of the 30 per cent uplift factor on value added for bounty on export sales; the exclusion of beaming, warping and sizing processes; the deregistration of companies which fail to make a bounty claim within 12 months of the financial year; and the introduction of a minimum bounty threshold of $10,000. Savings from the accelerated phase down of the three textile bounties are expected to total $56m over the three years to 1995.

The Bill also serves to provide for the continuation of bounty assistance for local production of certain metal working machine tools and robots. This bounty, due to expire in June 1991, is now to be extended until 30 June 1997, with bounty rates progressively phasing down to 5 per cent by 1996 in line with the rest of the manufacturing industry. In addition, the bounty's coverage is to be widened to cater for current and prospective advances in the area of processing technology for new materials, with imports of these products to be duty-free. Bounty will only be paid to firms achieving in-house value-added bountiful production of at least $200,000 per annum.

The coalition supports the extension of the bounty at reduced rates, as this is consistent with our policy of gradual predictable reductions in industry protection. The Bill also proposes the extension of the coverage of the computer bounty to incorporate the manufacture of printed circuit boards from 1 July 1991. At the same time, the tariff on these items will be removed. The higher cost of the bounty is expected to be offset by a proposed reduction in scheduled bounty rates. The coalition does not oppose the broadening of the computer bounty to include printed circuit boards.

Bounties are generally less distorting than tariffs, and this change, coupled with the proposed reduction in the bounty rate, will not require additional appropriations. In addition, the Bill also serves to require certain minimal annual production levels to be met to be eligible for certain bounties. It proposes minimum annual threshold levels into the bounty schemes for books, computers, metal working machine tools, robots, textiles, yarns, bed sheeting and printed fabrics.

The coalition opposes the introduction of, or increases in, minimum thresholds in bounty schemes, and amendments will be moved to delete these provisions. In this Bill the Government is proposing to insert into the six bounty Acts minimum annual thresholds for payment of the bounty, in most cases $10,000. In one case-that of the book bounty-it was proposing to increase the threshold from $500 to $2,000 per title, but the Government changed its mind, because we understand that the change would have affected many participants in the industry, and agreed to accept in the House of Representatives a coalition amendment to restore the original limit. While welcoming the Government's change of heart on that bounty, the coalition remains of the view that all thresholds should be withdrawn. We do so for a number of reasons.

The Government claims the principal reason for introducing the thresholds is to promote efficient industrial development, not to make savings on bounty payments. Indeed, it does not claim that any significant savings will be made and no estimate of financial impact is provided in the second reading speech to the Bill, although total savings of $1m a year were claimed in the 12 March statement. By improved industrial development, one must assume that the Government means fewer and larger firms. The coalition, however, is of the view that excluding access to the bounty on the basis of size is arbitrary and could reduce the amount of competition in the industry.

In any event, why should small business not have the same access as big business? Small business is struggling out there to make ends meet and why should it not have `the level playing field' with big business as it relates to this particular area? Let me read into the record a letter from a small business which drew to the Minister's attention the problem created by this particular proposal. This letter is from the Managing Director of Syntech Automation Pty Ltd in relation to working machines and robots. It says:
The subject Act was due to expire in 1991, and it is to the Government's credit that it has been decided to extend the term to 1997.

However, there is a major shortcoming in the provisions in the new Act relating to the size of the companies which can benefit from the Bounty, in that to be eligible for the Bounty the applicant company must have a value added in excess of $200,000.

Our company is a small one employing fifteen people and with a turnover of $1,200,000. Of this total turnover approximately $200,000 would be classed as value added, based on 1990/91 results. In a poor economy with low turnover we face the possibility of being ineligible for Bounty in 1991/92.

We can also become ineligible because a lot of the work we do is not covered by the Bounty because it does not fall within the description of ``metal working'', even though much is used in the metal industry e.g., an automatic tyre inflating machine for a major car maker. Any variation in the mix of work we do could make us ineligible even in a buoyant economy.

This company attempts to compete with imported machinery, and in the last twelve months we have produced import replacement capital equipment to the value of $250,000 (at import cost). This has required a high level of technical and commercial risk, which is partially offset by the Bounty which is offered.

The proposal to implement a $200,000 floor will disadvantage smaller companies like ourselves, in favour of a very few larger companies. There is a large gap between companies of our size, and the next size level of engineering automation houses, and the smaller companies account for a large percentage of the automation carried out in this industry.

Clearly, that letter from Syntech puts it in a proper perspective. What the Government is proposing by its legislative direction is to restrict, inhibit and discriminate against small business operators in this country. Not only does small business have to reach its $200,000 value-added in tough economic circumstances that might make it ineligible in the next financial year to be able to claim that support-not of its own doing, I hasten to add, but because of the recession we had to have-but also it is being penalised simply because it is daring to suffer the impact of a recession and daring to attempt to grow and prosper. It is now being inhibited because of the direction contained in the legislation. For that reason, we will be seeking to remove those limits.

We concede that there is a valid argument that industry assistance, whether through tariffs or bounties, perhaps encourages industry fragmentation. Indeed, this has been one of the very visible and significant costs of industry protection in this country. It is an inevitable by-product which is yet another reason why industry protection should be phased out. Undesirable though fragmentation may be, we consider it is an impossible task to determine who are the potentially efficient manufacturers who should receive assistance and who should not. The only solution is to get rid of the assistance. Happily, this Bill certainly moves in that direction.

Undesirable though fragmentation may be, we consider it an impossible task to determine who are the potentially efficient manufacturers who should receive assistance and who should not. The only solution is to get rid of the assistance. Happily, this Bill certainly moves in that direction.

One could ask why the Government is introducing these thresholds now so late in the life of the bounty schemes. At least its argument would have been stronger and a little more consistent a few years ago. The coalition has seriously considered the arguments put by the Government but we consider that the balance of argument weighs in favour of our amendments. On the surface, and especially from an administrator's point of view, many small bounty payments must seem too small to be of any significance, but the danger of reducing competition in any form is too large to ignore, especially if new entrants are discouraged. Moreover, departmental officers suggest that these targeted small operators will continue without bounty. I think that is ignoring the real marketplace and the real economic circumstances out there in that marketplace now. That suggests that they are efficient and, whilst they may not need bounty, we do not see how the introduction of the thresholds can then be based on grounds of promoting industry efficiency. If this is the case, it is just a case of saving money, which is worth while but not apparently the aim of the changes as identified and proposed by the Government.

As we understand the threshold mechanism, as bounty rates fall the impact of the fixed dollar bounty thresholds will be effectively increased. For example, if a bounty is currently 20 per cent and a threshold is $10,000, then a firm needs to generate $50,000 of eligible production costs. When the bounty rate is 10 per cent, then $100,000 of costs must be generated. Smaller production units, and therefore smaller companies, will have the bounty drop out ahead of their larger competitors as bounty rates phase down, hence the very significant growing discriminatory disadvantage to small firms. In the case of the computer bounty, which is phasing down by two percentage points a year, the amount of value added required to be generated will increase from around $60,000 now to $125,000 by 1994, when the bounty will be 8 per cent. This effective increase in the threshold clearly exceeds the expected inflation rate, although perhaps the Government knows something about the levers it will adjust over the next year or two that we do not know about.

talk.start.para: â€”I doubt it.

â€”Given its track record and past performance, that might be right. I hope that the Minister will confirm whether it is the case that the effective thresholds will increase significantly as bounty rates fall and whether this effect is intended, because it is not alluded to in the second reading speech and has a dramatic and disadvantageous effect for smaller companies. We would also be interested to hear what impact the Government expects this to have on bounty recipients and future bounty payments.

speech.para: In summary, the coalition's opposition to these changes fits in with our longstanding opposition to similar arbitrary provisions in other bounty schemes-for example, orderly development provisions of the shipbuilding bounty schemes or our opposition to the minimum volume sanction in the car plan. Essentially, it is a case of our believing that efficiency is better served by letting the market sort out the most efficient structure, which, of course, will continually change, in a low assistance environment-not with arbitrary requirements, no matter how well-intentioned they may be-provided that coupled with these changes come substantial micro-economic reforms to ensure that people can effectively adjust with these changes over a period to remain in the marketplace and to be viable, effective companies employing Australians generating goods in Australia for import replacement programs and being able to access, therefore, the international marketplace. Only when we get that equation right will we ensure the growth and prosperity of companies and small firms in particular in this country, and only in that way will we ensure a reduction in the dole queues. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill epitomises the Government's failure to deliver an economic environment which would allow a revitalisation of Australian industry, in particular because it:

(a) effectively breaks commitments to industry, in particular by failing to deliver, in conjunction with reductions in protection contained in the bill, substantial reforms in areas which increase production costs in this country, including:
(i) comprehensive labour market reform to allow genuine enterprise agreements and voluntary unionism;
(ii) promotion of full and effective competition in telecommunications;
(iii) abolition of security of tenure on the waterfront and removal of cabotage on Australian coastal waters; and
(iv) introduction of a comprehensive goods and services tax;

(b) fails to reduce all protection to all industries including the textile, clothing and footwear and automotive industries to, at most, negligible levels (that is, between zero and five per cent) by the year 2000, in conjunction with a package of reform measures; and

(c) fails to strengthen the existing anti-dumping procedures to allow Australian producers adequate defence against dumped and subsidised imports at a time when domestic protection is being phased out''.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is considering the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991, the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Customs Amendment Bill 1991. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is the largest of these Bills; indeed, it is one of the largest of its type ever considered by this Parliament and probably the most far-reaching.

speech.para: The Bill proposes to implement the proposals outlined by Senator Button on 12 March, and also some measures already introduced as customs tariff proposals. The measures announced in the Government's industry statement signal an end to the protectionist infant industry experiment which has been conducted in Australia for almost the whole of this century. Put broadly, this theory predicted that a competitive, efficient and mature industry could be created by establishing a tariff structure which allowed domestic industries to survive for an establishment period. Over time, the protective tariff wall would be removed after giving the industry time to get established and to gain the necessary skills to survive international competition. As well, Australia's extreme isolation and the consequent transportation costs tended to provide a natural protective element where local raw materials were used in the manufacturing process, but this is no longer the case.

Unfortunately, the subsequent exposure to international competition usually did not occur; indeed, successive governments often increased the rate of tariff protection to suit the short term interests prevailing at the time. This often had detrimental effects on performance in other sectors, such as increasing primary production costs. Because of the dire straits in which Australia now finds itself, the protective tariff walls are being removed. In 1988 the Government announced and began implementing a major phased reduction in both specific and general tariffs. It has recently delivered a major statement which proposes to continue, and in some cases accelerate, the tariff reductions.

The concept of tariff reductions is an inviting one. The price of goods would fall, which obviously benefits consumers. In addition, the consumer price index would be lowered, thereby dampening the measured inflation rate. To the extent to which the tariffs apply to business inputs, there would be a benefit to local producers which would hopefully boost their competitiveness. However, there is also the problem of the effect that these changes would have on the work force currently producing the goods which enjoy the tariffs. The brunt of any restructuring will fall on the employees in the passenger motor vehicle and the textile, clothing and footwear industries. These are large industries employing tens of thousands of people. These industries also have very important regional significance. For example, the Geelong region in Victoria will be very heavily affected if the large scale rationalisation of the motor vehicle building industry occurs.

Consequently the Australian Democrats are most concerned that adequate retraining facilities be available to those displaced by the tariff cuts. The Government announced some retraining measures in its March industry statement, but the funds to be set aside appear to be woefully inadequate to deal with the estimated job losses.

Before addressing these problems, it is appropriate to detail exactly what the Bill proposes to do to tariffs. The general ad valorem rate on manufactured goods will be phased down to 15 per cent or lower by July 1992. The Bill proposes to continue this reduction so that all these goods will be subject to a 5 per cent rate by 1 July 1996. There will be five annual reductions which will reduce rates by 1 per cent or 2 per cent for goods currently subject to 10 per cent and 15 per cent duties respectively.

Tariff assistance for agricultural industries will also phase down to 5 per cent by 1 July 1996, except for vegetable products which will reach the 5 per cent rate by 1 January 1998. The post-1992 arrangements for the dairy, sugar and tobacco-growing industries will be determined by a current Industry Commission inquiry. However, the Bill also proposes to adjust the existing specific tariff rate for raw and refined sugar and for related products. The proposed new rates of $76 per ton from 1 July 1991 and $55 per ton from 1 July 1992 would replace the existing rates of $95 per ton and $76 per ton respectively. This is described in the second reading speech of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) as bringing the sugar industry `back within the spirit of the 1988 decision to reduce general tariffs to a maximum of 15 per cent ad valorem equivalent by 1 July 1992'.

These existing rates were insisted upon by the Senate in 1989 after the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology conducted an inquiry into assistance for the sugar industry. We have not been convinced that the current arrangements are in any way deficient and we propose to amend the Bill to remove the proposed changes. It is very interesting to note that during the debate in the other place the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations, Mr Downer, claimed that the proposed level of tariff in this Bill was too high.

Let us look at what some of our competitors do to assist their sugar industries. Many countries provide a guaranteed price for the product their local producers supply. There is no doubt that these distortions, in the end, do more harm than good. The European Community's common agricultural policy costs European consumers hundreds of thousands of millions of dollars every year, apart from the indirect problems it causes to the efficient farmers in other countries, such as Australia.

France, for example, pays $809 per tonne for sugar. With a world price of $258 at the moment, that is a subsidy of $551 per ton. Compared with this, Thailand, with a subsidy of only $446 per ton and the United States, at only $356 per ton, look positively mean. These figures show how relatively efficient our Australian industry is. The tariff is being reduced. What is the rush? Why pre-empt the Industry Commission review?

The textile, clothing and footwear and motor vehicle industries are special cases and have special arrangements applying to them. Tariffs on passenger motor vehicles will have dropped from around 100 per cent at the beginning of the car plan to 35 per cent by 1992. This Bill proposes to continue this reduction so that tariffs on cars and on original components will be at 15 per cent by the year 2000, although the rate on replacement components will remain at 15 per cent until it aligns with the general rate in the year 2000.

The Industry Commission investigated the motor vehicle industry assistance arrangements and reported on a recommended course of action. The original draft report of the Commission recommended the reduction of tariffs for motor vehicles in four steps of 5 per cent to reach a 15 per cent rate by 1996. Due to the outcry this caused, the final report contained the eight-year phase-in period which has been adopted by the Government.

The tariffs on light commercial and four-wheel drive vehicles and the components for these vehicles will be reduced from 15 per cent in line with general tariff reductions. The export facilitation scheme is to be expanded. Credits will be calculated on the basis of $1 for every dollar of Australian automotive value added in the local content of eligible exports. Ceilings on the level of export credits which plan participants can earn have been abolished, as have been the restrictions on the sale and the transferability of export credits.

As well as other improvements, the arrangements are extended to allow for the inclusion of automotive machine tooling, automotive tooling and services relating to automotive design and production as eligible exports. Of course, the Government also announced another decision relating to the motor vehicle industry in the March statement. The decision to lower the luxury car tax is opposed by the Australian Democrats although, unfortunately, the legislation effecting the decision has already been passed by the Senate.

The Democrats can see little vision in the plan for our motor vehicle industry. Surely it is clear to everyone that the key to exporting cars in the 1990s and beyond will and indeed must be superior environmental performance. Many honourable senators will be aware of the clean air legislation which will apply in California at the end of this decade. This historic law provides that 2 per cent of new automobiles sold have to provide very low or zero emissions. Over time, this percentage will increase. Already, General Motors is working on the `impact' electric commuter car. No doubt other major manufacturers are doing similar research and development. Now is the time to put considerable research and development funds into an electric car industry in Australia. Ultimately, we may even be able to produce viable solar powered vehicles, although that is admittedly a very long term objective.

However, the Government has completely ignored this direction when framing its newest car plan. We are not saying that any direct assistance is necessary for electric vehicles. The creation of an industry would be greatly bolstered by three general measures. First, a sales tax exemption could be provided to electrically powered vehicles. The Australian Democrats have proposed such an amendment to the Senate, but it has been defeated in the past.

Secondly, we have no fuel efficiency policy. A minimum fuel economy standard was recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in its report on reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect which was released in January of this year. The Committee recommended that a minimum fuel economy standard of eight litres per 100 kilometres be set for all new vehicles sold in Australia by 1998 and that this standard be reduced to six litres per 100 kilometres by 2005.

Thirdly, we need a serious re-use and recycling policy for cars and their parts. Recent reports show that the German car manufacturer BMW is currently investigating the possibility of total recycling of all car parts by placing a deposit on vehicles. Not surprisingly, the German Government is also investigating the possibility of legislation to enforce this type of scheme. Again, we are in danger of being left behind.

The Government could and should intervene directly by the use of government purchasing policy to further influence the development of world class environmental standards. The Comcar fleet could and should be used to trial alternative clean transport options. State and local governments should also become involved to provide a market for alternative commuter vehicles.

The Bill also proposes to implement the Government's revised plan for the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The present plan for these industries was announced in 1986, came into full operation on 1 March 1989 and is scheduled to run until 1995. The Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority was established to revitalise the TCF industries and to ease the restructuring necessary to make these industries more competitive. The Authority released a state of the industry report in 1990 which concluded that any adjustment which had occurred up until that time was not related to the industry plan.

The major adjustment pressures from the plan are expected to emerge over the next one to three years. This convinced the Government to accelerate and extend significantly the rate of tariff reduction in these sectors. The new arrangements will extend the end of the plan from 1995 to the year 2000.

Fortunately, the Bill also proposes to introduce an import credits scheme from 1 July 1991. Import credits will initially accrue at the rate of 30 per cent of the domestic value added of TCF exports and will phase down to 15 per cent over the period of the scheme. The credits can be used only to reduce tariffs on TCF imports and are freely transferable. The Democrats welcome this initiative. We do not share the view of the Opposition on this matter. In fact, we cannot understand how the Opposition can be committed to the abolition of all tariffs and yet not support a scheme which grants tariff exemptions on the basis of export performance. The scheme automatically phases down to 15 per cent of the domestic value added over its lifetime and has general industry support.

As far as the export facilitation scheme is concerned, we would appreciate it if the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) could explain in his concluding remarks why the proposed scheme only grants import credits at the rate of 30 per cent when similar arrangements in the motor vehicle industry grant import credits at the rate of 100 per cent.

In addition, all quotas will be terminated on 1 March 1993 and out-of-quota duty rates currently programmed for 1 March 1992 will be halved. The industry statement also promised to involve the Prices Surveillance Authority in monitoring the prices of TCF goods from the beginning of the implementation of the new phasing arrangements. The Australian Democrats welcome this move.

As we have heard, the Bill also proposes to phase out the existing developing country preference for Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore. The tariff preference arrangements are a development incentive which is provided by developed nations in order to assist developing nations in world trade. The preference is a flat 5 per cent reduction in whatever the relevant tariff would otherwise be. The reclassification of these four so-called `Asian tiger' nations is really just recognition of the fact that these countries are no longer in the underdeveloped world. It is in fact good news that this preference is no longer needed by these countries. Indeed, the trading performance of Taiwan, in particular, over the last decade has been quite amazing.

The removal of the preference is very gentle. Existing rates will be frozen until the phasing arrangements which are currently in place or are to be instituted fall to the rates currently enjoyed by these four nations. Thereafter, the general tariff rate will apply to imports from these countries. This move is supported by the Democrats-indeed, my colleague Senator Spindler called for this measure to be included in the industry statement.

The Bill also proposes to modify the duty free provisions for capital equipment. These measures should assist in the development of Australian industry by reducing fixed costs. This will assist in adding value to Australian resources by Australian industry. For many years the Australian Democrats have believed that much greater use should be made of financial disincentives to export unprocessed resources. Of course, the classic example in this regard is the destruction of our forests in order to provide woodchips to overseas pulp mills. We then import the high value-added paper products.
This futile cycle could be discouraged by levying a tax on non-plantation woodchips which are exported.

The specific exemptions to be granted under the Bill are for minerals processing equipment not ordinarily made in Australia; components for the repair, modification and construction of ships of greater than 150 gross construction tons; and certain printed circuit boards and machinery for working advanced materials which qualify for bounty assistance.

In addition, more capital equipment will attract the split consignment provisions which allow the importation of complete capital equipment or parts of this equipment in separate consignments at the rate of duty applying to the complete plant. The Australian Democrats also support these proposals.

As well as these historic measures which I have detailed, the Bill also deals with some amendments which have been previously introduced as customs tariff proposals. These relate to various matters, but I wish to discuss only two of them. First, the Government announced the abolition of the duty on wheelchairs, defibrillators and heart pacemakers as from 1 January 1991. The relevant rates are 17 per cent and 15 per cent respectively. This is a long overdue step which has been vigorously advocated by the Democrats for years. Indeed, just last year, Senator Spindler moved amendments to the customs tariff legislation to effect this policy. Those amendments were defeated last year, but the Democrats' persistence in the matter was rewarded by Senator Button's announcement by press release that the exemptions were to be granted. It is a great pity that this could not have happened earlier.

The final matter I wish to mention on this Bill is the indexation of the revenue duty rate on certain mixed spirituous beverages made from ethyl alcohol, wine and fruit juice. Apparently, this amendment is necessary to close a loophole which granted a huge market advantage to an imported beverage because of a very low rate of tax which arose because of the particular way the law is constructed. I am informed of one product-which apparently has the name `Nick-off'-to which this amendment is directed. I would appreciate it if the Minister could also explain to the Senate exactly what the situation is in regard to this matter.

The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is an omnibus Bill which proposes amending five current bounty Acts pursuant to measures announced in the industry statement last March. The decision announced to alter the book bounty has been reversed by the House of Representatives, and we welcome that decision. The textile, clothing and footwear bounties are also to be altered as follows: the textile yarn bounty will be phased from 30 per cent value added on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995 and replaced by a five per cent tariff; the bed sheeting bounty will be extended to 30 June 1995 without review but will phase down from 16 per cent per square metre on 1 July 1992 to zero by 1 July 1995; and the bounty on textile printing will phase down to zero by 1 July 1995.

The eligibility for bounty assistance will be withdrawn for the beaming, warping and sizing processes which occur before fabric production. Repeat winding is also to be excluded from eligibility. These alterations are expected to yield about $4m in savings annually. These amendments arise from the recommendations of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority into the administration of the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981.

The Bill also proposes to continue the existing bounty on machine tools and robots which would have otherwise expired on 30 June 1991. The bounty will now expire on 30 June 1997. The Bureau of Industry Economics conducted a review of this bounty and concluded that the scheme had been effective in maintaining a viable machine tool industry and encouraging industry restructuring into high technology areas, including the production of robots. In short, the targeted market intervention by the Government has been successful and we are happy to support the continuation of this program.

The scheme is to be extended in a number of ways. First, the bounty's coverage will be extended into the area of processing technology for new materials such as ceramics, polymers and composite materials. As the Minister said in his second reading speech:
Whilst there is little local production at present in machine tools for the working of such advanced materials, this measure should encourage tooling in such areas.

This playing field is being tilted towards future technology. This is not a strategy of picking winners but simply the mature recognition that industry will be heading in a particular direction and that Australia's best interests lie in us also following that direction. The bounty may make it worth while for Australian firms to undertake investments which would otherwise never be viable.
Debate interrupted.

interject.speaker: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I put the question:

interject.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I take this opportunity to pay brief tribute to the successes that have finally been achieved by Eritrea and the Eritrean People's Liberation Front during the last month. I am sure that most honourable senators will be aware of the almost 30-year unbroken civil war that has been raging in the Horn of Africa. The Eritreans would not regard it as a civil war, because they have always maintained their right to independence and to secede from the federation which was imposed on them.

speech.para: I do not think that anyone thought the fall would be quite as dramatic or as complete as it has been in recent weeks. By the `fall' I refer to the much-publicised and well-celebrated departure of President Mengistu, who no doubt would have few rivals in a claim to being the bloodiest of Africa's dictators-on a par, I would have thought, with Idi Amin. The brutal rule of the Dergue over the last 17 years has meant that a tremendous rebuilding program will need to be undertaken both in Ethiopia and in those provinces to the north of Addis Ababa.

I think it is particularly encouraging that the response, since the fall of Mengistu and the liberation of Addis, together with the success of the Eritreans in resuming control of Asmara, the capital, in many ways is the culmination of all of their dreams. Thomas Keneally's fine book Towards Asmara potently summarised the symbolic significance of Asmara in that context. The gaining of control of Assab, the port on the Red Sea, in conjunction with Massawa, means that the Eritreans now are totally in control of their own area.

I think the most encouraging feature is that, even though when one reads various newspaper accounts and tries to analyse the texture of the regimes that are likely to come to government and the colour of the various fronts that have been waging war and one still sees that on the one hand they can be described as traditional Marxists and on the other as being very much aware of the limitations of Marxism, increasingly there are signs that they are not likely to fall into the same traps that have befallen most of the liberated countries in Africa and most of the independent countries in Africa, of which there are probably now some 48.

As a result, I think it is promising to see the developments in recent days, particularly the talks in London, which appear to have resulted in all of the disparate groups agreeing that those independence talks ought to proceed and that there ought to be a referendum conducted in Addis Ababa and a separate referendum-an act of self-determination-for the people of Eritrea. It is of great significance also that the United States Government has indicated its support for such an act of self-determination. Certainly, that is the first time the United States has officially sanctioned Eritrea's call for a referendum.

In the meantime, the Eritreans are prepared to accept an interim government, a nominally Marxist government of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front in Addis Ababa, but they have made it very clear that they do not want to participate in that government and that they will be seeking their own autonomous regime-that is where their efforts will be concentrated. I think that does show not only a consistency of purpose but also a recognition that it is going to be a very fragile dismantling, a very difficult process which should not be rushed into. That is why the fact that the independence process is likely to take a period of months before there is any finality achieved even in Addis Ababa, I think, underlines the importance of mature political approaches.

I think all of the parties in Ethiopia broadly described started off as avowed Marxists and, indeed, in many ways I think Mengistu has been largely responsible for discrediting those sorts of notions and aspirations. His was probably the last country in the world to declare itself a people's republic. It was certainly the last country to set up a Marxist-Leninist party in 1984. When one recognises the enormity of the offences and the brutality perpetrated by his regime harking back to the red terror in the late 1970s-I was certainly in Addis Ababa and witnessed the results of that, and I well remember stories about heads being hung on lampposts to warn people against confronting the regime, most of whose cabinet members were personally executed by Mengistu-one can see that a regime that called itself Marxist-Leninist was really doing its best to totally discredit that sort of a label. Given the passage of events in eastern Europe and elsewhere in the last couple of years, I think all of the parties to the conflict realise that that sort of slogan and that sort of recipe can offer them no hope at all.

The support of the United States will be very important in ensuring that we have mature progress. I was particularly heartened to read comments by Mr Issias Afwerki, who represented the Eritrean People's Liberation Front in talks in London earlier this month. A newspaper article quoting his remarks stated:
The Eritrean guerillas might have been influenced by Marxist ideas-``if you were not a leftist at university in the 1960s, you were ostracised''-but peasants and farmers had had enough of such ideas.

Of course, he has travelled very extensively in recent years promoting the Eritrean cause. On the subject of the role of the United States, which is normally the paramount villain in the demonology of most emerging nations, the article stated:

The US could still play a key role in bringing democracy to Ethiopia, he believed. Its leverage was moral rather than political. But the US influence-the target of angry demonstrations in Addis Ababa-``would definitely have a constructive effect''.
He was also sympathetic to the efforts by the former colonial masters, the Italians, British and French to broker peace in the Horn of Africa.
He had little time for more ``revolutionary'' regimes that professed support for Eritreans, especially radical Arab States.
The interference of the Libyans, Syrians and Iraqis had been motivated mainly by a wish to destabilise the Addis Ababa government-a recipient of Israeli aid.

Those comments show a maturity of political purpose that will serve Eritrea well in the years ahead. I take this opportunity tonight to acknowledge that it has been a war without parallel. I do not think there has been another civil war in the twentieth century that has gone on for as long as this war has. It has, I think, reached its culmination in a way that the Eritreans always believed it would. However, those who have followed its progress had come to think it would never reach a conclusion.

We are seeing some very historic events, and some very constructive moves are taking place which will, I think, result in a negotiated settlement that will not simply blow the borders apart but allow for genuine acts of self-determination to result in the Eritreans in particular being able to conduct their own affairs. After all these years of struggle, they have certainly managed to achieve miracles on the way through, not just with hospitals and almost complete cities underground but also with very extensive education systems, all of which have had to withstand the barrage of constant bombing overhead. Having come through that sort of 30-year baptism, they are going to be well placed to undertake the just as difficult transition to peace and to economic progress.

I pay particular tribute to the efforts of Fessahaie Abraham, as the representative of the Eritrean Relief Association in Australia. I speak in my capacity as a parliamentary patron of that Association, together with Senator Schacht from the Australian Labor Party. We are both very pleased indeed with the passage of events to date. We hope that the Australian Government will do all it can to ensure that whatever role it can play will be played, and that whatever assistance we can sensibly offer will be offered. I have in mind particularly technical assistance, not just the transfer of funds.

We are all aware of the endemic droughts and famines that beset the Horn of Africa. This year is no exception. The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations in Rome is still saying that the level of Western assistance is by no means enough, and that we still face the prospect of drought and famine for some seven to eight million people in the region. An enormous amount can be done on the emergency relief front and on the political and diplomatic fronts.

I hope, and I am sure that it will be the case, that Australia will continue to take a keen interest. A number of refugees have come to this country from that region. They have been model citizens. They have made the Government aware of the need to assist not just the Eritreans but all those others who have been victims of strife in the region and, in the years to come, for Australia to continue to play a constructive role.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.42 p.m.

proctext.para: The following documents were tabled:
Defence Act-Determinations under section 58b 1991-Nos 46, 47 and 50.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

question.speaker: Knowles Sen S.C.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1991:

question.para: (1) What is the total expenditure by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on the employment of Grant in Aid workers with ethnic organisations.
(2) What are the standard salary and associated costs for each Grant in Aid worker.
(3) How many Grant in Aid workers are currently funded through the department.
(4) What monitoring systems are employed to ensure that Grant in Aid workers perform their duties.

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The total expenditure by DILGEA in 1990/91 on the employment of workers with ethnic and other community organisations under the Grant-in-Aid Scheme is estimated to be $9,740,000.

(2) There are four (4) levels of subsidy (to cover salary and associated costs) payable to organisations funded under the Grant-in-Aid Scheme. The level of grant is determined by the nature and requirements of the work program finalised and agreed to by grantee organisations and my Department, and the qualifications, experience and knowledge of the worker employed. Subsidy levels are adjusted annually to take into account cost increases.
The current annual values of the four levels are as follows (each level has two values because the ``on-cost'' component varies according to need):
(3) The Grant-in-Aid Scheme currently funds 283 workers of whom 209 are full-time and 74 are part-time. The number of full-time and parttime workers is not fixed.
The booklet outlining conditions of eligibility and rules of operation for the Grant-in-Aid Scheme explains funding levels in more detail. A copy has been provided to Senator Knowles.

(4) Grant holders are required to annually review the performance of the grant, in particular, progress in implementing the agreed work program. This review report is then considered by the Department which negotiates a further work program with the grantee detailing what is to be achieved over the next year.
In addition to the review report grant holders are required to provide the following documents:
* a completed accountability statement (within three months of the end of their financial year);
* a copy of the organisation's Annual Report (as soon as available);
* a copy of the minutes of the Annual General Meeting or any special general meeting where changes to the Constitution are approved; and
* a list of Management Committee members.

The Management Committee of each organisation funded under the Grant-in-Aid Scheme actually employs the worker and monitors his or her day-to-day work. Workers report regularly to their Management Committees.

question.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 May 1991:

question.para: (1) What will be the estimated fortnightly increase in expenditure on Department of Social Security pensions which will result from the `deeming' rate being reduced from 10 to 8 per cent.
(2) How many pensioners will need to inform the department of a change in their income as a result of the reduction in the `deeming' rate.
(3) What are the estimated administrative and staffing costs entailed in reducing the `deeming' rate from 10 to 8 per cent.
(4) How many pensioners over 80 years of age will the department contact individually about the `deeming' arrangements.
(5) What are the estimated administrative and staffing costs entailed in contacting these pensioners individually.
(6) What is the estimated total fortnightly decrease in expenditure on pensions which will result from the `deeming' provisions being applied to pensioners over 80 years of age.

answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is more meaningful to refer to the increase in expenditure on an annual, rather than on a fortnightly, basis. This is because the impact will change from fortnight to fortnight, as additional numbers of pensioners (eg new grants and reviews) become affected by deeming.

In annual terms, the Budget estimate of savings from deeming on cash and accounts was $51.9 million in 1991-92. The revised estimate of the decrease in expenditure on Department of Social Security pensions on the basis of a 10% deeming rate was $95 million in the first full year. This was based on the annualized effect of the impact of the implementation of deeming in March 1991 and projections of additional pensioners affected over the period to the end of 1991-92. The reduction in the deeming rate to 8% is estimated approximately to halve the decrease in expenditure on pensions. Thus the savings are likely to be about $47.5 million in 1991-92 compared with the Budget estimate of $51.9 million.

(2) Pensioners whose pensions have been reduced by the deeming provisions because they have deemed income included in their pension assessment had their pension entitlements automatically adjusted for the reduction in the deeming rate, with effect from the 6 June pension payday.

For pensioners with money in pensioner accounts which were paying the previous deeming rate of 10%, if banks and other financial institutions decide to reduce interest rates on these accounts in response to the reduced deeming rate, it is in the interest of pensioners to advise the Department. This ensures that they are paid any increase in pension which is due to them.

To make it easy for pensioners to advise the Department of special pensioner accounts which may have a reduction in interest rates because of the lower deeming rate, a special deeming data collection centre has been established. The centre will enable quick reassessment of pensions resulting from falls in interest rates. Pensioners with these accounts will not need to contact their bank to check whether the interest rate has fallen, as the Department will do this for them.

(3) It is not possible to identify separately all costs associated with the reduction in the deeming rate. Most of the tasks associated with the change (such as providing information, computer processing and pension reassessments) are part of ongoing, normal staff duties and processes and cannot be separated out. Information about the change and action required by pensioners was included in the May edition of Age Pension News.
Separate processes for which costs can be identified are as follows:
* Set-up and operate the National Data Collection Centre: $442,000 (i)
* Departmental letters to non-age pensioners informing them of deeming rate change: $22,000
(i) is an estimate only, as final costs will depend on the volume of telephone calls to the centre.
However, all costs associated with the change are being met from within existing Departmental staffing and administrative allocations, with no supplementation.

(4) It is estimated that around 54,000 pensioners aged 80 years or more (including partners) are currently being paid a higher rate of pension because the deeming rules are not being applied to them until the Department contacts them to explain the deeming rules.

(5) The special contact arrangements for pensioners aged 80 or more are being undertaken by Departmental staff, including FISP officers, as part of their duties. In some States, special units have been set up and in others the procedures are being undertaken by Area Office staff of the Department.

It is not possible to identify separately the cost of these measures. However, the measures are being undertaken within existing staff and administrative allocations for the Department, without supplementation.
(6) It is more meaningful to refer to the decrease in expenditure on an annual, rather than a fortnightly, basis. This is because the impact will change from fortnight to fortnight.

In annual terms, the decrease in expenditure on Social Security pensions as a result of applying the deeming provisions to the pensioners referred to at (4) above is estimated to be $5.6 million in a full year. This is included in the overall decrease in expenditure of $95 million as a result of the deeming provisions at (1) above.
